PETITION.TITLE: States Grants Schools Assistance Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament
The petition of the undersigned shows:

that the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act 1988 includes legislation, Part III-Changes to Non-Government Schools and New Non-Government Schools, designed to inhibit the establishment, growth and development of these schools in Australia by the imposition of restrictive provisions in the areas of funding, enrolments and approval criteria.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the senators in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That in 1987/88 the Federal Government paid $6.4 million from taxpayers funds for 61,879 abortions under Medicare Items 6469 and 274/275 alone.
That in the same year Federal Government grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies and abolish Government funding of abortion.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the senators in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Lithuania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the honourable members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. Australians believe in freedom and democracy for all people.
2. The annexation of the Baltic states of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia to USSR is not recognised as lawful by Australia; these Baltic states were illegally occupied by USSR.
3. Lithuanians have suffered their own ``Katyn Massacres'' after the infamous Stalin-Hitler pact of 1939.
4. Lithuania's restoration of independence of 11 March 1990, is a peaceful and democratic expression of the desires of the overwhelming majority of the peoples of Lithuania.

5. Australian Government should support the democratically elected Government of the Republic of Lithuania, headed by President V. Landsbergis. Australia should extend humanitarian aid to Lithuanian peoples and full recognition of the Lithuanian Government.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from 1,052 citizens) and Short (from 198 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a Universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469,274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the Senate will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws the attentions of the Senate to our opposition to any attempt to restrict access to the rebate for abortions under Medicare.

Medicare is a universal health care system and as such the availability of any schedule item should never be determined on the basis of the moral values of a minority of citizens. Equity and access within the present system should be the right of all Australian citizens and guaranteed to them.

The Webster Abortion Funding Abolition Bill would, if successful, severely limit the availability of rebates for items 6494, 274 and 275. The effect would be twofold-further discrimination against all women (particularly those who could not afford the full cost of this procedure) and an invasion of the confidentiality that exists between client and medical practitioner.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any related items on the Medicare schedule.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled;
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we the undersigned, having great concern over the effect that increasing availability of pornographic material is having in hastening the spread of moral pollution in our nation, call upon the Federal Government to:

1. To dramatically improve the Federal Attorney-General's Guidelines for Classification of Video tapes/discs, which restrict the importation, production, sale or hire, screening in private homes and especially mailing by Australia Post, so as to include the total prohibition of any pornographic, obscene or blasphemous video cassette, or film which exploits or degrades women as sex objects, or which contain child pornography, bestiality, sodomy, group sex or violent sex acts with women, such as rape and pack rape, sadism and torture, etc., or which promotes homosexuality or lesbianism;
2. Resist moves to have Federal Funds granted to subsidise the production and export of X-rated videos; and
3. Implement the decision of all State Attorney's-General to have the distribution of X-rated Videos in the Australian Capital Territory outlawed.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will protect our society, especially women and children from moral pollution and its harmful effects.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That we the undersigned, having great concern that Canberra is now the ``Porn Capital'' of Australia and because of the spread of moral pollution in our nation, call upon the Federal Government to introduce immediate legislation in support of existing State Legislation:

1. To provide strict controls over the importation, production, sale, hire or mailing of video-cassettes particularly in the A.C.T., with the open sale and/or hire of only G, PG, and M-rated video cassettes; and the total prohibition of the sale or hire of R rated video-cassettes, so that R rated films can only be viewed in an adult theatre by persons over 18 years. We totally reject the concept of ``X'' rated or ``N.V.E.'' rated video-cassettes, which would allow the legal sale and hire of hard-core pornographic videos for viewing in the homes of our nation, which would endanger our children; and
2. To give whole-hearted support to Senator Walters's Private Member's Bill to implement the recommendations of the Select Committee on Videos; and

3. To dramatically improve the Federal Attorney-General's Guidelines for Classification of Video tapes/discs, which restrict the importation, production, sale or hire, screening in private homes and especially mailing by Australia Post, so as to include the total prohibition of any pornographic, obscene or blasphemous video cassette, or film which exploits or degrades women as sex objects, or which contain child pornography, bestiality, sodomy, group sex or violent sex acts with women, such as rape and pack rape, sadism and torture, etc., or which promotes homosexuality or lesbianism;
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will protect our society, especially women and children from moral pollution and its harmful effects.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tobacco: Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament. The Petition of the undersigned shows: THAT TOBACCO ADVERTISING SHOULD BE BANNED. Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should: CONSIDER LEGISLATION BE ENACTED TO ENSURE THAT THIS OCCURS, and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Animal Patenting
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Australian Senate

The undersigned citizens of Australia, and custodians of the Earth, oppose the patenting of animals, and the processes for altering them. Animal patents would *reduce biodiversity, *compromise animal welfare, *concentrate ownership of breeding stock, and *allow companies to appropriate the fruit of centuries of selective breeding. We note with concern that many applications for animal patents have been lodged with the Australian Patents Office and without your intervention they may soon be approved.
Please take all possible steps immediately to ensure that:
1. The Patents Office rejects all existing applications for animal patents and declines to accept any more:
2. The Senate amends the Patents Bill 1989 to prohibit the patenting of animals.
We pray that all members of the Australian Senate will act on this petition.

PETITION.TITLE: Nurrungar
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
Nurrungar is a US military communications base located about 500 km north-west of Adelaide. Last year, the Australian Government renewed its lease for another 10 years.

Nurrungar receives and processes information on Soviet missile launches and nuclear tests from US satellites. Nurrungar is also part of the US Star Wars network. The base therefore involves Australia in preparations for nuclear war.
Nurrungar is an acknowledged target in the event of a nuclear conflict.
With the launch of new satellites in the early 1990s, any arms control role Nurrungar may possibly have played will be redundant.
Australia has little control over or even knowledge of Nurrungar's role, thus undermining our independence and sovereignty.
Nurrungar is part of a land claim by the traditional owners of the area, the Kukutha people.
Available figures suggest we pay $30 million a year towards the cost of running Nurrungar.
Latest opinion polls show 51% of Australians do not want US communications bases with a nuclear role.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Immediately serve notice on the United States Government to terminate the lease on Nurrungar.
Close the base at Nurrungar and grant the Kukutha land claim to the area in 1990.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Geurie, New South Wales, Water Supply
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
A petition of the undersigned citizens shows,
Our disappointment at the continued failures and substandard supply of water to the village of Geurie, New South Wales over the past 40 years.
We are concerned that as Wellington Shire Council ratepayers we are facing compound increases of 15% p.a. over the next 7 years on our rates.

We are duly concerned that the deficit in funding for the proposed Augmentation Scheme by Wellington Shire Council and Public Works Department will further be passed onto the ratepayers and have an adverse effect on the lives of the Geurie residents.

We your Petitioners implore you the Senate give due consideration to ensure that the Wellington Shire Councils application for ``Country Towns Water Supply Improvement Programme'' ``COWSIP'' Funding be approved so that an adequate supply of water can be delivered to the village of Geurie New South Wales.

PETITION.TITLE: Privacy Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws attention to the Senate of their concern regarding proposed changes to the laws governing credit reporting, as suggested in the Bill `The Privacy Amendment Bill 1989'.
The proposed reforms will:
Restrict the legitimate use of credit checking by business who sell/supply goods and/or services to their customers on credit terms.

The proposals/reforms will prevent businesses from determining the solvency of their customers and will increase the financial risk of credit providers, leading to an increase in company liquidations and individual bankruptcies.

Additional costs to business from bad debts due to the lack of adequate credit checking information will result in the increased prices/charges and will result in credit providers refusing credit facilities.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate will call on the Government to refer these proposals restricting credit checking to a Senate Standing Committee for further consideration before proceeding with the matter.

PETITION.TITLE: Violent Television Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
We are concerned about the increase in violent television programmes for children and particularly those programmes promoting violent toys that are available for sale in Australia.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray;

That you support the Broadcasting (Prohibition of Violent Programmes for Children) Act 1988 which has been presented by WA Independent Senator for Nuclear Disarmament, Jo Vallentine. This act aims to prohibit the broadcasting of children's TV programmes that are violent and that promote toys modelled on characters, weapons or other war accessories which are also available for sale in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Hill (from 39 citizens) and Short (from 15 citizens).

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium

PETITION.TITLE: May Gibbs Home, Nucote
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament, the Petition of the undersigned shows:

As delegates to the Second National Curriculum Resources Collection Conference, we are concerned to preserve Nucote, the home of May Gibbs, creator of Snugglepot and Cuddlepie. As the home of one of Australia's long-enduring and much-loved classics of children's literature that continues to inspire a love of the Australian bush and wildlife, it is worthy of preservation for future generations of Australians.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Preserve Nucote, the home of May Gibbs, as part of the cultural heritage of all Australians and as a fitting gesture to commemorate the International Literacy Year 1990.
Your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Day
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament
The Petition of the undersigned shows:
That Australia Day is celebrated as a public holiday on different days in the month of January in the various States and Territories.
Your petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should:
Nominate 26th January as a National Public Holiday for celebration of Australia Day.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Warships, Australian Ports
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President of the Senate and senators and the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

Noting that nuclear armed warships continue to be invited to Sydney Harbour, we the undersigned citizens of Australia, strongly urge that the Australian Parliament prohibit the entry of nuclear armed or nuclear capable vessels into Sydney Harbour and other Australian ports.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Peace Tax Trust Fund Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
At present all Australians, including those who conscientiously object to war and the preparation of war, are required by law for a portion of their income tax to be spent on military use.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray;

That you support the Peace Tax Trust Fund Bill 1989 which has been presented by Western Australian Independent Senator, Jo Vallentine. This Bill does not propose that anyone be permitted to withhold tax, but that the law should be changed to allow conscientious objectors to divert the military portion of their tax into more positive and socially useful programmes.

PETITION.TITLE: Environmental Bill of Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate assembled:
The Humble Petition of certain Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth
That there is urgent need for the United Nations to adopt an Environmental Bill of Rights using the 1987 Report by the World Commission on Environment and Development.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament pass an `Environmental Bill of Rights', therefore giving Australia a leading role in environmental protection.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON HEALTH LEGISLATION AND HEALTH INSURANCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the committee known as the Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance, constituted by a resolution of the Senate on 13 June 1989, be re-constituted under the same terms and with the same functions and powers.

(2) That the committee have power to consider and use for its purpose the minutes of evidence and records of the Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance appointed in the previous Parliament.
(3) That the committee present its final report on or before 29 June 1990.
(4) That the foregoing provisions of this resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the standing orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the standing orders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) notes with sympathy and concern the thousands of people in the Queensland towns and districts of Charleville, Augathella, Blackall, Alpha and Jericho, who have sustained severe damage to their homes, businesses and properties and suffered stock losses through the recent floods that devastated western Queensland; and

(b) calls on both the Queensland State Government and the Federal Government to announce, as a matter of urgency, their disaster assistance plan, so that small businesses, farmers, graziers and home owners can make proper economic decisions, in order to evaluate and assess the viability of their future in western Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) welcomes the decision of the Soviet Government to allow Soviet Jews who wish to emigrate from the Soviet Union to do so;
(b) calls upon the Soviet Government to honour its agreement permitting direct flights from the Soviet Union to Israel to facilitate free migration of Soviet Jewry to the state of Israel;

(c) calls on the Soviet Government to permit an increase in the number of flights from Moscow which could cater by indirect routes for such migration, pending the commencement of such direct flights; and
(d) requests Mr President to convey this resolution to the Soviet representative in Australia.
Mr President, I seek leave to make a 15-second statement.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been told that I could have put down a stronger notice of motion, but I advise the Senate that the motion of which I have given notice is identical in substance to the motion passed in the Parliament of New South Wales on 2 May with the support of all parties. My hope is that this motion could be similarly treated.

DEBATE.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES AND QUEENSLAND: FLOODS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes that:
(i) the recent floods in the west of Queensland and New South Wales have been the worst in a hundred years,
(ii) many families and individuals have lost their possessions and suffered great hardship and many local businesses cannot be re-established without substantial aid;
(b) recognises that it is now three weeks since the onset of the floods and that the task of rebuilding is urgent;

(c) calls on the Federal Government in concert with the State governments to explain in detail, as a matter of urgency, what help, financial and otherwise, will come from government sources so that those people affected can plan for the future reconstruction of their lives and communities;

(d) further notes that, for the towns downstream of the floods, appropriate planning was greatly hindered because no accurate predictions could be made of the likely flood levels, given the complex geography and the variables involved in the great western river systems, as opposed to the eastern coastal rivers; and
(e) calls on the Federal Government to fund an adequate research program as a matter of urgency so that an accurate computer model can be generated and developed to aid planners in future floods.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) recognises the enormous assistance which has been given to our flood stricken victims by Australian Defence Force personnel;

(b) recognises that whenever disaster strikes in our country in peacetime or in war, the Australian Defence Force is willing, ready and able to swing into action regardless of personal inconvenience or danger; and
(c) expresses its gratitude to the men and women of the Australian Defence Force for their continuing selfless contribution to their fellow Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That on the occasion of the 75th anniversary of the landing at Gallipoli, the Senate-

(a) expresses its profound gratitude and appreciation of the inestimable sacrifices made by all Australian men and women who have fought in wars under the Australian flag, so that we may have the way of life we have developed and the national stature we have achieved; and

(b) notes the example of interdependence, comradeship, selflessness and discipline demonstrated by all those who served the country and calls on the Government and the people of Australia to not have had those sacrifices made in vain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) supports an independent and free Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia;
(b) condemns the Soviet Union for its campaign of intimidation specifically against Lithuania;
(c) calls on the Soviet authorities to abandon their blockade of vital raw materials to Lithuania and to allow the immediate resumption of oil, gas, food and medical supplies;
(d) calls on the Soviet Union to accept the declarations of independence by the Baltic Republics and to facilitate a peaceful transition to their full autonomy; and
(e) calls on the Australian Government to ensure that the Australian people's support for the people of the Baltic Republics is heard in Moscow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) notes with concern the damage and devastation that flooding has caused to north western NSW and parts of Queensland and Victoria, resulting in soil and property damage and emotional distress to thousands of families;
(b) expresses sympathy to those people who have lost family, homes, businesses, machinery, pets and livestock;

(c) commends the defence forces for their quick response to calls for use of aircraft to assist in the evacuation and joins with the evacuees from towns such as Nyngan and Charleville in thanking the forces for their many acts of kindness and care, including transport, housing and feeding of people and livestock;
(d) applauds the courage and fortitude of the residents of towns and surrounding areas and acknowledges the community spirit with which they have bravely faced the disaster and its aftermath; and

(e) calls on the Government: (i) to put in train immediately, effective relief measures that take into consideration the financial burdens of all those affected by flood damage, including employees, self employed people, farmers, shop owners, motel and hotel keepers, local Councils-all of whom will need help if these flooded towns are to be rejuvenated and restored, and (ii) to undertake a thorough review of both disaster prevention measures and emergency procedures so that flood prone areas can be better prepared and protected in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes with concern the default by the USSR on wool payments to the value of $100m;
(b) expresses concern regarding the Soviet Union's capacity to maintain its $1b annual value of imports from Australia; and
(c) calls on the Government to press on with the discussions with Moscow over the Soviet Union's capacity to meet credit payments on time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes that Australia does not recognise the 1940 incorporation of the Baltic nations of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia into the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics;
(b) recognises the inalienable right of the peoples of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia to full independence and the establishment of political systems of their own choice;

(c) notes that the parliaments of Lithuania and Latvia have, on 11 March and 4 May respectively, declared their independence from the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and that the parliament of Estonia has indicated its intention to move to a position of independence from the USSR;
(d) congratulates the peoples and leaders of the Baltic nations on their courage and determination in asserting their rights to independence and self-determination;

(e) commends the government of the Soviet Union for the tolerance and restraint with which it has responded to the demands for enhanced political freedom in the Baltic states and other satellite nations, while expressing the Senate's concern over threatened and actual economic reprisals against the Baltic nations;

(f) calls upon the Australian Government to validate and fortify ``in a positive and constructive way'' the claim of the Baltic nations to full independence by extending full diplomatic recognition to the governments of Latvia and Lithuania; and

(g) calls upon the governments of the Baltic nations and the USSR to negotiate such agreements on their future economic and political relationships as, while not compromising the independence of the Baltic nations, will duly recognise the inter-dependence of all peoples and the need for friendship and cooperation between neighbouring states.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes with grave concern:

(i) the worsening crisis in Australia's balance of payments, with a deficit on current account of $1.8 billion in March and an estimated deficit of $20 billion for financial year 1989/90, making a cumulative deficit of $95 billion in the seven years of the Hawke Government,
(ii) the further increase in Australia's inflation rate in the twelve months to March 1990,
(iii) the continuing record levels of real interest rates and the hardship this is causing to millions of Australian homebuyers and persons engaged in small business, and
(iv) the rapid deterioration in the outlook for employment, investment and output;
(b) condemns the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance for refusing to acknowledge either the existence of the economic crisis or the need for urgent action to correct it;

(c) welcomes the honest, forthright exposure by the former Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) of the Government's unwillingness and inability to take the necessary hard decisions to remedy the recession the Government itself has, as Senator Walsh has said, engineered;

(d) calls upon the Government as a matter of utmost urgency to reverse its disastrous economic policies of fiscal irresponsibility, centralised wage fixation, and non-existent micro economic reform, thereby resulting in dangerously high interest rates, staggering business failures, rising unemployment, negative growth in GDP and stagnant productivity growth; and

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That these Bills be now read a second time.

I table the explanatory memoranda. I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard. The reason for seeking leave to incorporate is that these Bills were introduced in the House of Representatives in the previous Parliament by the then Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
FEDERAL AIRPORTS CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1990

A central plank in the Government's micro-economic reform agenda for restructuring the public sector is that government business enterprises (GBEs) should be as efficient as possible and responsive to consumers' needs.

The GBEs within the Transport and Communications portfolio, in addition to producing final goods and services for consumers, also produce intermediate inputs for the rest of the economy, with a resulting impact on Australia's overall cost structures and the ability of Australian businesses to compete internationally.

The Government sees the commercialisation of GBEs as a necessary and fundamental pre-condition to improvements in efficiency. GBEs such as the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) and Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) are therefore being placed on a more commercial footing, bringing them more into line with the disciplines traditionally associated with private sector enterprises.
This Bill, together with the Civil Aviation Amendment Bill 1989, represents the legislative changes necessary to finalise the Government's reform of its aviation industry enterprises.

The reform package accords broadly with reform packages for other enterprises in the Transport and Communications portfolio which were announced in the ministerial statement of 25 May 1988 ``Reshaping the Transport and Communications Government Business Enterprises''.

However, as a relatively recent piece of legislation, the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986 already incorporates a number of measures which accord closely with changes made to other public authorities through the GBE reform process. For example, the Act establishes corporate planning and financial targets as the basis for Government oversight of the FAC.

To some extent, therefore, the Bill represents fine-tuning of the existing strategic controls over the Corporation to bring them more closely into line with other reform packages agreed by the Government. It also removes a range of detailed controls which the Government still exercises over the activities of the Corporation.

In addition to presenting a package of reforms for the Federal Airports Corporation, the Bill includes provisions which will allow the Corporation to participate in arrangements to prevent or deal with hijacking or other acts of unlawful interference with civil aviation. I now turn to specific provisions contained in the Bill.

A major change provided for in the Bill is the scrutiny of proposed statutory charges levied by the FAC under the Act by the Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA). The Government believes there is a need for visible checks and balances to be put in place to ensure that there is no perceived misuse of the FAC's monopoly position. The Minister will retain the formal power to disallow charges and be given the power to set replacement charges.

The provisions are intended to enhance the effectiveness of the Minister's present power to approve or disapprove charges, by providing the Minister with the opportunity to consider any report of the PSA before making a decision and by enabling the Minister to set charges to replace those which are unacceptable.

In line with the philosophy of moving from oversight of day-to-day operations to an emphasis on results and Board accountability, the Bill removes a range of day-to-day controls exercised by Government, including controls over the terms and conditions of individual borrowings, the approval of individual contracts, the purchase of shares and the establishment of subsidiaries and partnerships. These are now appropriately the responsibility of the Board.

The Bill provides greater recognition for the role and purposes of the Board, and greater emphasis on Board accountability for the performance of the Corporation. It also provides for an increase in Board size from 7 to 9 members.

Other provisions in the Bill relating to appointment and dismissal of Board members, conduct of Board meetings and the appointment and powers of the Chief Executive Officer reflect more clearly the respective roles of the Minister and the Board and clarify issues of administration of the Corporation.
The Government is fully satisfied that appropriate scrutiny of expenditure by the FAC will be maintained through the strategic oversight process.

Although the FAC currently pays a range of Commonwealth and State taxes and duties, it is exempt from payment of Commonwealth sales tax and Commonwealth income tax. This Bill removes that exemption and provides for the FAC to be fully subject to Commonwealth sales tax with effect from 1 July 1990 and Commonwealth income tax with effect from 1 July 1991.

The Bill has no immediate financial implications for the Commonwealth, although, over time, the reforms of the Federal Airports Corporation included in the Bill are expected to enhance the efficiency of the Corporation and improve its returns to the Commonwealth.

The imposition of income tax on the Corporation for the 1991-92 financial year is expected to result in increased revenue to the Commonwealth. The amounts cannot be accurately quantified at this time, as they depend on a number of factors including the profitability of the Corporation, the extent of tax deductions obtained and the tax rates prevailing in the 1991-92 financial year.

Liability for payment of Commonwealth sales tax, with effect from the beginning of the 1990-91 financial year, will result in increased revenue to the Commonwealth. The amounts will depend on actual purchases by the Corporation and cannot be accurately quantified at this time.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum for the Bill.
CIVIL AVIATION AMENDMENT BILL 1990

A central plank in the Government's micro-economic reform agenda for restructuring the public sector is that Government Business Enterprises (GBEs) should be as efficient as possible and responsive to consumers' needs.

The GBEs within the Transport and Communications portfolio, in addition to producing final goods and services for consumers, also produce intermediate inputs for the rest of the economy, with a resulting impact on Australia's overall cost structures and the ability of Australian businesses to compete internationally.

The Government sees the commercialisation of GBEs as a necessary and fundamental pre-condition to improvements in efficiency. GBEs such as the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) and Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) are therefore being placed on a more commercial footing, bringing them more into line with the disciplines traditionally associated with private sector enterprises.
This Bill, together with the Federal Airports Corporation Amendment Bill 1990, represents the legislative changes necessary to finalise the Government's reform of its aviation industry enterprises.

The reform package accords broadly with reform packages for other enterprises in the Transport and Communications portfolio which were announced in the ministerial statement of 25 May 1988 ``Reshaping the Transport and Communications Government Business Enterprises''.

However, as a relatively recent piece of legislation, the Civil Aviation Act 1988 already incorporates a number of measures which accord closely with changes made to other public authorities through the GBE reform process. For example, the Act establishes corporate planning and financial targets as the basis for Government oversight of the CAA.

To some extent, therefore, the Bill represents fine-tuning of the existing strategic controls over the Authority to bring them more closely into line with other reform packages agreed by the Government. It also removes a range of detailed controls which the Government still exercises over the activities of the Authority.

In addition to presenting the package of reforms for the CAA, the Bill also includes provisions relating to the carriage of dangerous goods, clarification of the provisions relating to statutory liens on aircraft and protection from State laws where the CAA performs a function directly related to the regulation of air safety. The Bill also implements two amendments arising from recommendations of the first report of the Air Safety Regulation Review Task Force.
I now turn to specific provisions contained in the Bill.

A key element in establishing an environment within the CAA which will encourage greater responsiveness and efficiency is the proposal to remove Public Service Act coverage of its employees, thereby making the CAA Board the direct employer and allowing a more flexible and business-like approach to the management of the Authority. Transitional arrangements contained in the Bill provide that existing staff will continue to be employed, initially, on the same terms and conditions. Mobility provisions of the Public Service Act will continue to apply.

Another major change provided for in the Bill is the scrutiny of proposed statutory charges levied by the CAA under the Act by the Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA). The Government believes there is a need for visible checks and balances to be put in place to ensure that there is no perceived misuse of the CAA's monopoly position. The Minister will retain the formal power to disallow charges and be given the power to set replacement charges.

The provisions are intended to enhance the effectiveness of the Minister's present power to approve or disapprove charges, by providing the Minister with the opportunity to consider any report of the PSA before making his decision and by enabling the Minister to set charges to replace those which are unacceptable.

In line with the philosophy of moving from oversight of day-to-day operations to an emphasis on results and Board accountability, the Bill removes a range of day-to-day controls exercised by Government, including controls over the terms and conditions of individual borrowings, the approval of individual contracts, the purchase of shares and the establishment of subsidiaries and partnerships. These are now appropriately the responsibility of the Board.

Other provisions in the Bill relating to appointment and dismissal of Board members, conduct of Board meetings and the appointment and powers of the Chief Executive Officer reflect more clearly the respective roles of the Minister and the Board and clarify issues of administration of the Authority.

Although the CAA currently pays a range of Commonwealth and State taxes and duties, it is exempt from payment of Commonwealth income tax. This Bill removes that exemption and provides for the CAA to be fully subject to Commonwealth income tax with effect from 1 July 1991.

As I indicated earlier, other provisions in the Bill, unrelated to the reform measures outlined above, include measures to implement, as far as practicable, the recommendations of the Air Safety Regulation Review Task Force's first report that the cost to industry of proposed standards of aviation safety should be taken into account by the Authority, and that significant offences in the regulations relating to crucial areas of air safety should be included in the Act.

The Bill also strengthens the role of the Authority in specifying conditions for the carriage or consignment of dangerous goods and provides for the establishment of dangerous goods training programs for air operators and freight forwarders.

The Act currently requires the Authority to grant individual permissions to carry or consign dangerous goods and to specify conditions in respect of each such permission. The section does not enable the Authority to grant general permissions. The amendments will empower the Authority to grant general permissions, in addition to the specific permissions currently provided for. Such permissions would be specified in Civil Aviation Orders or the Civil Aviation Regulations and would be subject to such conditions as the Authority specifies in the Orders or Regulations, as the case may be, in relation to the particular permission.

In order to ensure the effective screening of dangerous goods the Act will be amended to provide that an air operator must not carry air cargo and a freight forwarder must not accept any air cargo unless it is accompanied by a declaration of the contents of the cargo.

Provisions in the Act relating to statutory liens on aircraft have been amended to rectify a deficiency in the definition of that term, and to extend the existing protection offered to the Authority and its officers to cover actions brought for recompense of economic loss suffered as a result of seizure of aircraft under the statutory liens provisions. The Act already provides that when an aircraft has been seized under a statutory lien then neither the Authority nor its officers may be sued for loss of, or damage to, the aircraft.

The Bill also provides that a state law will not apply to the Authority or its property where it is necessary for the Authority to perform functions directly related to the purpose of regulating air safety. The particular functions are the provision of air route and airway facilities, air traffic control and flight services on aerodromes, rescue and fire fighting services and search and rescue services.

It is intended that this particular provision will only be used where the matter is essential to the performance of the Authority and negotiations with a State or local government authority have been unable to result in resolutions.
On the recommendation of the Attorney-General's Department, the Bill amends existing pecuniary penalty provisions to bring the Act into line with recent amendments to the Crimes Act 1914.

The Bill has no immediate financial implications for the Commonwealth, although, over time, the reforms of the Civil Aviation Authority included in the Bill are expected to enhance the efficiency of the Authority and improve its returns to the Commonwealth.

The imposition of income tax on the Authority for 1991/92 and subsequent financial years is expected to result in increased revenue to the Commonwealth. The amounts cannot be accurately quantified at this time, as they depend on a number of factors including the profitability of the Authority, the extent of tax deductions obtained and the prevailing tax rates.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum for the Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXPORT MARKET DEVELOPMENT GRANTS AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Robert Ray, at the request of Senator Button) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to amend the Export Market Development Grants Act 1974.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill amends the Export Market Development Grants Act 1974 to preserve its continuity from 1 July 1990-the Act is otherwise scheduled to terminate on 30 June 1990.

In light of the 30 June 1990 expiry date for the Export Market Development Grants Scheme, I, as honourable senators will recall, appointed a Committee for the Review of Export Market Development Assistance in December 1988. This Committee, chaired by Professor Helen Hughes of the Australian National University, was charged with examining Government measures providing financial assistance for exporters under the Export Market Development Grants Act and schemes established under the Australian Trade Commission Act. The Hughes Committee presented its report to me in July 1989.

Honourable senators will also recall that on 28 February this year the Prime Minister and I jointly released the Government's decision on the Hughes Committee report. The Government accepted the majority of the Committee's recommendations.

In our announcement, the Prime Minister and I foreshadowed that amendments to the EMDG Act arising out of the Government's adoption of the Hughes Committee's recommendations would operate from 1 July 1990.

Whilst this is still to be the case, the recent election and the need to consult widely with interested bodies and persons about the precise nature of the new provisions required in a revised EMDG Act to give effect to the Government's decision, and the regulations which will underpin many of the extended services which will now become eligible under the EMDGs, precluded the required substantive amendments to the EMDG Act being brought forward in this Parliamentary Sittings. The Government wishes to ensure that all possible views are taken into account so that the best possible framework, within the limits of the Government's decision, is implemented in respect of the revised EMDG Scheme.
Accordingly, I have brought this Bill forward at this time to preserve the continuity of the EMDG Act so that no exporters will be disadvantaged by the Act lapsing through the effluxion of time.
It is intended to bring an EMDG Amendment Act implementing the Government's announced changes to the EMDGs forward in this year's Budget Sittings, effective from 1 July 1990.
No financial impact is expected to arise from the current amendments.
This Bill was a previous Bill so the second reading is already on the record.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table two reports from the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, I present the report entitled The Development of the Senior Executive Service: Performance Based Pay, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move that the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

This report is the first under a general inquiry into the development of the Senior Executive Service (SES) begun by the Committee in June last year. It was largely completed in February. However, the cancellation of the two sitting weeks scheduled for February prevented tabling before the election. The Committee completed its considerations of the report on 18 April 1990 and resolved that the report be printed and tabled.

The report covers the single issue of performance pay. The introduction of performance pay is currently under consideration by the Government and the Industrial Relations Commission and the Committee chose to make a special report on this matter so that our concerns could be given some weight when the decision is made.

Although the Committee collected evidence on a wide range of other issues relating to the SES, it will take some time to consider and report on that evidence. I hope and expect that the Committee appointed in this Parliament will complete the inquiry with a further and more wide-ranging report in the Budget session.
Committee concerns

The report makes it clear that the Committee has serious concerns about the rationale for the introduction of performance based pay for the SES, the proposed arrangements for its introduction and the uncertainty which appears to exist about some structural and procedural aspects.
Mr President, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the remainder of my tabling statement, and I seek leave also to continue my remarks at a later time.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The main theoretical justification for linking the pay system to performance is to provide an incentive for improved performance [para 18]. However, most of the official witnesses were vague on the exact nature of the anticipated benefits [para 34]. There is very strong evidence, especially in relation to experiments with performance based pay overseas, which suggest that costs as well as benefits can flow from linking pay and performance.

The possible costs include the demotivating effect on staff not rated as eligible for performance based pay, antagonism between groups participating in the new pay system and those which do not and adverse effects on group cohesion and cooperation. There may also be a disproportionate focus on the reward system to the detriment of organisational goals. It can be difficult to separate individual performance from group performance and, in many parts of the Public Service, it may be difficult to define performance at all [para 32].

The Committee was sufficiently concerned by all this to recommend that performance based pay not be introduced until a formal study of the costs and benefits is undertaken and it is established that significant net benefits are likely [para 40].

Some witnesses suggested that the performance based pay proposal involved an attempt to evade the wage guidelines [para 18]. It was also suggested that the new system would become market rather than merit related [para 35]. The Committee concluded that, if there is a case for market parity in SES remuneration, it should be argued openly, allowing full consideration of relevant issues [para 35].

The Committee stressed that, if loss of better performers among senior staff is the main problem, there are other options for dealing with it [para 36]. In particular, it should be possible to expedite measures already planned to improve the conditions of professionals like lawyers, accountants and engineers.
Implementation

It is clear from the overseas experience of performance based pay that success depends on careful implementation [para 42]. The Committee has made recommendations aimed at avoiding significant potential problems if the proposal for performance pay does proceed.

We have recommended that, if performance based pay is introduced, coordination arrangements be improved in specific ways. We also recommended that implementation be phased in, with no agency being allowed to introduce performance based pay until it has operated a staff appraisal system for at least one year and that system has been independently certified to be effective. We recommended that the certification procedure include surveys that establish staff acceptance of the fairness, validity and reliability of the appraisal system and that the full results of the evaluation of the appraisal process be made public.

Another recommendation is that, if performance pay is introduced, it be extended to the groups immediately below the SES at the same time as it is available to SES officers. We considered this desirable both for pragmatic and ethical reasons.

At the time the Committee took evidence, no final decision had been made on whether details of performance payments to individuals should be public knowledge. We heard arguments both ways and the relevant academic literature is also divided on this issue.

The Committee concluded that the case for openness in public administration outweighed any possible increase in efficiency available from privacy on salary matters. Relevant to this conclusion was a belief that these efficiency gains would be, at best, problematic due to the difficulty of measuring public sector performance and the consequent ease with which the system could be manipulated. Public knowledge of levels of performance based payments might actually increase efficiency by forcing a higher general standard of honesty on those operating the system [para 66].

The Committee also recommended that performance based payments should be made largely or wholly in the form of bonus payments rather than as a supplement to regular salary payments. This was seen as enhancing the `at risk' element in the pay system which is generally seen as central to its motivational effects.

The Committee recommended measures to ensure reasonable consistency in performance pay policies across the Public Service. We also drew attention to the need, already acknowledged by the Government, for adequate funding of any performance pay system that might be introduced.
Flow on effects
Committee consideration of this matter largely occurred in the first two months of the year. Developments since then, which are not reflected in the report, deserve a brief personal comment.

The proposal to substantially improve SES remuneration in this way has significant implications for the groups immediately above and below the SES. The so-called feeder groups-Administrative Service Officers Class 7 and 8 and their professional equivalents-have begun industrial action based, in part, on perceptions of a large and increasing gap between their conditions and those of the SES. Department heads have also argued for a substantial wage rise partly on comparability grounds.

If the performance pay proposal was structured to avoid the problem of comparative wage justice, it appears to have been unsuccessful. It is also clear that performance based pay will not be a solution to any problems that might exist in regard to inadequate levels of pay.
Conclusion

In its report, the Committee expressed some sympathy with the professed intention of the performance pay proposal but also offered strong reservations about its practicality. Some members, myself among them, concluded that the proposal was inappropriate and fatally flawed.

It would be a fair reading of the report to conclude that the Committee was not impressed with the level of policy development shown in this case. The performance pay proposal has not even been considered by the Public Service Management Advisory Board, although that body has a statutory responsibility to `advise the Government on significant issues relating to the management of the public service . . . . . and to be a forum for consideration of management activities affecting the Australian Public Service as a whole'. Such policy development as has occurred has been divided among three separate coordinating agencies and the Committee was not convinced that there has been adequate coordination of their activities [para 43].
I hope that this report will both influence and improve the policy debate on executive remuneration in the public sector. There is certainly scope for a better debate than has so far occurred.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, the second report that I have leave to table is a report on behalf of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration entitled Departmental Annual Reports 1988-89.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
This report is a survey of the annual reports of departments for 1988-89. It documents a considerable improvement in the timeliness and quality of these reports.
I seek leave to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

This report follows a report on the timeliness and quality of annual reports presented by the Committee during the winter recess last year. The report I now table was largely completed in February. However, the cancellation of the two sitting weeks scheduled for February prevented tabling before the election. The Committee completed its consideration of the report on 18 April 1990 and resolved that the report be printed and tabled.

In its June 1989 report, the Committee concluded that there had been a steady improvement in annual reporting, that the current standard was relatively high but that there was room for improvement. The Committee made recommendations aimed at improving various aspects of timeliness and quality of annual reports.

The 1989 report attracted considerable interest in the Public Service and it seemed to the Committee that there was a marked improvement in timeliness of tabling of the 1988-89 annual reports. We decided to examine this issue in a short follow-up to the earlier report.

This report aims to be an overall comparative survey without going into the substance of the contents of reports. Each of the Senate Legislative and General Purpose Committees will separately report on the substance of annual reports of agencies within the portfolios they review. The report covers the eighteen executive and five parliamentary departments.
In summary, the Committee was pleased to report that it was correct in its initial impression of a general improvement in reporting.

There was a very marked improvement, for example, in timeliness for the 1988-89 reports. All but two of the 23 reports reviewed were tabled by the end of November 1989. Eight of the 1987-88 reports, by comparison, were tabled after November 1988.
There were also pleasing improvements in the numbers of departments which included indexes and other aids to users in their reports.

The Committee noted that the length of all annual reports but one had increased, as had the amount of material appended to reports. This was largely the result of a new requirement for departmental annual reports to include detailed audited accounts.

The Committee recognised that annual reports in the Australian Government sector are far larger and more complex than the reports of public companies or those of most State Government instrumentalities. This is not necessarily a bad thing. There is growing pressure for reform of this aspect of private sector performance and there are inevitable differences in public and private sector accountability systems.

The new requirement to include audited accounts of departments in annual reports proved superior to the former practice of tabling of a single consolidated audit report. However, the accounts of nine departments were qualified in some respects, although five of the audit qualifications were minor. The Committee felt strongly that this number was too high. It notes that a similar number of qualifications were made to the departmental accounts in the previous year.

Another new requirement for 1988-89 was for reporting on measures taken to enhance social justice. It was apparent to the Committee that some departments took this requirement more seriously than did others. The Committee found that the departments of Community Services and Health and of Social Security were particularly effective in their reporting on social justice. Many other departments limited their reporting to brief comments on their access and equity plans.

Similarly, the reporting on statutory and non-statutory bodies in departmental annual reports was mixed. The report of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, which coordinates the annual reporting guidelines, provides a good model for reporting under this heading. However, many other departments failed to report fully, or sometimes at all, on bodies within their portfolio.

With the few reservations outlined above, the Committee welcomed a significant improvement in the general quality of the majority of departmental annual reports. Perhaps the most important cautionary note is that the trend to longer and more complex reports may cause difficulty if it continues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek your guidance on this matter. The Standing Orders are the rules by which the Senate operates-they are rules which we can change any time we want to-and the rules of the Senate say that only formal business should be entered into before the Address-in-Reply to the Governor-General's opening speech has been adopted.

—Senator Ray moved 10 notices of motion earlier today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I had intended to seek leave to move a motion to refer this paper on electronic voting to the Procedure Committee, but I understand that that leave in fact will not be granted.
—I think you can move the motion to refer it to a committee without leave.
—In that case I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the document be referred to the Procedure Committee for examination.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether Senator Macklin was intending to say anything further on this particular matter, but I want to indicate that the Opposition is not in favour of referring this paper on electronic voting to the Procedure Committee until such time as Opposition senators have actually had an opportunity to read and study the paper.

SPEECH.PARA: I appreciate that Senator Macklin is motivated by the fact that the Procedure Committee would take the paper, study it and eventually come back to the chamber with certain recommendations, but there are very considerable matters to be raised and a number of honourable senators would want to participate in the debate prior to the Procedure Committee considering this particular matter, and put certain views on the record in terms of what might be called a going-in position on this question of electronic voting.

The paper which, Mr President, you have presented and which was circulated to us quite recently, is very detailed. It runs to some 16 pages and has a large number of attachments dealing with the question of electronic voting in a number of overseas parliaments. Because this is a matter which deals with the operation and the conduct of the chamber per se, it would not normally be a matter which would be decided on a party room level; in other words, those senators, like myself, who are inherently opposed to the system of electronic voting would not be in any sense corralled into dealing with this matter.

I also take the opportunity to put on record certain views about this, against the possibility that if the matter does go to the Procedure Committee and the Procedure Committee reports at some later stage, I might not have the opportunity to make those views known at the time that the Procedure Committee reports.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be a very quick report.

—Senator Hamer says that it would be a very quick report, but given the celerity with which the Procedure Committee has tended to deal with these matters, I am not persuaded even by the comments of my distinguished colleague. The matters canvassed in this report are not simply restricted to the question of electronic voting. For example, they deal with the question of recording of votes without division. We have in the past somewhat made use of this procedure.

SPEECH.PARA: I well recall on the last occasion that I was dealing with a piece of legislation-it was the electoral legislation that Senator Robert Ray, Senator Macklin and I were handling last year-and we came to the third reading of that Bill. Because we had crept a minute or two past 12.45, I simply rose in my place to indicate that we would not divide the Senate on the third reading but that I wished to record that all members of the Liberal and National parties would have voted against the third reading of the Bill if a division had been called.

It was only to suit the convenience of the chamber that the division was not called. Nevertheless, it simply appears in the Hansard that I rose and said that all members would vote against the Bill if a division were called, but there is no division list. As a result we are not sure, for example, where Senator Harradine, Senator Dunn or Senator Vallentine might have stood on that particular matter because a division was not called.

There is a suggestion on pages 15 and 16 of the President's report which deals with the question of whether the party leaders should be authorised to make a statement and, having made a statement, that names should in fact be printed in the Hansard and in the Journals of the Senate so as to allow people to record their views in a more formal fashion. We have a comment again on page 15 that the question of cost may or may not be germane to our consideration. A figure of $80,000 is mentioned.

Frankly, given the squeeze which there is on the Senate's budget, one of the additional things that the Opposition welcomes in Senator Walsh's translation to the back bench is that there may just be a Minister for Finance who takes a view that the Senate should be more adequately funded to undertake its activities. This is, I suppose, likely to be a vain hope, but I am in the process at the moment of keeping vain hopes alive, at least for the next couple of days.

TALK.START.PARA: —We shall have to have a recount as well.
—I am told by the Electoral Commission that even if the result comes down to 10 votes, it will deny me a recount, one way or the other; so we will see.

SPEECH.PARA: If, however, the Senate budget is to be continually constricted, there will be a real question to be asked as to whether $80,000-and $80,000 in this building tends to become somewhat more than $80,000-is in fact the correct allocation of Senate scarce resources in order to establish a system of electronic voting in order to save what the paper calculates may be a matter of only a few hours over the course of a whole parliamentary year.

The other matters which the President's paper raises include the question of guarantees that only the person who is supposed to vote, votes. Then there is the question as to whether people can change votes as they watch the little lights go up, or whether they would have to lock in their votes and then the lights would all go on together-which would be great fun. We have had quite interesting examples where people have missed votes. They have come in and said, `Somebody else stole the lift and we were not able to get in it, and therefore we were excluded'. Now we are going to have the problem of people saying, `Well, I didn't have my glasses with me and I pressed the wrong button'.That may or may not be the case. A quite legitimate comment is made on page 3 of the paper about the capacity to adjust pairs quickly. More than that: unless the voting has to take place at the senators' desks, the actual process of the public act of voting, as it is described, is one which needs to be taken into particular consideration.

So if the question is that the bells are to be rung for the appropriate period, that all senators are to come in to their places, that sitting in their place they will press the appropriate button or insert the appropriate card-if they remember to bring the card with them and they do not have the card in the desk and if somebody has not knocked off the card, and if they have not tried to put it into an automatic teller machine by which it has been seized and not yet returned to them-all of these matters need to be looked at.

If, however, the voting is to take place by people coming in, sitting in their place and pressing the appropriate button, some time would be saved in looking around the chamber and the Whips actually writing down the numbers. From time to time-although nobody would normally admit it-there are people actually present in the chamber who should not be present in the chamber because some Whips' arrangement has been made and the Whips develop a selective myopia and names do not appear, names which were supposed not to appear because there was a pairing arrangement. Those sorts of things, which actually make the system work in a more effective fashion, could be comprised by this proposal.

The paper is very useful in making the point that the claims often made that there are in the House of Commons and elsewhere far more regular procedures, under which everybody knows when a vote is to be taken and when those members of parliament in the United Kingdom who are under the Whip and who pay particular attention as to whether it is a one-line whip or a three-line whip actually bother to turn up for the vote, are based somewhat on a misconception. The President's paper is very useful in dealing with that matter.

It seems to me that a legitimate complaint is often voiced by colleagues on my side and, indeed, by members of the Labor Party, that from time to time when a vote is called for, only the Democrats and some independent senators sit on one side of the chamber, while all other senators sit on the other side of the chamber. It may well be that if Senator Macklin were really devoted to the principle of saving time, he would call for fewer divisions when he knows that the Democrats will be the only ones voting on one side. If the Democrats were to do this, they would not be able to go out into the electorate and say, `Look, the two major parties always vote with each other. We are the only purists who make sure that all of these divisions take place'. If one were to analyse the amount of time which is taken up by the Democrats calling for divisions, as distinct from the major parties calling for divisions, one may be provided with an interesting set of new statistics.

The disadvantages of electronic voting are well set out on page 11 of the document. The proposition that electronic voting would cause more divisions to be called seems to me to be a potential nightmare for all of those who are considering the question of the saving of time. I believe that in due course this matter, the Senate having formally requested a report on it from you, Mr President, will have to be considered by the Senate. It is probably correct that the Procedure Committee or some similar committee should be asked to study your paper, Mr President, eventually make a response, and then bring forward any proposals for changes, including any proposals for changes to the Standing Orders. If that were to be the case, I hope that members of the Government would be left in the same position as members of the Opposition parties-that is, they should be able to exercise their vote entirely on the basis of their own beliefs and conscience, and the matter should not be perceived to be a matter for Caucus.

The proposal to refer the matter to the Procedure Committee at this stage is not supported by the Opposition. We believe that the political parties and the independent senators should have more time to consider this matter. It may well be that, having considered it, they will want to make a decision on it at that time, rather than send the report to the Procedure Committee, bearing in mind particularly that the President's paper is a detailed and comprehensive one-one which I cannot imagine would be substantially altered or improved by referring it to the Procedure Committee. We would be more inclined to support the option of making the President's report an order of the day so that we can decide whether the Senate is in favour, in principle, of the introduction of a system of electronic voting. If it is so in favour, the Senate may refer to the Procedure Committee, the Standing Orders Committee or some other appropriate committee the mechanism by which the President's report should be adopted and put in place.

We are not in favour of referring this matter to the Procedure Committee at this stage. We would be happy to have discussions with Senator Macklin and with the Government over the further handling of this matter. If I were to seek leave to continue my remarks, perhaps that would mean that the matter would be automatically stood over. Perhaps, given my remarks, Senator Macklin may be inclined at least to accept some temporary halt to the resolution of this matter. From my understanding of the Standing Orders, I think I will seek leave--

TALK.START.PARA: —Won't it be Business of the Senate that will come back to haunt me every day?
—It will go onto the Notice Paper, but if you seek leave now there will be no further debate on it.

—I am seeking your guidance, Mr President, as to whether that is the correct motion or whether I should move that it become an order of the day for the first day of the Budget sittings. I seek leave to move that this motion becomes an order for the day for the first sitting day in August.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the debate be adjourned till the first sitting day in August 1990.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Devereux Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following Address-in-Reply be agreed to:
To His Excellency the Governor-General,

May it please Your Excellency-We, the Senate of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled, desire to express our loyalty to our Most Gracious Sovereign and to thank Your Excellency for the speech which you have been pleased to address to Parliament.

At the outset I welcome the three new senators who were sworn in yesterday. I understand that another one will be sworn in today. I think it is pertinent, particularly from my point of view, to make an observation in respect of Senator Bell from Tasmania-it is a rather healthy sign which I hope is a permanent one-that when the nomination of Senator Bell was put to the Tasmanian Parliament by the Australian Democrats and was considered by that Parliament it was the unanimous decision of the Parliament to appoint Senator Bell to that vacant position. It is proper to remind the Senate that most of the 26 people who voted three years ago not to fill the vacancy created by the resignation of former Senator Don Grimes are still in the Tasmanian Parliament and attended the joint sitting which agreed to the nomination of Senator Bell. I hope that that is a sign that the decisions of political expediency which mean that the wishes of a party which is seeking to replace a senator who has resigned are not carried out will no longer occur in the future and that all parliaments will act in an appropriate manner, as has been the case with the present replacements.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have to consider the calibre of the two people.

—That would mean that Senator Walters would never get here. I understand that some senators will make their maiden speeches today, so it is not my intention to go into all the areas covered in the Governor-General's Speech in great detail. I will confine my remarks to one area that will be of great concern during the term of this Government. I refer to a topic that is very widely discussed publicly-that is, the need for much more efficient industry in Australia. I totally agree that that is what we need.

SPEECH.PARA: It needs to be recognised that an enormous contribution has been made to changes in industry structure and the efficiency of industry by the trade union movement. It has been prepared to enter into an accord with this Government, the purpose being to streamline awards. At the moment we are going through a process of award restructuring. At the end of that period, hopefully, there will be much greater opportunities for workers to achieve far greater skills and far greater job satisfaction. As a consequence, industry will become far more efficient, and everyone in this country will benefit from that.

The matter I really want to address-and it is something that the Opposition should take on board over the period of this Government and into the future-is that the Opposition and many employers, although I do not say all employers, should look at the approach that the trade union movement has taken and adopt a far more cooperative approach, and look at a whole range of efficiencies that industry can carry out.

There is no way that we will get the sort of industry that we need in this country simply by legislating for voluntary agreements or legislating to give people the power to abolish penalty rates and all those sorts of things. That is not going to get us to a position where employers and employees in this country understand and accept the need to have greater efficiency in industry and greater excellence in the products being produced. That can be done only by a change in the whole culture of this country so that everybody understands that that sort of efficiency benefits all of us.

The problem we have is that the culture of both the Opposition and employers leads them to believe that the only way to improve efficiency in industry in this country is to be continually looking at cutting the wages of employees and putting people off if one is running into difficulties. They never really use the skills and knowledge of those people to increase the efficiency and prosperity of the company's operations.

To emphasise that point, I refer to an article that appeared in the Weekend Australian of 7-8 April. A survey was carried out by the Australian Chamber of Manufactures and the State Bank of New South Wales into manufacturing conditions and future prospects in New South Wales.
