It is interesting to note that that survey asked people what sort of action they would take if their businesses were deteriorating. The survey asked a whole range of questions and compared directly the attitudes of Australian businesses with similar businesses in Japan and the United States.

I do not want to go through all the questions asked; I simply refer to two sets of figures. One question asked employers what they would do if their businesses were running into economic problems. In Australia, the answer given by 34 per cent of firms was that they would immediately reduce their labour costs and employee numbers. The same answer was given in Japan by 12 per cent of firms and in the United States by 19 per cent. When firms in Australia were asked whether they would reduce other costs, only 20 per cent said that they would compared to the 43 per cent in Japan who said that that would be a priority and 40 per cent in the United States.

That, in itself, emphasises one of the real problems that we have right throughout the business community in Australia and, of course, on the other side of the chamber. Those people see reduced costs and increased efficiencies as being related only to labour costs.

I mentioned one area where industry in this country could substantially reduce its costs, and there could be great benefit to the environment. There should be a reduction of energy use by companies right across the country. I cite some figures that I have been given concerning a company in Victoria, Enersonics Pty Ltd, involved in energy audits and advising all sorts of companies across the country on what sort of savings can be made. A reduction in energy in the electrical area of a medium sized research complex in the western suburbs of Melbourne was demonstrated in a very short space of time to be 45 per cent. In a small office and shopping arcade, a 35 per cent reduction in the use of electricity and a 50 per cent reduction in the use of gas or oil was achieved. In a six-storey office block, a 35 per cent reduction was achieved in the use of electricity and a 60 per cent reduction in the use of gas or oil. In a four-storey office block, a 40 per cent reduction was achieved in the use of electricity and a 50 per cent reduction in the use of oil. All these figures can be verified.

I give some actual dollar amounts. In 1988 an audit was undertaken at a manufacturing plant whose annual energy costs were $1,750,000. The annual savings as a result of this audit totalled $416,000. A research laboratory whose energy costs were $490,963 saved $180,000 in energy. A brass forging plant with energy costs of $1,179,000 achieved savings of $556,000. A steel forging plant with energy costs of $1,143,000 achieved savings of $662,000. The list goes on. Those figures indicate the real question confronting industry in Australia. We do have to look at a whole range of efficiencies if we are really going to become leaders in industry, particularly manufacturing areas.

In my home State the actual power bill per year for Comalco Ltd is $36m, which is an extraordinary figure. However, the bulk of that bill is an amount for a bulk power purchase. Regardless of whether Comalco introduced efficiencies to cut down the use of power, the company would still have to pay the same amount of money. In my view, that sort of arrangement continuing into the future in this country is just crazy economics.

At face value, it seems to me that if those bulk contracts were not there and Comalco did not have the payment of a certain amount of money forced upon it-that is, it still pays the same money even if it does not use the power-substantial savings could be made. A company like Comalco could look at pre-heating its plant with natural gas for instance, which I would think would save extraordinary amounts of money.

I certainly hope that over the period of this Government those questions will be very seriously addressed by both sides of this Parliament, by industry, and by people generally. Enormous savings are to be made by both large and small enterprises. If we do not address these questions, we will continue wallowing around in this argument and the cross-fire between the Opposition and the Government, with the Opposition saying the only way efficiencies can be achieved in industry is to cut back wage costs and continually look at ways of getting people out of the work force, when in fact the most valuable asset we have are those people in the work force who have a great deal to contribute in all sorts of ways, not only in energy efficiencies but in other efficiencies. The real skills that those people have to contribute to industry, to the management of industry and to where industry is going have been neglected for many years. I think that we could all contribute greatly to the industry of this country if we took that matter on board, and proceeded in that way into the future.

In closing, I congratulate the Australian Labor Party and the Goss Government in Queensland. I have read in the newspapers and have been advised that the Queensland Government has just announced a decision to pay superannuation owing to some one thousand South East Queensland Electricity Board workers who were sacked by the National Party Government seven years ago.

I believe it is an absolute disgrace that for seven years workers who, by a decision of the Queensland Industrial Commission, were entitled and ready to go back to work, were prevented from doing so and were sacked by the Queensland Government. Not only did the Queensland Government do that but it denied them their rights. I understand the total amount owing to those people was somewhere in the vicinity of $10m. I want to place on record my congratulations to the Queensland Government for its courageous decision. I thank the Senate for the opportunity to move the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise with great pleasure to second the motion moved by my colleague Senator Devereux.
—Why do you not have a tie on today like you had yesterday?
—I just thought I would give it a try to see whether Senator Crichton-Browne was observant enough to notice the difference.
—It has certainly lifted your elegance.
—I thank the honourable senator for the comment; I have to confess I occasionally wear ties, and yesterday was one of those occasions.
—You always wear them when the television cameras are there.

—No, I have done interviews without ties when there have been television cameras present, and I get comments accordingly. I do not think people should make a great fuss about wearing ties or not wearing ties. It is a matter of individual choice. I notice that 17 members of the Senate never wear ties at all, and one of them, Senator Walters, is sitting next to Senator Crichton-Browne. Women members of the Senate never wear ties.
—You do not wear a dress and I don't comment on that.
—Order! Let us return to the Address-in-Reply.

—Let me get on to the Address-in-Reply and to the important matters contained in it. We have been asked by the Whips to speak for less than our allotted time, and I certainly wish to cooperate with that so I hope I will be no more than, say, 15 minutes. There are a number of matters I wish to speak about which arise as a result of the Governor-General's Speech yesterday. First of all, the Governor-General gave such an excellent speech because of the return of the Australian Labor Party Government for its fourth historic term. The Speech outlined the Labor Government's program for the next four years. Already a number of people have commented that there will be a very busy program over the next three years to deal with the matters contained in the Governor-General's Speech. I think that reflects the commitment that is in the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the Parliamentary Labor Party's return to Canberra in informal discussions it is very pleasing to note that throughout the Parliamentary Labor Party, and not just in the Cabinet, there has been a real commitment to get on with major reform. We are not going to waste the opportunities that we have in our fourth term to carry out those reforms, whether they are in the major economic area or in the so-called micro-economic reform area.

I want to make a couple of comments about the result. The other day in Adelaide at the Senate declaration of the poll I noticed that, unfortunately for the Australian Labor Party, we won only two out of the six Senate positions. The Liberal Party of Australia, quite rightly, was pleased that it had won three out of six. It was also pleased that in my own State it won the seat of Hawker from the Labor Party, but we evened that up by winning back the federal seat of Adelaide. Despite the pleasure the Opposition has had of a reasonable result in the Senate, winning seats like Hawker and having had a very good result in Victoria, when it comes to the bottom line the Labor Party still forms the Government of Australia. In politics there are no second prizes.

We on our side of politics have unfortunately suffered losing elections on many occasions in the past. Certainly in my younger days, in the 1950s and 1960s, as a young supporter of the Labor Party, the never-ending success of the coalition in winning elections was quite disillusioning. I never thought that in my lifetime I would see a Federal Labor government elected four times in a row and have a chance to govern uninterrupted for a decade. The fact that the Party has been able to win four in a row reflects well on it. Some people have commented that this was an election the Labor Party stole, that it was a lay-down misere for the Opposition to win. I suspect that is partly right. I make no bones about the fact that I thought a Party which went to the electorate when interest rates were around 17 per cent would be in a very hard position to win re-election.

I think the reason we won is that though a majority of the people in the electorate may have been willing to vote us out, a bigger majority was not willing to vote the Opposition in. That came down to the fundamental position that the credibility problems of the Opposition could not be overcome in its presentation, and that is why it lost the election.

I see today in the press, published for the first time, that the accurate two-party preferred vote is supposed to be 49.8 or 49.9 per cent for the Labor Party and 50.1 or 50.2 for the coalition. I presume that has been done by an accurate two-party preferred vote count-out in every one of the 148 electorates around Australia and that it takes into account a proper two-party preferred vote-Labor-coalition-in each of the seats, even in seats such as North Sydney where an independent won and Mr Mack's preferences should be counted between Labor and Liberal. Either way I concede the fact that it is overwhelmingly likely that the Labor Party did not get the majority of the vote. It is a reflection of the single-member constituency system that it is possible mathematically for that to occur and that if effective campaigning takes place in the right electorates a government can be returned. It is in no way a gerrymander, and I hope honourable senators opposite do not start shouting about a gerrymander. There is not malapportionment. The boundaries are drawn on a one vote, one value basis with a 10 per cent discrepancy. It reflects the fact that the Labor Party is better at winning and holding marginal seats than the Opposition. We have proved our ability to out-campaign the coalition in the critical seats. I think that has to be recognised by the Opposition.

In relation to matters in the Speech in which I have a particular interest, I want to refer to the section dealing with communications and transport. The Government has outlined, amongst other things, two major areas of reform and change, one dealing with telecommunications and Telecom Australia and the other dealing with rail transport. I fully support the idea that we must upgrade our rail systems if we are to have a more efficient land transport system in Australia but I warn that I do not believe the Federal Government should be required to provide massive amounts of funds to do so while there are six different managements and six different ownerships around Australia.

There are too many examples of the State rail systems not being managed efficiently on a national basis. I believe the Federal Government should put money in, but only on the basis that there will be a central management that is effective and ensures that there is proper efficiency for the delivery of rail transport in Australia. We cannot go on having interstate trains where, when we get to the border, we change the crews, the operational management and so on. I believe that in this modern age that has to be overcome very quickly if we want a decent rail system that serves the Australian community, and particularly the need for more economic reform in our transport system.

Telecommunications is another area of the Speech in which I am interested. There has been much debate recently because of the Australian Telecommunications Authority (Austel) report which recommends allowing competition against Telecom Australia for cellular mobile phones. The fundamental issue that has to be addressed is whether in a country like Australia it is appropriate that the network system of communications which presently is a monopoly for Telecom, as agreed to by Parliament over now nearly 90 years, should be allowed to be broken up and to have competition. I believe also that there are very good arguments for maintaining the actual network as a Telecom monopoly. Telecom is a government monopoly which is responsible, through its board, for reporting to Parliament. I also believe that, in a modern age, whoever has access to information and its distribution has power and influence. I further believe that it is probably more appropriate in a social context that whoever controls the information distribution system in a country should be responsible directly to parliament through a government organisation or statutory authority such as Telecom. However, I also concede that many areas of competition in the add-ons, as they are called, could be looked at and opened up without affecting the operation of the first network. As they proliferate with modern technological development, the provision of the add-on services in telecommunications can be thoroughly investigated, and I believe that is an area where competition would be acceptable.

As I said, I have been asked to limit my remarks to less than 15 minutes, and I want to conclude on a number of brief points. First, I want to make a couple of remarks about a good friend of mine who is not in the Ministry any more-Senator Peter Walsh. He chose not to stand for re-election. At the moment the Opposition is taking some succour from the fact that Senator Walsh is making and writing remarks which it thinks are critical of the Government's performance. I think that Senator Walsh, in his usual inimitably frank way, has raised a number of issues that have to be debated by the Government. However, I also want to say to the Opposition that, if it thinks he may be tough about Government policy, he is much more rigorous in his denunciation of the Opposition's performance and policy in the economic area over the past seven years than is any comment he may make about the Government. Walshy, as we all call him, often takes the view that the community and the Labor Party have not learned the lesson about the need for economic efficiency and economic reform. My own view is that I do not think that over the past 10 years anyone in the Labor Party has done more than Peter Walsh to make members of the Labor Party economically literate. He has probably educated us about the need to make judgmental decisions regarding economic priorities. What Walshy taught us is that there are no easy decisions; tough decisions have to be made, but they should be based on equity and against privilege wherever it may exist. I want to pay a tribute to Peter Walsh: both as a friend and as a colleague he has done much to educate me about the realities of how a government should govern for all the people without fear or favour.

Secondly, my parliamentary Party has selected me to chair the Parliamentary Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade over the next three years. I accept it as a great honour to be nominated by the Government Party in the Parliament and I look forward to chairing that Committee. I accept the view that in status the Parliamentary Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade is probably the pre-eminent joint committee of the Parliament. I do not know whether chairmen of other standing committees or joint committees would agree with that, but that is the informal comment around, and I suspect that, amongst members of the Party in government, there is always keen competition to chair and to serve on the Committee. I accept that responsibility and I look forward to the Committee's work over the next three years.

Mr Acting Deputy President, the Labor Party is going into the 1990s as the Government of Australia for its fourth term. I believe the 1990s will be as significant in Australia as were the 1890s, 100 years ago, which was the decade of Federation. I believe also that the 1990s will be the decade when not only the most significant economic reform and structural change take place in this country but also, I hope, serious constitutional debate will take place as occurred 100 years ago when creating the Federation. I hope we have a mature debate in this community about the need to change the Constitution to meet the requirements of having a governmental system in Australia that is effective and efficient for the twenty-first century. I do not think that anyone would say that in the twenty-first century it is reasonable to govern a country with a Constitution drawn up on the precepts of what existed in Australia in the nineteenth century.

I also hope that, as part of that debate, we can look at constitutional change that leads to the establishment of a republic of Australia. I believe that, on 1 January 2001, the centenary of the foundation of the Federation, it would be most appropriate that Australia declare itself a republic and that it is most appropriate for that to occur. It is more appropriate for the future of our country and our own region that we are recognised as a fully independent country. We recognise the fact that Great Britain, for its own reasons and quite appropriately, is more and more drawn into what is happening in Europe and will be part of some European federation in which the old concepts of the so-called British Empire or British Commonwealth will no longer exist. We will stand and fall economically and socially by our relationships with the Western Pacific or the Asian region. I think it would be much more to our advantage to be identified as a republic in those relationships rather than as a constitutional monarchy, which does give some impression, at the very least, that we still have constitutional connections-and subordinate connections-to Great Britain.

So, I hope that the 1990s is a decade of not only economic reform in this country, which it will be, but also constitutional reform. I do not believe that we will effect the most efficient economic reform in this country unless we have serious constitutional changes to enable that economic reform to take place. As a part of that, over the next decade, I hope we can have a mature debate about the evolution of a republic and I think that generally the year 2001 would be the most appropriate date for Australia to declare itself a republic.

It is with great pleasure that I second the motion relating to the Address-in-Reply and look forward to participating in the debates in this chamber over the next three years as a member of the Labor Party in government, with a major package of change in this country that is so necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My Party has paid me a great honour in electing me its Leader in this place and in that capacity I wish to make a few preliminary comments before I address the Governor-General's Speech in detail.
—I hope you are there for 10 years.

—I have no intention of being here for 10 years, Senator Schacht. The Opposition has changed substantially. We present a new leadership. We present in excess of 20 new faces to the Parliament. Although we would very much wish to have won this election, because we would have regarded that as being in Australia's best interests, we accept the judgment of the people and we will set about the task of further refining our policies and developing them for not only the next period of government but also the next decade and beyond, because we really do think that it is time that there was some longer term thinking in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I congratulate all new senators who have been elected. At this stage I particularly mention those who are taking their place in the chamber within these few days: on my side, Senator Olsen, who yesterday replaced Senator Tony Messner; Senator Ian Campbell from Western Australia, who is replacing the former Senator Chaney; and the honourable senator to be, O'Chee, who takes his place in the chamber tomorrow and who will replace the former honourable senator, John Stone. Tony Messner is from my State and he made a major contribution to the work of the Senate and my Party over a long period. I would like to recognise that contribution through this speech this morning. Senator Chaney I mentioned yesterday; and Senator John Stone, although he may not have been here for long, certainly will be remembered. His intellect was admired by all and I think he introduced a new dimension. The intellectual jousts between him and Senator Walsh were always stimulating.

I want to say at the outset that I intend the Opposition in this place to be a constructive Opposition. We have no wish to be destructive. We believe the plight facing this country demands far more than that. We will press this Government upon its promises and we will demand of it the highest standards, standards to which we believe the community is entitled from a government of Australia. We will urge of this Government the types of reforms that we believe this country needs.

I also want to say finally as an introductory point how highly I regard the institution of the Senate in the Parliament of Australia. We will use the Senate and its committees to continue the task of improving the Government's legislation, a task that we have now undertaken for some years in opposition. We will use the Senate and its committees to enhance the financial accountability of government and to guard against administrative abuses. We will continue to make constructive contributions, within the traditional bipartisan way in the committees, to important areas of policy reform. In other words, we will seek to enhance the standing of this institution.

I will turn to the background in which we must place the Governor-General's Speech of yesterday. This is a time of critical importance in Australia's history. I am an optimist and I look forward to the next century and the celebration of 100 years of federation. I think we all should recognise that these intervening years, the 1990s, are going to present enormous challenges to all Australians and particularly to those of us who have been given the privilege of providing a lead-whether it be in government, in opposition or as individuals in the Parliament.

This is a period of dramatic international change. The ideological abyss which has divided the world community during the period of my lifetime is suddenly being broached. The pace of change is staggering. There are those, of course, who would wish to see a more ordered transition, but when the chance for freedom comes it must be grasped. With any change there are risks, and the political and economic transitions now occurring will bring instability and some danger. Australia and other democratic nations must act with courage and constructively help ease the trauma associated with such change.

The new multipolar world will in many ways be more challenging. Australia has had a comfortable niche within the Western alliance: very much a supporting role. A new maturity is going to be called for as Australia develops new political and economic relationships in a less structured environment. The world may not necessarily be a safer place. Competition and rivalry, as demonstrated by history, seem to be part of the nature of mankind.

In our own region we will find particular problems and challenges. The ideological thaw of eastern Europe has not reached North Korea, China or Vietnam, although we have of course in recent times witnessed the cry for freedom. We approach the first anniversary of the Tiananmen Square massacre. We witness the people of Cambodia still suffering the misery of conflict, the Philippines suffering continuing political trauma and many of its people suffering economically. The residents of Hong Kong are worried about 1997, when the Red Army will legitimately move in, and for us, closer to home, there are ongoing troubles in Papua New Guinea and other South Pacific states.

In economic terms we see in the international community a picture of contrasts-a growing and powerful European Community, and the dynamism and expansion of the Asian market, even though its key players might be suffering a few hiccups. Japan has perhaps a few more challenges than before, but nevertheless is continuing its inexorable march to economic superpower status, although demonstrating a few signs of stress. The United States of America, still the first economic power in the world, is similarly experiencing some strain under new realities. By contrast, the Third World remains debt ridden and impoverished, with some of the worst deprivation within our own region.

Against this background we see an Australia which must address not only the changes occurring in the surrounding world environment but significant economic, cultural and social changes within. Our society has become increasingly more complex and more multicultural, with greater social variances and a changing age profile. Governments must now respond to different social and cultural demands, different family structures and an ageing community. As we know, governments must also respond to a much more environmentally sensitive and demanding community.

We are also a country of contrasts. The gulf between the rich and poor has deepened, and, whilst most Australians continue to share a reasonable standard of living, we also share an enormous and growing debt. It is a debt which I must say, without wanting to be unduly provocative at this time, has more than quadrupled under Labor. I raise the issue because resolving Australia's debt crisis is probably the greatest challenge facing government. It is unhelpful, furthermore, as this Government has sought to do, simply to blame the private sector when about half of that debt-that half being some $64 billion-is in fact public debt. Private indebtedness itself has been built within government-set taxation and other investment parameters. It is this level of debt and Labor's attempt to constrain its expansion by high interest rate policies which contributed to the Government's record low primary vote in the last election.

It is the Governor-General's Speech, seen against the background of the Government's record and the constraints of the accord to which we must look to see whether Labor is capable of providing the lead necessary to reverse Australia's economic decline. Ordinary Australians have a right to be worried. They see the infrastructure of our country deteriorating. They experience the roads and railways every day. They see them in a sorry state, and yet they must be a key to our economic recovery. It is not surprising that this Government now has to pay out some $5 billion a year in interest payments alone.

Australians have witnessed a shady generation of entrepreneurs seeking short term enrichment through paper shuffling rather than building productive enterprise and then, unfortunately, crashing-to the detriment of our international standing. We see an export profile much as it was generations ago: a country still reliant upon primary production and extractive industry, although now supplemented with a reward for providing recreational facilities for those who are doing better elsewhere.

So we are witnessing a scenario we so often see elsewhere in the Third World: the cost of high technology, high value added imports exceeding the return from the export of low value added raw materials, and therefore huge current account losses each month. We in this country maintain our First World expectations and, more often than not, our First World standard of living. But we have not built a balanced, sophisticated First World economy in order to sustain this lifestyle, and so we borrow.

In the past this Government has failed to provide the lead, the policy prescription, to a more efficient, productive economic base. Its high interest rate policy to dampen demand has in fact crushed local competitive capacity. It has contributed to an ongoing cycle of inflation which has further inhibited our international competitiveness. It has driven Australia into a recession, a recession of its own making.

A recession might in turn dampen demand but it will not lead to a more efficient and productive Australia. So I look to the Governor-General's Speech for ways in which Labor intends to bring interest rates down and I and my colleagues remain disappointed.

I look for hope of a reduction in total taxation in order to increase incentive and there is none. Of course, under our system governments cannot force greater productivity and greater efficiencies. They must offer incentives or reduce disincentives. One such burden is the cost of inefficient government enterprise, and although privatisation is occurring all over the world, even now in eastern Europe, it is rejected by this Government.

I look for ways in which the Government will reduce unnecessary regulation. I do not speak about regulation for necessary safety standards or environmental standards, but regulation which stifles flexible and creative productive endeavour for no real community advantage, but sadly I find no change to the snail-paced program of the last Hawke Government.

I look for a freeing up of the labour market, reform which will reward productivity, yet again I am disappointed. Programs for improving our infrastructure are slow moving and inadequate. The Inter-State Commission calculated that container terminals overseas are at least 60 per cent more efficient than in Australia. The Government's program, in answer to that, is designed to lift our efficiency by 30 per cent. The challenge, which this Government does not seem to understand, is not to be more efficient than we were last year, but to be more efficient than our competitors.

Why does this Government continually accept a compromise? It does so because consensus is the cornerstone of the Hawke leadership. Consensus arises out of compromise and consensus might be an appeal to human nature which wins elections but it has retarded this Government's capacity to reform. Labor now has too many debts to repay, too much baggage to carry. Thus we saw this tired speech of yesterday.

I give the Senate the example of the waterfront union leader whom some of us saw on the television program on the weekend and who said, `If foreigners want to trade with Australia they will have to do so on our terms and conditions'. The accord means compromise with that sort of blind attitude, an attitude which will drive this country bankrupt. There is no workable alternative to a Liberal prescription of placing faith in individual Australians.

More of the same, which is the Government's answer, is leading us backwards. To put up the barriers again is not an option. With such a small domestic market, trade must be our lifeblood and only international markets will offer the economies of scale we will find necessary. Special deals for particular industries might work in a guided democracy such as Singapore-although Victoria may now be looking to try it-but in our system the reality is that the benefits and thus distortions simply get locked in.

We do not wish to be negative. What we wish is to impress upon the Government the urgency of this economic challenge. We are becoming less relevant in the world community and less able to influence events in ways which are in our best interests. We are suffering a loss of sovereignty as we become more economically dependent upon others. Ultimately our security and our independence will be at risk. In the meantime our standards of living will fall and more importantly we will have a reduced capacity to support those who particularly need the support of government-the aged, the disadvantaged and the infirm. We will have less capacity to protect our own environment and help others of the undeveloped world to protect theirs.

I know that governments do not like the concept of their influence being reduced, which is a product of this Liberal prescription I outline, but there are so many other areas in which the Australian Government could be putting positive endeavour, some complementary to the subject I have been discussing. Such areas include ensuring the best possible education system for this country, education that could put us at the forefront of technology and help us out of our isolation. We have major immigration debates ahead, questions on the quality of health care and health funding for this nation, environmental issues for Australia, debates on social policy, drug abuse, homelessness, all of these challenges that face government. There is a long way to go before Australia can be said to be a completely fair and just society. These are the real challenges which should be facing this Government.

I should add as I draw to a conclusion that the Liberals have been communicating this message of faith in individuals for a long time. Alfred Deakin during debate in the House of Representatives in 1912 said:

We rely upon our citizens working for their own families and their own future to develop our resources and perfect industries in a way that could never be attained by a regimented body of public employees marshalled under political control and bring political pressure to bear in their own class interest, no matter how ruinous its effects might be upon Australia's interest at home and abroad. Big as Australia is, immense as her resources are, she cannot live alone any more than any other continent can.

Nothing has really changed. I repeat the message we bring to the Government in this debate-it is not too late; it is a matter of urgency. Release the shackles and provide a new freedom for individuals to achieve their maximum potential. Give individuals the opportunity to take up the challenges and the opportunities of the 1990s. By doing so, the Government will be ensuring Australia the best chance of entering the new century, strong and confident.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The election that took place a short time ago was an important election for Australia's future and for this Parliament. The Australian Democrats were led into that election by Janine Haines, who unfortunately was not able to win the seat that she was running for in the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: When she started out on that process-I remind the Senate that she made that announcement about two years ago-the media almost universally were writing stories that come the next half-Senate election the Democrats would not get anyone elected and hence would be relying on only the three continuing senators. By her application, incredible hard work and dedication to the task, Janine Haines achieved the highest vote that the party has achieved since it was founded and in the new Parliament the highest representation that we have had in this place. In the minds of most people, the Australian political scene was shifted away from what has been perceived as a rigid two-party system but which since Federation has always been at least a three- or four-party system.

Her successes are now being felt within the party in general. We certainly believe that we are now operating in a new context. That, I think, is a very important context, not the least of which is that a considerable number of seats in the House of Representatives were won on a second preference vote from Australian Democrats voters. It is difficult at the moment to estimate those, particularly because of the problem of New South Wales giving its returns to central headquarters, but on our rough estimation-and I hope that later today I might have the firm figures-52 such seats in the House of Representatives were determined by voters who gave their first preference to us and their second preference to the people who won the seats. Thirty-three of those seats were Labor Party seats; 19 were Liberal-National Party seats, on our estimation. The figures may change slightly, but in any event the overall figure will be around 50.

The reason for that, I think, is that for the first time the issues on which the party was founded and to which it has dedicated itself since 1977 captured the public imagination. I refer to the fact that in our 1977 founding document we talked about a sustainable economy. Unfortunately that topic only found its way into the Speech of the Governor-General on 8 May 1990 when he said in the fourth paragraph that in fact the Government was going to dedicate itself to strategies for ecologically sustainable development.

We still do not think that the true import of that particular proposition for sustainable development has been understood. We still believe there is a lot of work that we have to do to direct people's attention to what is happening and to what needs to happen. We have never seen a division between the environmental debate and the economic debate. We believe that the type of division is a fallacious one.

If I may give an example that I have used a number of times before-it seems to me that it really illustrates very strongly the argument that the Democrats put forward-if we took a rationalist economic line we could very well say that, if a child dies, that family is better off. We could say that if all we were judging it on was the dollars and cents. Since the same number of dollars and cents are coming into that family and there is one less mouth to feed, it might be said the remaining members of that family would be better off.

Of course I do not believe there is one person in Australia who would hold to that. Everyone would want to say that that family is worse off. We are not talking about dollars and cents; we are indeed talking about a whole host of other values that this society should, and hopefully does, hold dear. We are talking about the values that need to be part of the economic debate and not seen as pure peripheral items that we may get around to if we have time or when all the economic problems have been sorted out. At its base, the economy is there to serve the people of this country. There are no values inherent in growth or anything else unless they are directed to the well-being and the support of the community.

That rather silly economic debate that some people in this place and certainly a lot of other people outside have been attempting to pursue for a long time hopefully saw its death knell in the last election. Hopefully nobody would have the temerity to go out in future and argue purely on the notion that growth for growth's sake is a good thing.

We hope also that people may start to look at what has been taken to be growth in this country. They may start to realise, for example, that a river into which no toxic wastes are poured and which is not used for irrigation never ends up in our gross domestic product. However, if we build a toxic waste plant right next door and pour the pollutants into that river, that polluted river becomes a drain and as a drain, with its disposal function, it gets into the accounts. Most Australians probably do not realise that they are contributing to the gross domestic product if they have a car crash, or the fact that when we chop down a tree it suddenly becomes part of growth in this country and yet when that tree is standing in the forest and growing it has no economic value.

These are absurd propositions-propositions which in the last election I think were disturbed. They are propositions that I think for the rest of this decade will be shown for what they are; that is, mindless assumptions dedicated to values that have been comprehensively rejected by the community.

So in terms of my party's performance at the last election, we are the only party in this place to get an increase in its vote, and we also had an increase in our representation. We believe that we had an increase in our representation. We believe that we have been given that additional vote of confidence by the people to continue the tasks that we have undertaken in this place now for the last four parliaments, and now in this the fifth Parliament, in which we have held the balance of power.

I think at this early stage it would be useful for me simply to outline what we believe that responsibility entails and what we are dedicating ourselves to carrying out. I wish to make those items fairly clear because in the past there has been a great deal of misrepresentation and I think that at the beginning of the new Parliament it is useful to stipulate once again our views on a number of these matters.

First of all, there has been an extraordinary amount of discussion about mandates-even in the Governor-General's Speech we had reference to the notion of a mandate; one of those lovely political science terms that float around, but the meaning of which I think people fail to address in a concrete way.

During the election campaign we said that we may not be supporting a particular piece of legislation if whoever was elected went ahead with it and we were attacked both by the Labor Party and the Liberal-National Party. They said that, if they won a majority in the House of Representatives, they should have a free legislative hand. I found it extraordinary that that view was pushed, because one knows that of course parties in opposition have never pursued that attitude. The Liberal-National Party now will in fact be reminded of a number of things it said during the election campaign. I am quite sure it has absolutely no intention of carrying them out in this Parliament; that is, it will not give the Labor Party a completely free hand. Indeed Senator Hill, speaking as Leader of the Opposition, indicated only a few minutes ago that the Opposition was not going to do that. Yet, that was part of the proposition that the Opposition put to the people.

Our view, and the view we have taken consistently with regard to a mandate, is that under the Constitution the only sensible notion of a mandate is that which is provided to an individual person elected. That person can claim a mandate in the House of Representatives because he or she has been given the voice of the people to bring into this place. Likewise senators from the States. The individual certainly has a mandate. I think it is reasonable, then, to extrapolate from that constitutional mandate that is given to each individual under a party system that if a sufficient number of mandates are gathered together to form a majority in the House of Representatives-and the Labor Party in this case has a majority of those people who received mandates from the people-it has a mandate to govern; that is, for the Executive to carry out the laws passed by the Parliament. It definitely has that mandate and it is required to carry out those laws in a conscientious way. Indeed, Ministers take an oath to do that.

There is, however, outside of all that, still another proposition; that is, who has the mandate with regard to the laws? Under our Constitution, all laws are required to be passed by both Houses. Hence it cannot be said that anybody in the last election received such a mandate, because in fact they have not been able to gather together a majority in both places in support of particular propositions. Hence, no party has received from the electorate, quite deliberately, a mandate with regard to legislation and we will continue to do what we have done in the past; that is, address each piece of legislation on its merits.

But can I point to a radical distinction between the stance that we have taken and will continue to take in this chamber and that which is currently being debated around the traps-for example, in Victoria, as to whether or not the upper House there may reject Supply, or in Western Australia, where there is talk amongst the Liberal and National parties as to whether they will reject Supply or whether they will refuse to deal with any legislation or whatever else.

That is not our view. It has never been our view, and it will not be our view. Our view is that this chamber has a responsibility to deal with legislation presented to it by Government, or by other senators, or by individual members of the House of Representatives who may be successful in getting a private member's Bill through that House. But that is our responsibility. It is not a responsibility to go on strike.

With regard to whether or not we would use the processes of this House to bring down a government, as senators are well aware, since the formation of the party in 1977 we have said that will not be part of our role. Following on from that, it means that there is at least one set of Bills which we guarantee now, as we have in every other Parliament in which we have held the balance of power, to pass.

They are the Bills which provide for the ordinary annual services of Government, as the phrase goes in the Constitution. Again, this one has been bandied around and made to appear into all sorts of different items. Basically it is Appropriation Bills No. 1 and No. 2 and the Parliamentary Supply Bill, unless this place does not wish to continue to work, plus the Supply Bills which we are about to deal with-Nos 1 and 2-in this place, which are basically the supplementary Supply until appropriation is passed later in the year. They are the Bills.

I am not referring to money Bills, which are another whole host of Bills which deal with money. I am not referring to taxation Bills. If people cannot tell the difference between raising money and spending it, I suggest they should learn very quickly, because it is a fundamental element that every Australian has to be aware of. I am not referring to Budget Bills, which are all of those Bills that the Government may bring in during a Budget session. I am not referring to anything other than those Bills which are necessary for the ordinary annual services of Government.

The Government of the day, while it retains a majority in the House of Representatives, we believe is entitled to that appropriation and we will continue to do that. Hence, for the life of this Parliament that issue is not on the agenda here, although it may be on the agenda in State Houses. We will not be using the forms of this House to bring down a government. That is merely a reiteration of the fact that it is interesting that since we gained the balance of power that item has been off the agenda here and it will remain off while we have the power in this place to make sure that it does.

But all other legislation needs to be examined, we believe, on its merits. The Senate, when it meets after 1 July, will be trialling a new method that I certainly had a hand in arguing through a committee and into this place. I wish it well with that item. It will be an extremely difficult one to operate and to make it work well, but I think it is worth the effort to try to reform the legislative process and to bring in, as was the intent with that particular method, more outside scrutiny of what it is that we do.

After all, at the end of the day, the Bills apply to all Australians and I believe that they have a right to be involved at a much earlier stage than simply finding out that a Bill has been passed which causes them to do X, Y or Z. I believe they have a fundamental right in a democracy to know that we are contemplating doing that. If they have an objection, if they have a problem, it is best to learn about it before we do it, rather than after we have done it.
That is the intent. Whether it will work, I do not know. I think there are a lot of difficulties with it, but I think it is worth the trial that the Senate intends to give it.

I believe there needs to be predictability with regard to legislation; that the Government needs to provide to the Senate much further ahead of time its legislative program and to stick with that program, not to chop and change, and not for people to have a bright idea and then bounce it into the Parliament.

When one considers the practicalities of drafting and the problems that are involved today in 1990 with the drafting process and the fact of bringing those particular Bills into concurrence with so many other pieces of legislation, making sure that unintended consequences are not included, it must mean that Government has these Bills in mind far earlier than we ever hear about them. I believe that the Senate ought be informed that the Government is intending to bring in these particular pieces of legislation and at the earliest opportunity those pieces of legislation should be provided.

I think that the Standing Orders, which have been reiterated in a whole new written form, ought to be abided by in terms of the processes by which a Bill goes through the chamber. There are very good reasons for the various hiatuses of time between one element and the next- between the first and second readings, between the second reading and the committee stages. I think all of those are excellent and ought be included.

The exercise with regard to legislation we believe should be addressed more and more, and hopefully under the new procedures will be, to the merits of the legislation and not to the political point scoring that a particular piece of legislation may provide. I think we in the Senate have to remember that there is another chamber and that the other chamber is probably far better equipped than this chamber for those political debates. Is it necessary that we spend all of that time yet again on another political debate?

I think the Senate needs constantly to reform its processes, because if we preach to the community outside about the need for productivity, about the need for growth, about the need to take on new technologies, it is very strange that the first hint of a productivity reform in this place has people scurrying into highways and byways. I think the reaction to the paper on electronic voting is an instance with regard to that, of immediately not seeking to find where good elements might be in that but of saying, `Let us have a look at where the bad elements might be'. If the community and our economy did that we would never move. We would never have adopted the Edison electricity, because at the time gas was cheaper, more widespread and, after all, it had been tried.

So I think there is a need for an openminded view with regard to change and to growth as an institution and not for us to think that simply in 1990, because the institution is still in this substantial building, somehow or other it has a reason to continue to exist. The reason must be in the way it acts and what it does, not in the fact that it is written down that it has to be there. I think a useful contribution for this chamber-as I believe it has made an excellent contribution in the last few parliaments-is that it needs to continue that open-mindedness towards change and, hopefully, towards improvement.

The growth of the Senate committee system, particularly through the statutory committees-there are now three; two have been used in the past and the third one will be operational in the life of this Parliament in terms of the corporations legislation-is a new and a welcome departure, a departure by which, hopefully, those senators who work on those committees will have an in-depth and expanded understanding of a particular knowledge base, which will improve debate in this chamber.

The party system is likely to continue into the next Parliament in almost an unchanged way, and it will probably be in the long term future before we see much freeing up of that. But it is a pity that opportunities have been lost in the immediate past to have some freeing of the party control of the Parliament, particularly when there are strongly held views; and we have seen those here in senators in all parties. They can easily be recognised when they occur and, hopefully, the Labor Party, in terms of its internal discussions, will be able to see more opportunity for that movement to be able to take place.

The Senate has something to offer the legislative process. We do not know the final numbers yet. The matter is still in the balance even today. If the Liberal Party wins the last seat in New South Wales, the numbers will be: 31 Labor Party, 35 Liberal-National, 8 Democrats, 2 Independents. If the seat in New South Wales goes to the Labor Party, the figures will be very similar to the current Parliament-32 Labor, as they currently have, 34 Liberal-National, as they currently have, 8 Democrats, and 2 Independents. The Independents will have been reduced by one, and we will have increased by one.

That is very little change when compared to about 30 House of Representatives seats changing hands. Very little change has occurred between this current Senate and the next Senate starting on 1 July. But I do not think that that should be taken as meaning that the Senate can rest on its laurels. It has a task ahead of it to make sure that it is productive and contributes to the general development of legislation. As I say, the new method will, I hope, do that as the first cab off the rank. But I would also hope that some of those other innovations, which may be uncomfortable to wear, which may require every senator, for example, if one adopted electronic voting technique, to actually know what they were voting about--

TALK.START.PARA: —That would not hurt.

—I do not think it would hurt, Senator Baume. It may not change one vote, but at least they would know what they were voting on because they would actually have to address the question. At the moment there is no need to address the question. I would also hope-and I do not think I am speaking out of turn to say this-that more senators in the new Parliament may read legislation. I think somebody from the House of Representatives in the election campaign said that he had never read a piece of legislation in all the 20-odd years he had been in the place. That is an indictment of the person, not something to be said in public. I would have felt that a person would be ashamed to say that. In the debates in the new Parliament I would hope that more senators will contribute and that they will not simply be left to the front bench people on the understanding that that is a quicker way to get through the material. That may not be an acceptable view for the Whips, I know; it makes life a lot more difficult for them. But ultimately, since the Senate is now meeting-and I emphasise to the media that the Parliament is not meeting for seven days; the Senate is meeting for a lot longer than that and it is part of the Parliament. We still had learned political commentators as early as this morning talking about the Parliament meeting for seven days. The House of Representatives may be meeting for seven days but the Senate is not. The Senate is meeting for four weeks. The Senate is now meeting, I think, for something like 40 per cent longer than the House of Representatives, and we shall probably have to exceed even that margin. It will probably have to meet for 50 or 60 per cent longer than the House of Representatives to be able to do its work properly. But I think that is an acceptable thing considering the length of time that other places meet.

SPEECH.PARA: I make a correction to some of the numbers I mentioned. In terms of the preference determinations, the numbers are indeed 38 Labor Party seats, 10 Liberal-National Party seats, which makes 48 seats-not the 52 that I mentioned first of all. So the final exercise, though the Victorian figures are still provisional, seems to be of the order of 48, not 52. But nevertheless, the number of seats so determined, I think, suggests that the policies we put to the people need to be given a great deal of consideration in the new Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by congratulating the two Labor Party senators who moved and seconded the Address-in-Reply. Although Labor chose some of its more junior senators, it could not choose a maiden speaker since it had no new senator in this place following the election. So I would now like to congratulate the new senators from the other parties. I congratulate Senator Olsen on his election, and Senator Campbell on his imminent swearing in. I congratulate Senator O'Chee on his imminent swearing in. I congratulate Senators Bell and Lees on having joined us yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: On the speakers list which we have before us there are no Labor speakers after those who have moved and seconded the Address-in-Reply. Perhaps this is an indication of the importance the Labor Party places on the Address-in-Reply to the Speech of the Governor-General. I want to use the time that I have available to me to draw attention to the very poor state of political debate in Australia today and to make the points that the debate is too personal; that it is too trivial; that it is too technical; but above all-and this is the point I want to develop-that it has far too little attention to matters of purpose, to matters of goals and to objectives. It is that factor which has led people to abandon the two major political groupings and to move to support third parties and independents.

People had been moving away from the main political parties, from my Party, from the Labor Party, and from the National Party, parties which have previously enjoyed their support. An independent person won election for a seat in a formerly safe Liberal area a few weeks ago. That person offered no specific policies-not one policy prescription. But he did project hope and integrity, and concern and involvement, and that is why he was elected. There are lessons in these voting movements. Either we learn the lessons, we move to understand the trends, and we do something about responding, or else we will continue to see support moving to third parties and to independents.

It is sad that so little of the post-election statements of the major political movements so far has related to these lessons. What should we have learnt from the election? It is sad that so little of the comment is related to this phenomenon of the third party and independent voting. It is sad that so little of the comment is related to ways in which we might seek to respond to what is a new and deeply felt public demand that things be done differently.

Let me return to my assertion that the political debate in Australia today is too technical, too personal, too trivial and too little is addressed to matters of purpose. We should be developing strategic goals first, providing inspiration for people. We should be exciting our young by our political goals and ideals. We should be trying to inspire all Australians. We are not doing it.

Maybe we are trying but we are not achieving it. That we do not achieve it is the greatest indictment possible of the current Australian policy. That too much of the debate is too detailed and too technical is sadly borne out by yesterday's speech by the Governor-General. Most people do not understand the various items in the Speech. Most people feel it does not touch them or their lives. I notice Senator Button smiling. Almost no Australian is inspired by what was said. People are not interested in programs that are presented just as activity. They want programs that are presented in terms of the goals to be achieved. People are not interested in activity or structure or money inputs; and it does not have to be like that.

It is possible to communicate between politicians and people. We have many examples. There have been great crises in this century in many countries. One characteristic of leaders who have emerged to meet those crises has been that they have been able to articulate goals with which the majority of their people could identify and which these people could follow. The most recent example that comes to my mind is the case of Vaclav Havel, the man who has been chosen as President of Czechoslovakia; the man elected as President of Czechoslovakia. What a statement! That man is a poet. His skill is to communicate brilliantly. In his acceptance speech he communicated the aspirations of a nation crushed by dictatorship and determined to do better. His speech was one of brilliance and passion, not one of dreary details. He did not present himself as a technocrat who would adjust this or change that slightly but as a person who was going to blaze a new track for his country and to invite people to join him.

It has been said of Winston Churchill that in a time of the greatest crisis for the British people, for the United Kingdom, he made of the English language a weapon of supreme clarity and power-and he used that weapon. He used what he could say to gather the people of his country with him in a noble common purpose. Do we hear that kind of political debate today? Not much. Churchill did so without being overly specific as to the details, but being quite specific as to the purpose. To paraphrase his words, he said: 'You ask what is my program. My program is victory'. That is all he would give the people.

We do not have any such common purpose in Australia today. I do not hear any such common purpose being offered to us by our national leaders. What we are offered instead are statements about input, the number of dollars we are going to spend; statements about structures, the kinds of commissions we are going to establish; the kinds of committees that are going to meet. We have statements about things that are going to be done. The Governor-General's Speech yesterday was full of things which are going to be done, but not where they are going to take us; not what kind of nation we would be once they were done-being busy, being active, doing things. That seems to be enough now for tired governments.

One can actually be quite busy doing quite ignoble things. We have had a number of countries this century which have demonstrated just that. We have had it here in this country. Let me give you an example, Madam Acting Deputy President. The Hawke Government just a few years ago decided to withdraw the supporting parents benefit from a particular class of beneficiaries, those whose children reached a certain age. The proposal saved money, but it disadvantaged some needy and vulnerable women and families. Think of that. That was a proposal and it went through. At no time did the Hawke Government present any logical statement of social purpose behind that action. It did not because there was no logical social purpose behind the action. What it did was to meet a financial objective, to save outlays. There was no defensible social purpose at all. On the contrary, Madam Acting Deputy President, that decision made inevitable the emergence of more latchkey children and made more difficult, inevitably, the task of single parents wishing to be home-makers. If one looks at the purpose that is being achieved, one sees that that purpose is ignoble. That is just one example of a myriad of actions.

Let me now say something nice about the Government. While I criticise the Government for its program as we heard it yesterday, I have to say that in another area it has taken action to its credit. The Government has moved the Public Service towards program budgeting and it now requires that the Budget be presented in program terms.

This means that spending is grouped under programs and that for each program there must be stated objectives-objectives which can be examined and tested and challenged, and which we do examine and test and challenge-and that there should be performance measures related to the achievement of those objectives. Really, what I would ask, Madam Acting Deputy President, is that the same Government apply to itself in what it proposes that which it now requires of the Public Service over which it has dominion.

You see, we must judge the Speech of the Governor-General against these kinds of benchmarks. Did the Speech point the way towards a better nation? Did the Governor-General's Speech point the way towards a fairer future? Did it point the way towards new opportunity and hope? Those are the tests which are important today; those are the tests which our electors are trying to make us apply. They are the questions which we are being asked by our young. What will it do for the country? Is it fair? The most famous thing for which John Kennedy is remembered is not his legislative failure but the words with which he inspired America when he said, 'Ask not what your country can do for you, but what you can do for your country'. People want to know what this program yesterday is going to mean for Australia. It is these tests which are important today, not the specific programs, not just being busy. So let us now look at the Speech of the Governor-General.

First in fairness to His Excellency, let us acknowledge, of course, that it was the Government's Speech, uttered faithfully by the Governor-General on behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Ministers. So if the Speech is deficient in any way that deficiency must be sheeted home to those who wrote the message, not to the person who delivered the message on their behalf. Recently I re-read Alan Reid's book The Whitlam Venture. It is good reading for any politician. In it he recounts the night of the election of 13 December 1975 when Labor had suffered a massive election defeat. Alan Reid records that as he left the tally room he had the following thoughts. I will quote some of his words. Alan Reid wrote:
As I left the tallyroom I wondered what that victory would mean for the future of Australia and the futures of the average, ordinary Australians of whom I was one.

Australians who really did not ask for much but only for the right to work in jobs that would keep themselves and their families in reasonable comfort, for a bit of leisure, for homes that they owned and could take a pride in; for being left alone and in peace and not pushed around by government and bureaucrats; to know that they and their fellow citizens were getting a 'fair go' and that the underprivileged and vulnerable were being helped so that their lives became more bearable and their children had some opportunity to escape the harshness that their parents had known and to achieve a better life style.

Madam Acting Deputy President, those are noble goals for any nation. They describe an Australia in which I would like to live. They describe an Australia for the achievement of which I would fight and strive. They are purposes which promise the enrichment of a society which embraces them.

But the Labor Government has not gone down that track; it has not chosen to move towards those ideals. It has done worse than that: it has done the opposite. It has trivialised the opportunity presented by the opening of this Parliament. It failed to set any visionary goals. It was content to identify its actions and its busyness. We have seen not the enhancement of work opportunity but increasing evidence now becoming apparent of fewer jobs being advertised, of pessimism about future prospects for work, of longer periods for those who find themselves out of work, of longer periods between jobs, of fewer jobs available in places where people live.

As for Alan Reid's goal that Australians should have jobs which would keep them and their families in reasonable comfort, Labor has a lot to answer for and a lot to explain. Family living standards have fallen, and they continue to fall. We are having more trouble paying for food for our families. We are having more trouble buying shoes and clothes for our children and for ourselves, and so on. Individual living standards are falling too, Madam Acting Deputy President. It is harder to afford small luxuries and it is harder to continue today to do what we could do readily seven years ago. As for picking up Alan Reid's vision of owning a home, a home in which we can take pride, all the movements in Australia are in the opposite direction.

It is almost impossible for young people to afford homes anywhere near their parents in the capital cities. My son is despondent about ever being able to afford a home in Sydney at all. He is a qualified person with good earning prospects. He is in full-time employment and he saves money and yet he has no sense of hope, no optimism, that he will ever be able to own a home anywhere in Sydney. What kind of nation is it that will permit this and say nothing about it when it puts down its program for the next three years?

Many decent, caring, responsible Australians are finding it impossible to continue to pay off mortgages on the homes they have acquired. More and more of those Australians are losing their homes. Others are spending larger and larger parts of their income on mortgage payments swollen by record high interest rates. For most of them it is harder and harder to keep that home as they would wish; harder and harder to maintain it properly; harder and harder to furnish it; and harder and harder to enjoy it. And this is after seven years of government. There is nothing in the Governor-General's Speech yesterday to offer hope to those people; nothing to inspire them; nothing to lead them.

As for Alan Reid's vision that we should ensure a fair go for the vulnerable, we should be ashamed of what we see in Australia today. We see more alienated people, not fewer. We see more homeless young people, not fewer. We see more people living below the poverty line, not fewer. We see more and more people giving up the struggle. We find more and more unmet need. And when you look into people's eyes, if you listen to them as they weep, when they tell you how it is, when they tell you how hard the struggle is, only then can you begin to understand what is going on today for those not lucky enough to be living on ministerial salaries.

While all this is happening to real people we have to listen to Government rhetoric that seems not to understand, that seems to be unaware, that seems to be dissociated from the real problems, and we have to listen to Government Ministers who give no evidence of caring either. Harshness is all around us and it is increasing. Far from achieving what Alan Reid had sought, of a fair go for the vulnerable, we see more and more people condemned to experience and continue in poverty and misery, and condemned to repeat the cycle of dependence which that brings with it.

This is not a new or a young government; it has had years. I think Senator Schacht boasted about government for a decade. This Government has had most of that decade and it has had all that time to deliver a better life for Australians. It has had time to deliver better prospects and more opportunity. Madam Acting Deputy President, I looked to the Speech of the Governor-General for some hope and direction. I listened for some noble goals. I listened for a vision to lead and inspire young people. I listened for messages that I could present to my children and to their friends. I listened for some message to draw people back to contribute to the mainstream of politics. But I looked in vain.

There were no such messages. I found none. There is just one phrase on the first page of a 12-page speech and otherwise it is a technician's document, a testament to being busy rather than being effective. A document may be good for accountants or bankers or economists; good for technocrats who want to fiddle and adjust and fix things at the margins without ever knowing what it is they seek to do for people or where they seek to lead us. Not only that; that document, if that is the best the Government can do, will accelerate the flight of caring people from the main political parties to third and fourth groups and to independents who seem to identify with their needs and their hopes and aspirations even if they do not have specific programs. That is what we are going to see.

I would like to dedicate myself to achieving those purposes identified by the late Alan Reid so eloquently almost 15 years ago. I would like to dedicate myself to trying to assert for individual Australians that there is hope, and to assert at the same time that we in this society have both rights and obligations. In doing that, of course, I would reject the arguments of those libertarians who would argue on the one hand for many rights and on the other for no obligations. But, on the other hand, Madam Acting Deputy President, I would also reject those of my friends who are socialists who identify obligations but are very reluctant to grant rights to individuals, just as I reject the increasing number who would replace the government of people with the administration of things.

In order to achieve the Alan Reid vision we really must allow the energy, the enterprise and the vigour of Australians to be released, but we must, at the same time, ensure that we undertake our duties as members of a community of caring people, that we remind ourselves that we remain committed to care and compassion and to action to achieve good outcomes. I have to say to you that there was nothing in the Governor-General's Speech yesterday which gave me any hope that the Government was aware or cared very much.

I would like to see a dedication to the good outcomes that characterise so many administrations of my political persuasion in the past. I went back to a speech I gave in this place on the Equal Employment Opportunity (Commonwealth Authorities) Bill 1987, a very important speech for me at the time. I quote a little bit of it. I said:
Liberalism is not, and has never been, just an economic doctrine and liberalism cannot be presented as such to an informed electorate.
Philosophical Liberals believe passionately in equality of opportunity, and of removing barriers, wherever they may be, which prevent people from exercising that equality.
The greatest achievements of philosophical liberalism have been to remove such barriers.
The ending of slavery, the emancipation of Jews and Catholics in Protestant England, public education, reform of the electoral system, the vote for women, are just some of them.

The Fraser Administration, of which I was a part, was the Administration that actually passed an Aboriginal land rights Bill, that took decisive action on promoting the rights of women, that made the first steps towards codifying and registering Australian environmental areas on the World Heritage List, that stopped the mining of Fraser Island, that put into effect the enforcement of the racial discrimination Acts. I am going to fight still, Madam Acting Deputy President, for a continuing Liberal vision of a society of free and powerful individuals each able to control his or her life.

I would like to have seen a Governor-General's Speech which took us somewhere down that road, which identified that vision and those goals and which indicated how they would be achieved. It is only by identifying objectives that we can see where the Government wishes to travel, where it seems to be going, and to know where it has been. Only by identifying objectives can we judge the performance of the Government. It is not enough for the Government to tell us what it is doing. It has to tell us where it wishes to take us when it has done those things.

That is the greatest single failure of the Government program laid down in the Speech. To the extent that this or any other government continues to avoid setting noble, visionary, admirable, defensible, testable objectives-ones with which many citizens can identify-it will sell short to a greater or lesser degree the community in which it operates. Any government that does that, Madam Acting Deputy President, will continue to oversee alienation and cynicism in its society, as we are seeing today in Australia, and as long as governments do that, so long will governments seem irrelevant to the problems blighting the lives of so many. As long as governments do that they will continue to contribute to the flight of people away from the mainstream of politics.

So, Madam Acting Deputy President, I found this speech-not the Governor-General's Speech because he was only delivering what the Government prepared for him-an inadequate testament. It is inadequate because while I knew what was being done I did not know where the Government saw us being taken. I say to my colleagues in this chamber that, while I did not know, neither did a whole lot of other Australians who have talked to me. Their complaint is not so much with what we do but as to why we are doing it and where we are taking them. Until the Government is willing to address some of those questions and to excite and inspire people, so long will the major political parties of this country continue to lose support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I listened yesterday with considerable interest to the Governor-General's Speech in which he outlined the Government's plan for the future. I noted that there were numerous references to the Government's commitment to justice and social equity, to creating a fairer Australia. Women and children, it seemed to be put, in particular were singled out as the lucky recipients of the Labor Government's good intentions.

SPEECH.PARA: One could be forgiven, I think, for expressing some scepticism in the matter. Nobody will forget the 1987 election promise of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that by 1990 no child would live in poverty. We are now well into 1990 and regrettably we know all too well that that, in fact, is not the case. That was not the outcome. None of us, of course, takes any joy from that fact or from the fact that the Government was not able to succeed in fulfilling that promise. Of course, amongst those are the half million people, including children, who live below the poverty line.

I was interested yesterday to listen for some real sign that in particular these people would be better off in the future than they have been in the past. The children I am talking about live in a range of different circumstances. Some of them are homeless because their family situation has collapsed. It has become so difficult and so physically dangerous that they have been forced to leave home. Of course, many of them live at home in a quite loving environment but one that is economically deprived, living on social security benefits or on particularly low incomes.
