A large percentage of children living in poverty are from single parent families.

It is a particular aspect of the Government's treatment of single parent families to which my remarks in this Address-in-Reply debate are directed. I welcome the opportunity to raise the matter, which I have raised before in this place on more than one occasion. It continues to be a sore; it continues to make life difficult and stressful for many Australians, a substantial number of whom are low income earners and almost all of whom are women. I speak today, though, in the hope that something will be done to investigate and follow up the problem more than has been done by the Government so far. I am talking, Madam Acting Deputy President, about the Child Support Agency.

I have spoken frequently about the Agency. I had a letter from the Agency inviting me to come to its Melbourne office to look at what it does. It is not with the Melbourne office that I have had any difficulties. People in Canberra and this region deal with an office not in Canberra, but in Chatswood in New South Wales. Let me also say that I have no philosophical opposition to the concept of parents being financially responsible for their children. It is one of the fundamentals of Liberal philosophy that we believe individuals should be free to make their own choices. They should, though, be responsible for the choices that they make. Responsibility of a parent for a child, I believe, is basic and important. It would be my preference that parents be prepared to accept the responsibility for their children without the need for government intervention. I recognise that there will always be some who refuse to accept their responsibilities and until the Child Support Agency was set up we accepted the role of the courts as the enforcing bodies for the financial responsibility on parents. We recognised though that there were significant problems with the enforcement of maintenance orders through the courts and supported the establishment of this Agency.

There has been a stream of complaints since that time-I refer though, as I said, particularly to the Australian Capital Territory-about the way the Agency is not functioning and meeting the needs of those who are dependent on it. Nobody doubted that there would be some teething problems. There certainly were at the outset. Most related to delays of three to six months in getting maintenance recovery under way. But unfortunately for some women, who under the old regime, through the courts, had been paid regularly, the change left them without maintenance for months, and in many cases the arrears which accumulated in that time still have not been recovered. It is true that some women who were receiving nothing are now getting some maintenance and that is very welcome indeed. I hope that that number grows. But the reports which have come to my notice on a continuing basis suggest that there are significant problems in the delivery of services by the Agency, certainly to people in Canberra and possibly elsewhere.

Like other colleagues I get requests from constituents to make representations for them on all sorts of things-taxation, immigration, social security and health. Some of these require correspondence to the department or the Minister. Frequently a request for help is received by my office and staff will make a telephone contact to the relevant department and discuss the problem with an officer of the department. It is exceptional, in my experience, to have any difficulty in dealing with officers of the Public Service in these situations. Almost throughout, in my experience, where information could be made available it has been made available, assuming, of course, that there is no breach of confidentiality or legal impediment to divulging information. It has always been willingly and courteously provided. A phone call will reveal the status of a case, the reason for a decision or what is holding up a decision in some instances. But the one glaring exception, in my experience, has been the Child Support Agency.

The Agency has no office in Canberra. I cannot suggest that there would be an office of the Agency in every town in the country, but I would have thought it would be possible to have a small office, at least, in the major centres. I want to speak about how the Agency deals with its clients and the experiences that I have had in my own office in dealing with it. I shall not go over the examples that I have used previously when speaking in the Senate about this, but I want to go over some of the things that have come to my notice in recent times and to make some observations about the way I think the Agency is functioning at present.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received through His Excellency the Governor-General, from the Governor of Queensland, a copy of a certificate of the choice by the Queensland Parliament of William George O'Chee as a senator to fill the vacancy in the representation of that State caused by the resignation of Senator John Owen Stone. I table a copy of the certificate.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PAPUA NEW GUINEA: SANCTIONS AGAINST BOUGAINVILLE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the extent of the sanctions imposed by the Papua New Guinea (PNG) Government against Bougainville? Was Australia consulted or advised by the PNG Government before the sanctions were imposed? Will Australian-supplied equipment be used to enforce the blockade? Does Australia support the blockade?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The restrictions that have now been imposed by Papua New Guinea, as announced in the last day or so following a week of some uncertainty, extend only to the 12-mile territorial sea around Bougainville. They involve the following particular steps, as announced by Mr Diro yesterday: Restrictions will apply to all coastal shipping to and from Bougainville except ships ferrying hospital and medical supplies, goods for the outer islands and fuel for the generation of electricity at the hospital. The Papua New Guinea Customs and Harbour Board will cease clearing vessels for landing in Bougainville and no pilot services will be provided to shipping services into Bougainville. Flights into Bougainville can only be made on the authority of the PNG Director of Civil Aviation. Services in Bougainville will be affected, including banking and telephones.

ANSWER.PARA: The subject of a possible blockade was discussed by me with the PNG Ministers concerned during my visit to PNG two weeks ago. At that stage it was made clear to me that something of this kind was very much in contemplation. I was told at the time that a total exclusion zone extending out to 50 nautical miles was not in contemplation, although it had been considered. Accordingly, I was extremely surprised when a notice to aviators and mariners was issued last week extending the zone out that far, which would, of course, interfere with our shipping lanes, and raised quite fundamental questions of international law.

That confusion was subsequently resolved over the course of the next few days. It was a mistake, an unintended exercise, by the PNG authorities. So we were given reasonable notice of their intention to mount a restrictive exercise of the kind that has now been put into place. It was not a matter of Australia being consulted or expressing an attitude on this, because clearly an exercise of this kind, as I made obvious at the time, was regarded by us as wholly an internal matter for the PNG Government.

As to whether Australia might become involved in the enforcement of this set of restrictions, all I can say is that no request has been made of us in that respect. Obviously we would look at any such request on its merits when it arose, although questions of very great sensitivity would manifestly be involved were we to become involved in a matter of that kind.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Resources aware of the results of the invitation by Woodside Petroleum Ltd to tender for contracts for construction of the Goodwyn A stage of the North West Shelf project? Have Australian companies been able to participate in this stage of the project? If so, can the Minister inform honourable senators which sectors of Australian industry will benefit from this participation? Can the Minister also inform honourable senators what benefits Australia can expect from the project as a whole?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first question was whether I am aware of what invitations were extended. Woodside Petroleum, in terms of the Goodwyn A platform construction, prequalified a number of Australian tenderers. I am aware of that process and of the complete result of the tender outcome, because I was a member of the sensitive contracts committee, constituted by Commonwealth and State governments, in this case the State Government of Western Australia, and met with senior executives of Woodside to review the outcome of such bids. Naturally, the sensitive contracts outcomes are confidential, are commercial-in-confidence, and I am not in a position to reveal them in the chamber, but I am aware of all those details.

ANSWER.PARA: A number of Australian companies did participate and a number of Australian companies had bids which were, by and large, not competitive with major overseas bids. However, following discussions with Woodside and following steps taken by the unions and some of the bidders-in particular, the Press Clough Ltd consortium in Western Australia-the bids were modified significantly because of savings able to be effected due to changes in the industrial relations procedures that were to be implemented for the work to be carried out.

As a result of that, and as a result of the State governments in South Australia and Western Australia as well being prepared to make some concessions-in the case of Western Australia, concessions of about $10m for site preparation and the forgoing of State taxes and charges in the form of payroll tax, et cetera-it became possible for the Commonwealth Government to consider whether it should exercise an existing provision under the Customs Act to waive a customs duty.

We believe that, in view of the importance of these contracts being located in Australia and future offshore work being able to be carried out not only on the North West Shelf of Western Australia but in the Timor Sea, given the prospects for the region, and the high growth of resource development within the Association of South East Asian Nations area, if an incentive were given to these companies to win a major international contract and demonstrate their capacity for quality workmanship, there would be a possibility of setting them up to win contracts in other major developing areas.

There was also a significant improvement in industrial relations not only for Press Clough but, because of the negotiations that were conducted, an improvement in industrial relations commitments throughout the whole of the third stage of the North West Shelf project. On that basis the concession was granted. As a consequence it is now guaranteed that for the life of the piles contracts in South Australia at least 150 jobs will continue and, because of the contract for the modules in Western Australia, 700 jobs will be able to be continued.

I conclude by saying that the actions of the State governments in both Western Australia and South Australia to support their local industry and to encourage a more competitive bid, in which case they have won these contracts, have to be contrasted with the attitude of the New South Wales Government. The Deputy Premier in New South Wales, Wal Murray, declined to give New South Wales industry the sorts of benefits, in order to help them be competitive, that the State governments in South Australia and Western Australia were doing. As a consequence the ability of Newcastle to be competitive was simply non-existent. In terms of supporting the particular local industry I think that is a significant consideration as to why Woodside in the end, and in its commercial judgment, decided to award the contracts as it has.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MINISTER FOR JUSTICE AND CONSUMER AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. Will the Minister give the Senate an explanation for making public statements which led to a criminal trial against one Prasart Yooyen for heroin importation being aborted?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable senators may be aware, the judge in this case has remanded the accused in custody to face trial again. Obviously I shall try to be as informative as possible in the answer that I give. I have been advised by the Attorney-General's Department and the Director of Public Prosecutions himself that for this reason there are limits on the detail which it is proper for me to provide. I wish to acknowledge straight away that the matter to which the honourable senator refers has been of serious concern to me, and indeed to the Prime Minister and to the Attorney-General. I acknowledge here, as I have to them, that my remarks to the media were most unfortunate in respect of both the presumption of guilt on the part of the person arrested in Thailand and their causing the judge of the trial in Sydney to abort the trial. I accept the error I made and the significance of that error.

ANSWER.PARA: The Prime Minister has looked closely into the circumstances surrounding my remarks including through detailed discussions with the Attorney-General and with me. Following these discussions the Prime Minister has also had a detailed letter from the Attorney-General setting out his conclusions. In order as fully as possible to inform honourable senators about the matter I take this opportunity to table the Attorney-General's report to the Prime Minister, and his reply, both of which were copied to me.

Having tabled these letters I shall not go into detail but I should mention several key points. The Attorney-General has concluded, and the Prime Minister has accepted, the following: First, in making the remarks which I did, I was totally unaware that the trial was under way in Australia. The Director of Public Prosecutions accepts that I had no knowledge of any trial prior to my remarks to the media and, indeed, that he was the first to inform me that a trial was under way several hours after my press conference when we met on a flight to Melbourne.
Second, obviously I had no intention of expressing an opinion which would lead to the aborting of a trial.

Third, what gave rise to this state of affairs were serious shortcomings in communications to me. There were various conversations involving the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions, the Australian Federal Police and my office, and conversations between my office and me, but at no stage before I spoke to the media was I informed of the crucial fact that a trial was under way.

Fourth, the Government considers it essential that we rectify these shortcomings so that no such situation arises in future. The Prime Minister has directed that a system be set in place forthwith to ensure that the Attorney-General, I and others are informed on a monthly basis of significant trials which are continuing or about to commence.

Fifth, as I said earlier, the judge in the trial has indicated that he has remanded all three of the accused in custody to face trial again when the publicity has died down. Our aim is to restore circumstances in which the trial may proceed.

The Prime Minister has weighed very carefully my error, taking into account the circumstances of a breakdown in communication with my office and between my office and me. He has also taken into account the lead role which I have played in the much enhanced collaboration between Australia and other countries in the war against drug trafficking. The matter has been thoroughly investigated and the Prime Minister's deep concern has been made very clear to me.

Senators will be aware of my strong personal and ministerial commitment to ensuring that our law enforcement agencies effectively combat the menace of drug trafficking into Australia. Honourable senators will understand my deep regret that, in pursuing this commitment, I inadvertently caused a jury to be dismissed. I am confident that the information system to be introduced at the direction of the Prime Minister will ensure that we will be even more effective in the battle to which I and the Government are committed. I tabled some correspondence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I ask a supplementary question, could that correspondence be incorporated in Hansard rather than tabled?
—I seek leave to incorporate the letters.

ANSWER.PARA: The Hon R J L Hawke, AC, MP

As I said to you when we discussed the matter, I have looked in detail at the circumstances surrounding the aborting by the Judge of a trial following the remarks made by the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Tate, to the media on 2 May 1990. I have spoken at length to Senator Tate and, of course, you and I have had the opportunity for thorough discussion with him.
I thought it appropriate that I should write to you to set out my main conclusions.
In the first place it is clear-and Senator Tate fully accepts-that the consequences of his remarks have been most unfortunate.

As you know, in granting a defence application to dismiss the jury the Judge is reported (and I am advised accurately reported) to have said, ``It is most unfortunate that the Minister for Justice made the statements attributed to him while the trial was proceeding''. He referred to his particular concern that Senator Tate had lent the authority of his office to a positive assertion that the person arrested in Thailand was guilty.

Senator Tate has assured me that he was not informed at any stage orally or in written submission that a trial was in progress. I am satisfied on this centrally important point that Senator Tate was unaware that the trial was under way. Had he been aware of this I fully accept his assurance that he would not have made the remarks he made. Obviously Senator Tate had no intention whatsoever of expressing opinions which would lead to the aborting of the trial.
In the light of this I accept that the repercussions of Senator Tate's comments, while most unfortunate, were nevertheless unforeseen by him.

What gave rise to this state of affairs were serious shortcomings in communications to Senator Tate. There were various conversations involving the office of the Director of Public Prosecutions, the Australian Federal Police and Senator Tate's office; and conversation between the latter and Senator Tate. But at no stage was Senator Tate himself informed before he spoke to the media of the crucial fact that a trial was under way.
The shortcomings in communication seem to have occurred at three separate stages.

I understand that when advised by the AFP case officer in the Sydney trial that Senator Tate intended to hold a press conference the Director of Public Prosecutions' instructing prosecutor expressed the view that the press conference should not proceed as it would prejudice the trial. This information was not conveyed to Senator Tate or his office before the press conference.

Next, an officer in the Australian Federal Police says that as far as he can recall he informed the Minister's office by telephone that there was a trial going on in Sydney and that the Minister should delete any reference to Australia or the activities of people in Australia from his press release. By implication that same advice would apply to remarks at a press conference. On the other hand, the relevant member of Senator Tate's staff says that while the AFP asked him to ensure that the Minister did not make any reference to ``the Australian connection'', there was no reference to the fact that a trial was underway in Australia.

Third, the staff member says that he informed Senator Tate of the AFP's cautioning about any reference to the Australian connection. Senator Tate recalls that he was told there was nothing to be said about any ``Australian links'' but that at no stage was he informed that a trial was in progress in Australia which might be linked to the person arrested in Thailand. The staff member informed me that he recalled, in relation to ``the Australian connection'', mentioning names to the Minister. The Minister's recollection is, however, that he was told nothing about any particular Australian end of the operation and no mention was made of the names of persons, domestic operations or trials. The staff member has indicated to me that, given the hurried circumstances of the conversation, he has no reason to question the Minister's recollection. Further, Senator Tate has informed me that he interpreted the advice not to refer to Australian links as meaning that he should not refer to particular, current police operations in Australia.

The communications were certainly not, therefore, as clear as they should have been concerning the possible implications of comments to the media at that juncture. But it is important, in terms of assessing the Minister's own conduct, that on no account of the communications which took place-that is to say Senator Tate's own account or that of his Office or indeed that of the AFP itself, which recalls making this point, but not direct to Senator Tate, only to his Office-was the Minister himself informed that there was a trial underway in Australia.

The Director of Public Prosecutions accepts that Senator Tate had no knowledge of any trial prior to his remarks to the media, and indeed was the first to inform Senator Tate that a trial was under way several hours after the press conference when they met on a flight to Melbourne.

I consider it essential that we rectify the shortcomings in communication of relevant information which existed on this occasion in order to prevent, as far as possible, any such situation recurring in the future. My Department has recommended to me that consideration should be given to the office of the DPP preparing, on a monthly basis, lists of significant trials commencing or continuing in the ensuing month. They proposed that this list should be circulated to both Ministers' offices, the Department and the AFP. I propose that we accept this recommendation. More generally I propose to bring to the attention of all involved in these matters the importance of complete and timely communication.

I have also expressed my dismay to Senator Tate that in the course of his press conference he had presumed the guilt of the person arrested in Thailand. He agrees with me that his comments were unfortunate.

The Judge has indicated that he has remanded all three of the accused in custody to face trial again when the publicity has died down. It is therefore highly desirable in terms of the administration of justice that the recent developments be put behind us as soon as possible. Our aim should be to restore circumstances in which the trial may proceed.

I have no doubt that Senator Tate's aim in speaking to the media on 2 May was to reinforce the central point of his press statement and that of the AFP that a major breakthrough had been made, through collaborative international efforts involving Australia, in the war against drugs. It is unfortunate that his concern to demonstrate the success of the efforts in Thailand led him to make remarks which led, in turn, to the aborting of the trial in Australia. But, as I have said, that result was obviously unintended and the mistake reflected in significant measure shortcomings in the chain of advice to him.
I am copying this letter to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs.
I refer to your letter of today's date following up our discussion of the circumstances surrounding the aborting of the trial in Sydney.

Having carefully considered your own conclusions as set out in that letter, and bearing in mind what the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs said in his discussions with us, I accept the position which you have put.

I wish to make very clear to you, and to Senator Tate to whom I am copying this letter, that, as I said when we discussed the matter, I agree with you that it is most regrettable that the Minister made remarks to the media which presumed the guilt of the person arrested in Thailand and also caused the Judge to conclude that he must abort the trial in Sydney. I also take the point, however, that Senator Tate was unaware of the trial underway in Australia at the time and agree that this is an important point in assessing the Minister's conduct.

I note that on no account of the advice which was given to the Minister is it contended that he was made aware of the trial. I accept that the Minister's sole intention was to draw attention to a significant accomplishment overseas, in which Australia had played a major part, in the battle against drugs.

The shortcomings in communication which led to the Minister being unaware of the trial are unacceptable and must be rectified. Your recommendation that a system be established of monthly reporting of trials is accepted and I want the system introduced forthwith.

The Australian authorities have made great progress in international collaboration to combat the trade in drugs. I am conscious that the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs has played a lead role in setting the policy framework for and encouraging this important effort. I want it to continue as a major priority of our fourth term agenda in the area of law enforcement.
I agree with your hope that the circumstances will be created in which the trial in Sydney may proceed as soon as possible.

While I emphasise again how regrettable it is that the recent situation occurred, my concern now is that we move ahead to build on the considerable achievements we have made in law enforcement, including learning the lessons of the recent incident and improving our systems of communication and the provision to Ministers of timely and relevant information.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister assure the Senate that there will be a retrial in this matter? When will it take place, and what are the costs that have been thrown away by his action?

—Obviously, it is completely outside my province to determine whether a retrial will occur. At the request of the DPP, I have specifically not mentioned any names which might identify the judge or the accused, but the judge has indicated his desire that the trial recommence when publicity about this matter had died down, and I am hopeful that honourable senators will take into account that desire on the part of the judge-that circumstances will prevail that will allow that trial to be taken up as soon as possible.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to recent declarations of independence by the Baltic states of Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia. Would the Minister outline what the Australian Government's position is in relation to those declarations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia has already recognised for many years the legal right of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia to exist as independent states. Like many other Western governments, we have refused to accept in international law their incorporation into the Soviet Union in 1940, rejecting the self-proclaimed Soviet sovereignty over them. The Government believes that the recent declarations of independence by their freely elected Parliaments do reflect the aspirations of the Baltic peoples to achieve economic and political independence through peaceful and democratic means. Equally, we do fully appreciate that it is the unprecedented process of reform in the Soviet Union which has made it possible for the newly elected Baltic parliaments to express these aspirations. We urge-I take this opportunity to do so again-the Soviet Government to respect those declarations and to refrain from actions inimical to the interests of the parties concerned.

ANSWER.PARA: The Prime Minister wrote recently to President Gorbachev in relation specifically to the Lithuanian situation in this respect. There are many complex political, legal and economic issues involved, as well as potentially serious consequences for the improving international climate, if tensions in the region escalate, and we do strongly believe that what is urgently required now is a genuine dialogue between all concerned aimed at achieving a negotiated settlement to prevent an already very delicate situation deteriorating.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to the recent hypocritical decision of the United States Administration to cite Australia as an unfair trader under Super 301 provisions of the US Trade Act. I also refer the Minister to the recent statements by Canadian Trade Minister Crosbie that if there are substantial results on major issues in the Uruguay Round negotiations of multilateral trade negotiations, a new world trade organisation should be established. First, given that the United States farm support and export subsidy policies have caused millions of dollars worth of damage to Australia's export earnings, what has been the Government's attitude and response to being cited as an unfair trader by the United States Administration? Secondly, what is the Government's attitude to the establishment of a world trade organisation along the lines suggested by Canada, and under what conditions would Australia support the establishment of such an organisation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —To some extent Senator Macklin's question is based on a false premise to the extent that the United States has not formally named Australia as an unfair trader under the so-called Super 301 provisions of the 1988 Trade Act. What has happened rather is that we have simply been mentioned in a report to Congress which the United States trade representative is required to make every year on the trading practices of its major trading partners. The purpose of that report is to assist United States trade negotiators to identify trade negotiating objectives. The section on Australia does cite our tariff regime, customs evaluation practices, export incentive scheme, government procurement program and various local content schemes. In most instances the report simply notes those aspects of our trading regime and notes further that the United States trade representative intends pursuing its negotiating objectives in relation to these matters in the context of the Uruguay Round of multilateral trade negotiations.

ANSWER.PARA: All that said, we are not especially enthused at this demonstration of high moral tone in relation to our practices against a background where some trading practices of the United States are unquestionably unfair, especially in agricultural trade. The export enhancement program, as we have debated on many occasions in this place, is one of the most trade distorting measures it is possible to construct, and Australia has repeatedly asked the United States to abolish such programs in the interests of freer world trade. It is also worth making the point in the context of our bilateral relationship that the United States continues to enjoy enormous trading opportunities in Australia. It does have a 2:1 surplus with us and this is the second largest surplus that the United States has with any country in the world.

So far as the latter part of the question, relating to the world trade organisation, is concerned, it is the case that at a recent trade Ministers meeting in Mexico attended by my colleague Dr Blewett, the Canadian Minister, Mr Crosbie, announced the intention to circulate a proposal to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade in July aimed at establishing GATT as a fully fledged international organisation using the concept `World Trading Organisation' at the conclusion of the Uruguay Round, the idea being to have all the agreements under one roof and to provide a strong, effective dispute settlement institution.

Canada's proposal is based on the fact that the Uruguay Round is the most complex and comprehensive round of negotiations in GATT's 40-year history. In addition to market access and agriculture, it covers-as we should know by now-the development of new international rules on trade and services, trade related intellectual property rights and investment measures, and updating codes from the Tokyo Round. The comprehensive result that we all hope will emerge from the round does raise significant institutional questions about how all the new agreements will link together and how a common dispute settlement process will work.

The bottom line is this: it is our view-generally shared by the trade Ministers at the Mexico meeting-that the idea put forward by Mr Crosbie should certainly not be dismissed. However, the shape of the Uruguay Round outcome will strongly influence institutional arrangements, so we do need to focus on the substantive outcome first before we get too obsessed with institutional structures. Institutional issues such as a world trade organisation should not detract in any way from that substantive negotiating process, and in particular should not be perceived as some alternative result to it-which might just conceivably be something in the back of the minds of the Canadians.

We should also bear in mind that the original attempt to establish an international trade organisation in 1947 did founder due to resistance from national legislatures such as the US Congress. So we need to adopt, as always in these matters, a very healthy sense of realism about its prospects for implementation, even if we do ultimately think at the end of the round it is a good idea.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL SECURITY: MAINFRAME COMPUTER SERVICE CENTRE

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Social Security to the decision of the Department of Social Security to locate the mainframe computer service centre for Victoria, South Australia and Tasmania in Melbourne. I also remind the Minister that he had indicated that when he came back from leave he would have a look at the matter and decide the issue. I simply ask: Will the mainframe computer service centre be located in Melbourne or, as we and indeed the Tasmanian Government believe would be more appropriate, in Hobart?

—As Senator Harradine would know, the Department decided some time ago to reduce the number of mainframes from seven to four and that involves the closure of a number of mainframes, including Hobart. I indicated that I would certainly accept the other closures going ahead but that I would review Hobart because there may well be an argument that in that city there are not so many employment opportunities for those who may be displaced. Of course, also there is a genuine feeling amongst Tasmanians that perhaps the Commonwealth has not provided enough employment to them, even on a pro rata basis, compared with other States.
—Hear, hear! A very clearly demonstrated argument.

—I might say to Senator Newman that all on this side of the House, as well as Senator Harradine, have raised it with me. Senator Newman has been as usual particularly silent on something affecting her home State. Nonetheless I will hold meetings with the unions and with my department tomorrow in an attempt to finalise the issue. I hope to be able to tell Senator Harradine on Friday exactly what we are going to do. Unfortunately tomorrow morning I have to go to Melbourne, so the meeting cannot be held until tomorrow afternoon after questions and I will not be able to tell Senator Harradine the resolution until Friday.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the disastrous flood that devastated the towns of Charleville, Augathella, Jericho, Alpha and Blackall nearly three weeks ago. In view of the Queensland State Government preliminary estimates of damage running into over $100m for housing, business, infrastructure, stock, machinery and fencing, can the Minister advise the Senate what Federal financial assistance will be given to the victims of the flood? If the assistance package has not been worked out by the Government can the Minister advise when the Federal Government will announce its disaster relief arrangements so that western Queensland flood victims can assess their economic future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate Senator Boswell's concern about the damage which has been done both to infrastructure and people particularly in towns in Queensland as a result of the floods. The position is generally that the States within broad guidelines and with the agreement of the Commonwealth decide how generous disaster relief packages should be. The Government is committed to providing the full extent of assistance under the national disaster relief arrangements to the people of Nyngan, Charleville and other centres affected by the flooding.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth Government has given a quarter of a million dollars to each of the public appeals for flood victims as a donor in Queensland and New South Wales and will be contributing more through tax deductability of other donations to these funds. I should say that the natural disaster relief arrangements with the States have worked very effectively since they were introduced in 1978, are very much a collaborative effort between State and Commonwealth governments, and are updated following consultation with the States each year.

I remind the honourable senator of what the basic principles of those arrangements are. The Commonwealth reimburses the States for at least 50 per cent of State outlays on personal hardship and distress; $1 of every $2 announced by each State in this area comes from the Commonwealth.

Secondly, in relation to other relief measures and restoration of homes, businesses and public assets to which Senator Boswell referred, I point out that a basic amount of disaster relief has to be spent by the States each year and after that amount is spent-and in the normal course of events it usually is-the Commonwealth then reimburses the States, first on a dollar for dollar basis, and then with three Commonwealth dollars for every State dollar.

They are the guidelines for administration of disaster relief schemes and I think they are arrangements which worked effectively in the case of Cyclone Winifred, the Ash Wednesday bushfires and other disasters and we believe they will work effectively again in this case but, as I make clear, it is a matter of consultation between State and Federal governments on the total amount spent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the Minister advise whether the Queensland Government has submitted a full and detailed report to the Federal Government on the flood damage to allow it to assess the disaster relief plan?

—I am not sure about that. I think the answer is no. There have been ongoing discussions between the Commonwealth and the Queensland Government, but I think it may be a little early for the Queensland Government to be in a position to totally assess that amount. But if there is any more information I can supply after consultation with the appropriate Minister, I will do so.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of three former distinguished senators-Reg Bishop, Colin Mason and Jack Evans. On behalf of all senators I welcome them to Canberra and I hope that the meeting that I know they are here to attend is a great success.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CONVENTION ON THE RIGHTS OF THE CHILD

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Attorney-General a question about the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. I understand that 84 countries have already signed the convention and its signing by Australia is strongly supported by many community groups. Can the Minister indicate how much longer it will be before Australia signs this convention?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, it is true that the Convention on the Rights of the Child was considered and adopted at the forty-fourth session of the United Nations General Assembly meeting in New York on 20 November 1989, and it was open for signature on 26 January 1990. Australia has not signed the convention as yet. Becoming a party to the convention is a two-stage process-first signature, and later ratification. Senator Coates would remember that signature to the convention does not make a country a party to the convention but signifies simply that the country will refrain from acts which would defeat the object and purpose of the convention until it is ratified or has made its intention clear not to ratify. The second stage is ratification, whereby a country becomes a party to the convention and is bound by it.

ANSWER.PARA: Many of the matters dealt with in the convention concern areas traditionally dealt with by the States and Territories. The Government has begun consultations with the State and Territory governments with a view to establishing whether Australian laws and practices are consistent with requirements of the convention. State and Territory governments were kept advised of developments during the drafting of the convention of the United Nations and are being consulted on the question of signature and ratification. It is true, as Senator Coates has indicated, that many community organisations have indicated their support for Australia's ratification following signature of the convention, and of course most recently Sir Ronald Wilson, a former justice of the High Court of Australia and the new President of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, speaking at a function organised by the Uniting Church of Australia, indicated his strong support for that particular convention and that course of action being undertaken by the Government. I understand that the Australian Episcopal Conference of the Roman Catholic Church has also indicated its support for the convention following the Vatican's accession to the convention.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister whether he would urge the Attorney-General to expedite the necessary consultations with the States so that Australia is not seen to be dragging its feet on this convention.

—I would imagine that given the very considerable role which Australia played in the drafting of this convention, particularly in the insertion of those articles which protect and recognise the important role of the family in relation to the protection of children's rights, the Government will be anxious to conclude the very necessary consultations with the States and Territories as speedily as possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and Minister representing the Treasurer. I ask the Minister: Firstly, to what extent does the present wholesale sales tax system represent a tax on exports; and, secondly, is this matter being examined in the review of the broad-based consumption tax presently being undertaken within the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce?

—There are different views, in answer to the first part of the question. For example, the review conducted by Professor Hughes of the export market development grants scheme estimated that the burden of the current indirect tax system on exporters of goods and services was something in the order of 6 per cent of export revenue. That figure, as I recall it in Professor Hughes's report, was based on 1982-83 figures, so it was a fairly old calculation, having regard to the broadening of the indirect tax base during the period of this Government.
—It is much higher now.

—There are differences of views about that. That would seem to be a likely conclusion, but I think there are differences of views about it because of the impact of various indirect taxes other than the wholesale tax itself. In so far as the second part of the question is concerned, my Department-I assume-has been looking at aspects of a broadly based consumption tax or value added tax, as other departments have. Departments do that as a matter of course if there is a public debate about an issue such as this, as there has been, and a lot of comment has been made in the newspapers and elsewhere. Might I say that I believe that the particular concerns of the Department, as do mine, go to the first part of the question that was asked of me, and whether there is something which can be done to alleviate any further burden on exporters. The Treasurer, in the statement which he made today at the National Press Club, specifically referred to that issue as one which was receiving further examination by the Government, one which has been dealt with in part by the extension of the aids to manufacturing concessions last year, but which is subject to further review by the Government at present.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I thank the Minister for that answer. As I got it in relation to the work that may be being done within his own Department, he said he assumed that the Department was looking at these matters. I ask him whether he will confirm that that is the case and will he provide the Senate with the details of the review more specifically that the Department is undertaking into this matter.

—I do not know whether I used the word `assume' in relation to the Department but I know that from time to time sections of my Department, as do sections of a number of other departments, look at these issues which are the subject of public debate, particularly amongst economic writers in the press, and that they have their own views about them. I know that that has happened within my own Department. I think I used the word `assume' in talking particularly about the question of the effects on exporters of the existing wholesale tax regime. Certainly, as I said, that has been a matter of major concern and now, following the statement made by the Treasurer today, my Department will be collaborating in looking at that particular question.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SALE OF MIRAGE AIRCRAFT TO PAKISTAN

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence and concerns the sale of the old Royal Australian Air Force Mirage aircraft to Pakistan announced by the Minister last month. Firstly, I ask the Minister why the package cost Pakistan only $36m, when the Minister's predecessor originally stated in 1989 that he was hoping to get $100m for the deal? Secondly, in the light of the sale of the Mirages to Pakistan, and the $5m contract for Redeco to work with the Dutch consortium, Nedeco, to design India's new naval base near Goa, I ask the Minister: what controls now exist on arms transfers and other military contracts, given that such sales to countries at odds with each other for over 40 years are hardly compatible with our international responsibility to act to reduce tensions in the region? Finally, I ask the Minister whether there was a difference over the Mirage sale with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. Can the Minister say what would be the point of a review of the sale if, once the Mirages had gone to Pakistan, they were then used in a conflict with India over Kashmir or over any other issue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The $36m was the best price my Department could negotiate for the sale of the obsolescent Mirage aircraft package. The package was first placed for disposal by international tender in August 1988 and negotiations began that year. Differences between earlier estimates and the sale price achieved must be considered in light of the availability of surplus military hardware flowing from the events in Europe. Concerning the question of what controls exist on the export of defence goods to overseas countries, I refer the honourable senator to guidelines for exporters, Australian Controls of Export and Defence Related Goods, published in July 1989.

ANSWER.PARA: The current level of tension between India and Pakistan is clearly a matter of concern to Australia, which enjoys friendly relations with both countries. We certainly hope that these tensions will reduce in the future. I note the recent favourable developments associated with the meeting between respective foreign ministries between those countries, which occurred late last month in the United States.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Department of Defence liaise closely on policy concerning defence exports. The sale of the Mirage aircraft was in accordance with Government policy and implemented by both Departments in accordance with that policy. Once the Mirage aircraft are delivered to Pakistan the Government of Pakistan will determine how they are used.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to his visit to Papua New Guinea (PNG) two weeks ago. How did it come about that, on the same day as the Minister was holding a press conference on arrival in Port Moresby to express his dissatisfaction with Papua New Guinea's economic performance, the Australian Government's confidential submission to the International Monetary Fund (IMF) was endorsing Papua New Guinea's `exemplary' economic strategy? Was Senator Evans's insulting conduct towards Prime Minister Namaliu and the Papua New Guinea Government deliberate or the result of unintended incompetence? Given Foreign Minister Somare's pungent rebuke yesterday-that Australia keep its nose out of Papua New Guinea's internal affairs-what chance of success has the Prime Minister's forthcoming visit to repair the damage?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first point to make is that the original question is based on a false premise. I did not at any time, on arrival or in any subsequent statement, criticise Papua New Guinea for not doing more to cut government expenditure, nor did I at any stage cast any aspersions on the scope of the structural adjustment that Papua New Guinea was attempting-the package that it had proposed to the World Bank. What I did say on arrival was this-and I quote from the transcript, which is readily available if honourable senators would like to see it:

ANSWER.PARA: I see this visit as an opportunity to get a first hand assessment and update on a number of problems facing Papua New Guinea at the moment and how those problems are being tackled. However sympathetic we may be-and we are very sympathetic to the continuing difficulties that you are facing-we simply can't solve Papua New Guinea's problems for Papua New Guinea . . . We will be looking to evidence of your commitment and the effectiveness with which that's being done.

I did, in other words, make the point that formulating a policy response, as appropriate as that policy response may be, is not in itself sufficient. Those policies have to be implemented effectively, and in Papua New Guinea's case in current circumstances that will require a sustained political commitment. So my comments were directed at the need for a sustained commitment and, above all else, effective implementation-and I make no apology for putting the proposition in those terms.

As to Mr Namaliu's reported response to my public statement in question, the circumstances were as follows: the following day after my arrival, questions were put to Prime Minister Namaliu at a press conference-which did convey the impression which Senator Hill, in his press release earlier on, and now Senator Teague have obviously also gleaned from press reports-which conveyed the impression that I had said on my arrival, before meeting any Ministers, that PNG's current budgetary belt-tightening efforts were insufficient, and Australia, moreover, was not prepared in any way to offer extra assistance at this time.

Not altogether surprisingly, Prime Minister Namaliu was a little wounded by this, not least because he had been occupied for some weeks previously with a very difficult and sensitive razor gang exercise which had produced what I readily acknowledge was a very impressive budget cutting and structural adjustment program, and was so regarded by the International Monetary Fund, our delegate there, and so on. He did say that he was disappointed and, perhaps to some extent, offended with these remarks which he believed I had made-but I had not-before I had talked to anyone. In fact, as I have already said, I did not make my comment in those terms. I have described the comments I did make. The whole thing generated a quite excited media response, particularly here. It generated quite an excited political response, too. When I met Mr Namaliu for a final meeting just before my departure, the misunderstanding about what I said was fully explained to him. I showed him the transcripts of the press conferences in question, and we parted on wholly amicable terms.

The final part of the question concerned Mr Somare, who expressed his upset a couple of days ago in relation to a report carried in the Canberra Times last Friday which drew upon the remarks of a departmental spokesman about our attitude to Papua New Guinea's declaration of a 50-nautical mile exclusion zone around Bougainville. The remarks of that spokesman and, indeed, the remarks I made myself in a doorstop interview that day, did reflect serious concern at the implications for Australia of that declaration which was made early last week. They also repeated concerns which I had expressed to Papua New Guinea Ministers during my visit a week earlier when I was assured that such a declaration, while it had been considered, would not be made. I have already made this point in answer to Senator Hill at the beginning of Question Time.

In his press release, Mr Somare suggested that Australia's interest in this proposed total exclusion zone amounted to interference in Papua New Guinea's internal affairs. I think the following points need to be appreciated: the Australian response that I was making did not relate to the current restrictive arrangements about a 12-nautical mile zone, which do not involve any international shipping lanes. I made it clear in Papua New Guinea, as I have made it clear subsequently, and again in Question Time today, that any decision about the application of a blockade in this area is wholly a PNG affair. Of course, the purported declaration of a 50-nautical mile exclusion zone is not, in any view, simply an internal affair for the country concerned; it is an action which can profoundly affect the interests of other countries. The notice to aviators and mariners that was issued on 2 May warned, after all, that unauthorised vessels sighted within the zone would be fired on without warning by PNG patrol boats. The exclusion zone was also defined as including air space up to 20,000 feet.

While no commercial aircraft fly directly over that route, there are certainly Australian ships that pass regularly through the passage between Buka and New Ireland. To the best of our knowledge about eight Australian flag vessels per month transit that passage, while the total number of commercial traffic could be as high as one per day. So it was in that context that I instructed our High Commissioner in Port Moresby to make our rather well-founded concerns known to the Papua New Guinea Government. And it was in those terms that I responded to press inquiries on the subject. I notice that Papua New Guinea has now rescinded notification of the proposed 50 nautical miles total exclusion zone. Mr Diro has said that he was obliged to acknowledge on the part of the Papua New Guinea Government that declaration of such a zone would be a violation of international law. He also acknowledged that it was the product of an internal communications failure. His Government accepted responsibility for the confusion in question.

Let me say finally, in response to this whole affair, that I would hope that my respect for the sovereignty and independence of other countries is well established. In the case of the South Pacific it is at the heart of the policy of `constructive commitment' which defines our approach to the region. Respect for each other's sovereignty is also, as Mr Somare pointed out, at the heart of the Joint Declaration of Principles which this Government concluded with Papua New Guinea in 1987. It is not my practice to comment gratuitously on the affairs of other countries, but when other governments take decisions which affect Australian interests, I am required to make our interests clear. It is my role as Foreign Minister to do so. I did so in a comparable situation last year, when Indonesia temporarily closed the strait between Lombok and Sunda. I can assure the Senate, without any apology whatsoever, I will do so again with any country in the region if the circumstances require it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I see the brief answer is `unintended incompetence'. Will the Minister now table the transcript of his remarks? I have yet to see Senator Evans stick to his scripted remarks in any such press conference. Would he also refer to the two parts of my question on which he has not touched at all-firstly, the IMF submission, in which the Australian Government expressed the view that the economy was exemplary; and, secondly, the Prime Minister's forthcoming repair visit?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to respond to Senator Teague's provocations in this respect, except to say that I did refer to the IMF response, if he is talking about the Executive Director, Ted Evans-who, incidentally, represents a constituency not confined to Australia but including Papua New Guinea as well. He certainly commented favourably on the structural adjustment package that PNG put together. I commented favourably on it when I was there and before I went there, and have also done so since I have come back. Obviously Senator Teague was not listening to the answer I gave. I did not say anything adverse about it at any stage and, therefore, there is no inconsistency whatsoever between the respective favourable comments that I made and those that Mr Ted Evans made. So there is no substance whatsoever to that question.

ANSWER.PARA: I have not got the document here with me, but I am certainly happy to table at the appropriate time the transcript of that opening press conference so that Senator Teague can see it for himself. I am also happy to table at the same time the transcript of Prime Minister Namaliu's press conference so that Senator Teague can see for himself the context in which Prime Minister Namaliu made the remarks that he did. Beyond that, I have nothing further to add.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support advise us of the current status of development of an airport facility at Badgerys Creek?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I answer Senator Aulich's question, I wonder whether I could extend a sincere welcome to Senator O'Chee in his first hour in the Senate. I was looking across the chamber and thinking of a conversation I had with Senator Bjelke-Petersen the other day when she mentioned the comments made about the old fogeys in the National Party in respect of Senator O'Chee's preselection and thinking that, by comparison, the juxtaposition of Senator McGauran and Senator O'Chee made them look like Ernie and Bert from Sesame Street.
—Order! Senator Collins, this is a rather unusual answer to a question.
—I am a rather unusual Minister.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I defer in part to Senator Collins's greater knowledge and the undoubtedly great benefit that he derives from watching children's television; nevertheless, to make those sorts of reflections is, I think, technically disorderly. If Senator Collins wishes to elevate himself or be elevated by prime ministerial fiat from the back bench to the front bench, one of the things that, presumably, is incumbent upon him is to answer the question that he is asked, to behave himself as befits the dignity of a Minister and to stop making reflections of that sort on honourable senators. As one who has complained about the problems of size, he has now got into the problem of making reflections on persons' ages, and I think it is the sort of thing he ought to withdraw. If Senator Collins now wants to be a member, as he is indeed now a member, of the front bench, he will be kept to what we regard as being reasonable standards, and I ask you, Mr President, to make him withdraw those remarks.
—Order! It was not unparliamentary, but I have reminded Senator Collins to answer the question.
—Mr President, I assume that was Senator Puplick's last hurrah-it certainly will be by 5 o'clock this afternoon.
—Order! Just answer the question.
—I am pleased to advise the Senate that there has been some progress with the question of Badgerys Creek.

—I will get on to that in a minute. The Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) has accepted the Civil Aviation Authority's commission, to carry out preliminary design work for the construction of a general aviation airport facility to be completed at Badgerys Creek by 1992. The phased development of Badgerys Creek airport is an integral component of a comprehensive set of measures which contains a commitment by the Government to construct a third runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, subject only to the completion of an environmental impact statement.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition to the preliminary design work for the general aviation facility the FAC will also undertake initial design work at Badgerys Creek for facilities to cater for domestic and international flights in later stages of development. I point out to the Senate again that a whole range of measures is necessary to ease the congestion at Australia's major airport. These include Badgerys Creek, the construction of the third runway and the introduction of a number of other measures which may even include peak period pricing at Sydney Airport.

I expect that the FAC will soon announce the names of some of Australia's foremost engineering organisations that will take part in this initial design project, which is due for completion in November this year. Building work for the construction of the general aviation facility will commence as soon as possible after the necessary design work has been undertaken.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister to table the enormous notes from which he read the entire answer.
—The Minister does not have to table speech notes.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. How long has the Government been aware of significant amounts of asbestos present at the Gowrie Hostel at Braddon? Was the presence of asbestos a major factor in the decision of the Government to sell the hostel and how much would it cost to remove the asbestos? Is there a similar problem at the Macquarie Hostel in Barton?

—I have not been in the portfolio for a few weeks but at the time that I left it I was not aware of these asbestos problems. I am not sure what may have been discovered since but I shall find out and make sure I can answer those questions tomorrow.

—Does the Minister for Social Security agree with the President of the Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS), Merle Mitchell, that the new provision of the Social Security Act which suspends unemployment benefits for 12 weeks if people are deemed to have reduced their job prospects by moving to another area is `ill conceived and unworkable, unfair and causing a great deal of hardship'. Is the Minister concerned that this provision, which I remind him was opposed by the Australian Democrats last December when it was introduced, is an effective reversal of the onus of proof for the unemployed given that over 75 per cent of the appeals against the removal of unemployment benefits so far have been upheld? In view of the increasing unemployment which we are now experiencing as a result of the Government's economic policy and anticipated by the Minister himself in today's Melbourne Age will the Minister commit the Government to removal of this provision to ensure that the injustice does not escalate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not agree with the assessment from ACOSS that this is ill-conceived, unworkable unfair and causing a great deal of hardship. Certainly some hundreds of people are affected by the decision. That is for certain. But I think if we are going to be serious about the policy of encouraging those on unemployment benefits or receiving Newstart or a Job search allowance to get into the work force we must maintain the integrity of the work test. It is very difficult to do that if we allow benefit recipients to move into areas where the chances of getting a job are greatly minimised, and in some cases completely nullified. The real test is how you work back from there to protect the integrity of the test without unduly causing hardship to those who are most in need. I believe that the decision was the correct one, but I believe that there have been some mistakes and inadequacies in its implementation. In the State of Victoria in particular, there was a problem concerning those who were offered Housing Commission homes in an area with less employment prospects, and there was the possibility then that if one did not accept that offer of housing, one would lose one's place on the list. That has been sorted out with the Victorian Housing Commission and it is no longer the case. All unemployment benefit recipients, all those receiving Newstart and Job search allowance, if they are in that situation and they decline the offer of housing, will not lose their place on the list. Other States are being approached. We believe there will not be any problem with that situation pertaining all round the country. We can get around that particular difficulty which was struck in Victoria.

ANSWER.PARA: There is also the problem of how one equates the employment prospects of individuals with the employment prospects generally in an area. That is where quite a number of mistakes have been made, and I readily acknowledge that fact. That has resulted in some discussions between my Department and the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES), whose job it is to make those assessments, and we will ensure that those problems do not occur in the future. Again, I believe we can solve that problem.

However, there is a third problem to which there is no solution under the Act, and I intend to approach the Government in the next few days to ascertain whether I can have an extra amendment added to the legislation which will be before the Senate in the next couple of weeks. That concerns those who move for medical reasons. At the moment, there is no scope for adjustment for those families who may move because perhaps a child is suffering from asthma or something like that in a particular area and they want to go somewhere else. I will approach the Government on that score and, hopefully, I will have some success. I do not believe that it is effectively a reversal of the onus of proof. It obviously is an extra test for people but, then again, if one wishes to maintain the integrity of the work test-and I believe that is necessary-I think we need to go along this route.

There may be some increase in unemployment this year, but as the Prime Minister repeated today, he and the Government do not believe that we will be in a recession or see any massive increase, so I am not of the view that this injustice, as the honourable senator put it, will escalate. Rather, I think that, by the measures we have taken in the course of the past few days, we can ensure that we will minimise any inconvenience or injustice in the future.

It is quite true to say that the rate of appeals being upheld in cases in this instance is greater by a factor of three than the average of appeals that are upheld generally through the system. I think that is primarily for the reasons I have outlined today. I believe we have taken steps to ensure that that will not occur again. I think honourable senators will see over the course of the next few months the appeal success rates of these matters going back to the same level as occurs across the Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. With reference to housing, the Minister has assured the Senate that in terms of public housing, action can be taken. Given the effective reduction in public housing and the long waiting lists, many low income people are forced into the private rental market, and, as we know, rentals are often lower in areas of higher unemployment. Can the Minister assure me that we will not continue to strike this problem with this particular provision in the area of private rental, or, failing that, that he will at least look into it seriously?

—I think I indicated today in the article to which Senator Powell referred earlier that I was looking generally at the question of the private rental market because I believe there are serious problems there, but I do not believe they outweigh the general policy concern of the Government to ensure that people who are on unemployment benefits so far as possible get back into the work force. While rents may be lower, people will still be at far greater disadvantage if they remain on unemployment benefits and simply move to an area to get a lower rent but where there is no possibility of getting a job. So, I do not see it outweighing our main concern, but I acknowledge that it is a concern, and it is something that I will keep under constant review.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier in Question Time today, Senator Boswell asked me a question about flood relief in Queensland. He asked me what approach the Queensland Government had made to the Commonwealth Government and I said that I thought that approach had yet to be finalised.

ANSWER.PARA: I do understand as a result of inquiries made during Question Time that Queensland has provided details to the Department of Finance of special measures instituted for personal hardship and distress. I think Senator Boswell should view that in the light of my earlier answer. It is my understanding that the two States affected, New South Wales and Queensland, will shortly write to the Minister for Finance seeking agreement to these and other special measures proposed. In relation to personal hardship and distress, preliminary figures have been provided and we are expecting a formal application shortly from both States.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to ask a question of you relating to a matter of the administration and practice of the Senate.

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that many persons regard tradition as something to be largely disregarded and that there is always an argument about appropriate standards of conduct, dress and behaviour.

QUESTION.PARA: The matter I wish to raise, which undoubtedly some people will find trivial, is in our view a matter of some principle. It relates to the attire worn by officers of the Senate and, in particular, the gentleman Usher of the Black Rod. The office of Black Rod is, of course, a very old and distinguished one going back many centuries. It has been part and parcel of tradition and the way in which the Senate conducts its business. The officer who is sent as the formal messenger between this chamber and the House of Representatives has served in the House of Lords in a particular fashion. Much as it may be a matter of some curiosity, the Usher of the Black Rod has dressed in a particular fashion. On ceremonial occasions such as yesterday he not only carries the staff of office which he has, but he wears black gloves, a sword and all of the other accoutrements and trappings of that office.

Normally a gentleman Usher of the Black Rod-or Black Rod, as we refer to the office in this place-wears lace. It is a matter of some curiosity, I suppose, but indeed it is part and parcel of a parliamentary tradition. Yesterday when the members of the House of Representatives were summoned here all honourable senators would have noticed the House of Representatives Clerks and senior officers seated at the table in the centre of the chamber and the Serjeant-at-Arms. They were wearing lace, and in that respect they were more splendidly attired than our distinguished officers. Although it is a matter entirely for Their Honours, we also noticed yesterday that the lady and gentlemen of the High Court were not in the traditional robes which judges of the High Court, with the exception of the late Mr Justice Murphy, have traditionally worn when presenting themselves in the chamber for significant ceremonial occasions.

We believe that in relation to Senate officers the matter of attire is not a matter simply of personal discretion but is a matter of the view of the chamber. It may well be the view of the chamber that they should wear cutaway jeans and T-shirts, in which case they will be perfectly entitled to wear cutaway jeans and T-shirts.

On the last occasion that some of these matters were raised-I look to the comments made on page 150 and 151 of the fifth edition of Odgers' Australian Senate Practice-the House Committee reported to the Senate about certain matters of dress.

The Committee reported that there were certain standards of dress which were regarded as appropriate and not appropriate, not in accordance with the dignity of the Senate. Indeed the Senate adopted the House Committee report when it was brought before it.

I well remember that similar actions were taken when an adviser to a Minister seated himself on the official adviser benches dressed in a poloneck pullover and jeans and the President of the time ruled that that was inappropriate dress and that officers were also to be properly dressed when they entered the chamber.

Mr President, I remember when the question of dress was raised many years ago with one of your distinguished predecessors, Sir Magnus Cormack, Sir Magnus simply replied, if my Latin serves me correctly, `de gustibus non est disputandum'-good taste is not a matter of debate. It does seem to me that while the officers have their own individual rights and can conduct themselves in a fashion which they think appropriate, where there are significant departures from the tradition of the Senate we on this side are concerned with the form and tradition and the standing of this Parliament. Over the years an attempt has been studiously and deliberately made as a matter of policy to denigrate the traditions, behaviour, standards and the way in which the parliamentary institution is conducted, but those matters do not go without our noticing them; they do not go without our remarking upon them.

I appreciate that it may well be that you, Mr President, as the presiding officer, have no specific jurisdiction in the matter or indeed that decisions have been made which may be entirely personal decisions made by the officers concerned in exactly the same way as the question of whether the President should be gowned and wigged is one which is entirely in the hands of the presiding officer of the day.

I simply wish to raise with you, Sir, the fact that there are a number of members of the Opposition who believe that the traditions of this Parliament are enhanced by certain things and are detracted from by certain things. When changes are made we as the members of the chamber are entitled to be consulted about them and to express an opinion. I express an opinion ex post facto on this matter, which I know is shared by colleagues on this side of the chamber. I say to you, Mr President: we regret it if a decision has been made to depart from a tradition of centuries in Westminster parliaments and almost a century in the Commonwealth Parliament and that none of us has been consulted. A very large number of us believe that the maintenance of even small courtesies, of even small symbolic indications of the particular position of senior officers of the Senate, of senior servants of the Parliament, is to be set at nought simply on a personal whim.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Puplick began by seeking leave to ask a question, Mr President. I must say I just hope this is not the shape of things to come in terms of questions directed either to Ministers or you, Mr President. I have no comment to make on the substance of the matter because I agree with Senator Puplick's opening remark about it.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Puplick raised this matter with me during Question Time today so I have not had a lot of time to make inquiries, but I have been informed that the Senate officers themselves decided to make some minor modifications to their chamber dress for the sake of convenience and that on ceremonial occasions the full dress will be worn. I believe it was a personal decision.

INTERJECT.PARA: It is not the first time there have been changes made. Honourable senators will probably recall that the jabot has not been worn by Senate officers now for some time. It is no decision of mine. I do not regard the changes, however, as major, but I will discuss the issue with the officers and I will get back and discuss the issue with Senator Puplick and members of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate, mindful that the people of Australia are the inheritors and custodians of the ANZAC tradition
(1) recalls that-
(a) from the deeds and sacrifices of the ANZACs at Gallipoli there emerged a powerful sense of an Australian national identity;
(b) the spirit of ANZAC was sustained and strengthened by more than 300,000 Australians who served overseas during World War I;

(c) despite the military failure of the Gallipoli campaign the ANZACs forged an unsurpassed reputation for bravery, endurance, resourcefulness, irrepressible humour under pressure and, above all, loyalty to one another;
(d) the experiences shared at Gallipoli helped forge the basis of a continuing close relationship with New Zealand;
(2) recognises that-
(a) the commemoration of ANZAC provides a continuing source of inspiration for all Australians

(b) the example of the ANZACs has been emulated many times, in war and in peace, by individuals and communities coping with natural disasters, tragedies of all kinds and, indeed, the challenges of every day life;

(c) the overwhelming response in the community to the commemorations to mark the 75th anniversary of the landing at Gallipoli expresses a spirit of national commitment central to the continuing relevance of ANZAC;

(d) the sacrifices-first at Gallipoli and then in all other theatres of war in which Australians have served in two World Wars, Korea, Malaya and Vietnam-emphasises the tragedy and futility of war, and the need to re-dedicate ourselves to the cause of world peace;
and,
