(3) noting the unprecedented nature of the pilgrimage to Gallipoli for the 75th Anniversary of ANZAC Day by veterans, war widows and junior Legatees, expresses its deep gratitude to all those involved in the success of that pilgrimage, including the Departmental officials and all others responsible for the planning and organisation, the personnel of the Australian Defence Force, the Returned Servicemen's League of Australia, QANTAS, and, in particular, the carers who played such a large part in ensuring the health and well-being of the veterans during the pilgrimage and their safe return home to Australia; and

(4) also expresses its deep gratitude to the Government and people of Turkey for their recognition of the importance of ANZAC to Australians and for their generous assistance to the 75th anniversary commemoration and pilgrimage.
Mr Deputy President, I regard the terms of the motion as self-explanatory and I have nothing further to add.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition of course supports the motion and I will speak only briefly to it. The recent seventy-fifth anniversary of the Australian landing at Gallipoli was one of those special moments in the history of our country. It was an occasion in which political differences were put aside and the leaders of the three major parties were joined in unity of purpose at Anzac Cove.

SPEECH.PARA: For those who were there and for those who participated in services throughout Australia the personal sacrifice of our original Diggers was commemorated. In a larger sense, however, the occasion gave us all pause to reflect on our national identity. We all shared the pride of our veterans returning to the site of that original landing-pride at their bearing, their grace and their humour. Watching them during their second odyssey to Turkey, we were reminded that these men and women are a living embodiment of the history of our nation.

Despite the campaign's failure, Gallipoli was a human triumph-a triumph of bravery, tenacity and courage. As Charles Bean, the official historian, wrote, it demonstrated `an endurance which will never own defeat'. It was at Gallipoli that the term `Anzac' acquired its heroic aura. It was from Gallipoli that names like Monash, Bridges, Simpson, Lone Pine and Quinns Post became household words. The qualities of courage, endurance in adversity, daring in attack and mateship that the Australian forces so consistently showed set a standard for our services in the first and second world wars and subsequent conflicts.
Those Anzac qualities of resilience, initiative and mutual care are needed as much today as before-as much in times of peace as in war. As my Leader Dr Hewson said at the Lone Pine service:

We now have a responsibility to live up to the example of courage and patriotism that they set. We have a special responsibility to build an Australia worthy of the ideals for which they fought . . . A nation we will be proud of and the world will respect.

Our commemorations were not just of the horrors of war but also of the hope that springs in the human spirit, and of the spirit of reconciliation that is now demonstrated in the relations between Turkey and her former adversaries. I congratulate the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) and his Department, which had the prime responsibility for coordinating the Gallipoli 1990 project.

I know that the steering committee which had charge of the organisation had representatives from the Australian War Memorial, the Returned Services League, the World War I Veterans' Association and the departments of Foreign Affairs and Trade, Prime Minister and Cabinet, and Defence. I also pay tribute to the Gallipoli task force in the Department of Veterans' Affairs which supported that committee.

I would also like to take this opportunity to congratulate the 26-person carer group which the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) mentioned, which provided superb care of our veterans on their arduous journey. I of course include the work of those from the Lady Davidson Repatriation Hospital who had the care of the veterans both before and after the trip.

On behalf of the coalition, I pay tribute to the work of the three arms of the Defence Force and the crews of HMAS Sydney and HMAS Tobruk who took part in the Gallipoli ceremonies. Finally, I pay particular tribute to Mr Bill Hall, patron of the World War I Veterans' Association, for conceiving the idea behind the Gallipoli 1990 pilgrimage and his inspiring work in seeing it through to completion. In paying homage to our fallen at Gallipoli, to their comrades and survivors, we rekindle a faith in our future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the National Party of Australia I too would like to support the motion that has been brought before the Senate today by Senator Button. I felt a great deal of pride when I watched the media and saw those 57 old Diggers over there in a foreign land representing Australia, and I thought they did it magnificently well. I congratulate them for the spirit that they showed. It must have been very difficult for them at their age to fly halfway around the world and to be moved in different ways-in buses, walking and so forth all round the areas of battle such as Lone Pine. I think they did an absolutely magnificent job.

SPEECH.PARA: I congratulate the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) also. I think it was a wonderful way to celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of Anzac. It was innovative and it was splendid. The fact that these people went over there had some other spin-offs. As I attended my local Anzac Day ceremonies I noticed that a vastly increased number of Australians have become aware of Anzac Day and attended the various services throughout the land. I believe record crowds were in attendance at the major marches in all capital cities. So I believe that the 57 veterans, the eight war widows and eight delegates who went to Turkey to revisit the site of the Gallipoli campaign renewed the spirit of Anzac. They got that spirit through to the people of Australia and they gave the younger people a vision of what Australia is all about. For that reason alone, I believe the campaign to take a delegation of Diggers-some more than 100 years of age; I think the eldest was 103 and the youngest 93-renewed the spirit of Anzac and showed our young people what it was all about.

It has been said often enough, and I repeat it today as the grandson of a Gallipoli veteran, that Anzac Day is really the Australian day. It is our traditional Australia Day, the day that we celebrate. That spirit goes right throughout Australia. I saw it in Charleville only the other day, on Anzac Day. The floods had run over the town. The people of Charleville had their Anzac Day parade. All the people of the town turned out, not to celebrate war but to pay homage to Australian veterans of all wars. I thought it was a wonderful tradition that in spite of all the hardships in Charleville, those people put on the ceremony there. It is just another demonstration of the tradition of people helping each other in times of adversity.

That spirit was born in 1915 in the Gallipoli campaign. I once again congratulate the Government on taking the delegation of Diggers, war widows and legatees to Turkey and renewing the spirit of Anzac.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to state the Australian Democrats' unequivocal support for the Spirit of Anzac motion. It is a motion which acknowledges the deep significance of the events of the Gallipoli campaign and the sacrifices of those who fought and died there. It is a motion also which acknowledges the extent to which these events and those who took part in them have helped forge a spirit that is truly and uniquely Australian, and it is a motion which recognises the special significance of the seventy-fifth anniversary of these events and the positive cooperation and unanimity of spirit between the Governments of Australia and Turkey and the veterans of both sides in citing the courage of the many, on the one hand, and yet the futility of war on the other.

SPEECH.PARA: In recent decades, as the ethos of peace begins to prevail over the ethos of war, Australians have had a degree of ambivalence about the `celebration' of Anzac Day. This to some degree reflects Australia's growing multiculturalism. In time this ambivalence will resolve itself. Such ambivalence was encapsulated in Eric Bogle's profoundly moving song The Band Played Waltzing Matilda. I draw honourable senators' attention to the excellent editorial in the Australian Financial Review of 24 April, which explored some of the ambivalence and contradictions inherent in our attitudes towards Anzac. But one thing we are not ambivalent about is that there is no doubt at all that Australians are as one in their indebtedness and gratitude to the heroes who were the Anzacs.

As we watched the recent commemorative ceremonies at Gallipoli there was an apparent sense of the profound futility of war. However, sadly, one can notice a growing tendency in recent years to project military action as good and even as entertainment. It is ironic that tonight, in my own capital city of Sydney, I understand that a mock military battle is the major curtain-raiser to the State of Origin rugby league match. Many thinking Australians are alarmed by this emerging Ramboism. Despite these continuing contradictions and ambivalence in our attitude, I rise on this occasion to unequivocally reiterate the Australian Democrats' wholehearted support for the Spirit of Anzac motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the shadow Minister for both veterans affairs and defence personnel, I am very proud to be associated with what will be a joint resolution of the Parliament. I was fortunate enough to travel in this pilgrimage. It occurs to me that it has some clear parallels with a much earlier pilgrimage recounted in Chaucer's Canterbury Tales. We, too, were going to visit hallowed ground. We, too, a variety of people, were going in a caravan, of the twentieth century at least. We were going for a variety of purposes, and each had our own tale to tell. I would be grateful if Senator Evans does not allocate me a particular role in the caravan. It is perhaps in his mind to do so. Nevertheless, it was a very special thing. It is not given to many people to travel as we did in a very closely confined group for a common purpose for 10 days of close, very intimate association. There was a spiritual quality to the entire pilgrimage.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things that will remain in my memory was seeing those very old soldiers, those very old men of whom we are all so proud, becoming young men again on the arms of our young soldiers. Many of the young men who accompanied us on the Spirit of Anzac, the Qantas aircraft, were roughly in the age group of the young men who fought at Gallipoli. That, somehow, went very much to one's heart. It was much easier to imagine the cheerful young men with their slouch hats who went off to war. Most of them say now that they thought it was an adventure. They learnt very soon that it was not an adventure, but they went with a cheerful spirit and with pride, in that they believed that what they were doing was important for their king and country. It is not for us in this generation in any way to deride their pride.

It is very good that today we are remembering their deeds. We are not glorifying war, as speakers have said previously. We are remembering with pride the achievements of those who survived and those who lie on the soil of Gallipoli. Far too many of our young men were left behind at Gallipoli. When I say that those involved in the pilgrimage went for different reasons, one of the consistent reasons that I found when I talked to the old men was that they went to see their mates. They went to pay tribute; they went to say goodbye. Many had never been back. I think many of them were very fearful of going back. The tension in our modern caravan increased the nearer we got to Gallipoli.

I think that, on one hand, for many of us younger members of the pilgrimage, the ceremonies on Anzac Day were what we expected to be the highlight of the pilgrimage. On the other hand, for the old men, the day after Anzac Day was probably the day for which they were waiting most intensely. That was the day on which, as best they could, on walking sticks and with the aid of walking frames, many of them blind or nearly blind, they were taken by young soldiers and by the nurses who were their carers, to walk around the areas where they fought and where often they were wounded. Some of them found it very hard to work out the positions where they had spent so many months in 1915. The Turks have reafforested that part of the peninsula. The pine trees are growing up and the pine needles are falling and covering the trenches. It is now hard to see exactly what it was like. I visited there seven years ago. At the time there were no other people on the battlefields and the trenches were very clear. Sadly, many remnants of the battle were clear for all to see and collect. These days, that is disappearing.
On the day that the old men visited their battlefields, they came back very late to dinner. They were very quiet. They were tired, but they had gone through a very emotional experience.

There were four young Duntroon cadets in the catafalque party at Lone Pine. They were probably the ages of most of the young men who fought at Gallipoli. At the Lone Pine service, young Australians with packs on their backs had come across from Europe to take part and to see what it was all about. Some of them said, `We really came out of curiosity'. But once they, too, had walked the cliffs of Gallipoli, there was no curiosity any more, just an awed fascination and reverence, if you like, at the feats of their forefathers. They had not realised just what an awesome undertaking the battle at Gallipoli had been for everybody who took part in it. The young backpackers climbed with their heavy packs, but they were not climbing under fire; they did not have wet uniforms; they were not clutching rifles; they did not have the holly bush tearing at their uniforms and their skin. They did it under the noonday sun, at peace.

This motion refers to the unsurpassed reputation of the Anzacs being an inspiration to us all. I know that those of us who travelled with the veterans have a very special memory. But I am heartened to realise what those young Australians who were there on the peninsula during the Anzac celebrations took away, too, by way of a recognition of the feats of their forebears. It is an inspiration to all Australians to endure, to be brave, to be resourceful, to emulate that irrepressible humour under pressure, to provide loyalty to each other. Those are things that we learnt from the Gallipoli men. But we also have to recognise that from it comes, and should come, a sense of national commitment, as is spelled out in this motion.

The sacrifices emphasise the tragedy and futility of war. They emphasise the need to dedicate ourselves to the cause of peace. But I say also that they should remind us that we have soldiers, sailors and airmen and women today for whom we must give the sort of care and encouragement that we have given to our soldiers of other days. Our young men and women in the forces today have inherited this noble tradition. I am quite convinced that, if the need arose, they would fight for this country as their forebears have done. We must not in time of peace forget them, denigrate them and push them to one side. It is true that if we want peace, we will not achieve it by being seen by the world to not be prepared to protect our freedom and to fight for it. Therefore, my Party believes very strongly that peace will be achieved by being seen to be strong.

I do not wish to take up an undue amount of the Senate's time. Others before me have mentioned that there were many people involved in this pilgrimage. It was a quite massive undertaking. I would like to list some of those people to whom credit must be given. The Returned Services League had the original idea. The RSL and Mr Bill Hall, who put it to the Government, should be commended for the inspiration for the pilgrimage. I would like to pay tribute, too, to the journalists who travelled on that pilgrimage who would perhaps describe themselves as hard-bitten journalists and who, by the end of it, were proud to admit that they, too, cried at Lone Pine. I also pay tribute to the nurses who got so very little sleep throughout the trip, as they were so determined to ensure the health and well-being of their old veterans. Those nurses came from both the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Royal Australian Air Force. There were also doctors from the Department and from the Air Force. There was the band of young men who came from the Australian Army. There was the honour guard as well, and the signallers. The Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Army provided people for administration.

The Royal Australian Navy should not be forgotten. At dawn on Anzac Day, as we arrived to take our places on Anzac Cove, we saw out at sea, standing off from the beaches, ships from the navies of Britain, Turkey and Australia lit up. That is how many men fighting at Gallipoli in 1915 would have seen them over those many months.

Of course, we must not forget the tremendous cooperation of the Turkish Government. As the Minister has already said in another place, things did not always go without a hiccup, but we always felt that there was good will and a wish to make it go well.

Just before we left Turkey we were taken by the Turkish Government to visit their military museum in Istanbul for a formal farewell. It was fascinating for those of us in the Australian party who were taken on a short tour to see that the Gallipoli campaign occupies a very tiny corner of that museum. Over the centuries the Dardanelles, and all the area covered by Turkey, have been the scene of many battles. To them, this was just a small part in their history. For us, of course, it was in many ways the founding of our nation.

In that it took us three-quarters of an hour to embark people on to a plane or to disembark them or to get them on or off a bus, and in the administration sense as well, it was an enormous undertaking. The Government is to be congratulated for being prepared to do this, partly for the veterans themselves and partly, I believe, for the nation.

I say once again how much I appreciate having been a part of that pilgrimage. I am grateful for the opportunity that was given to me to represent the Opposition on the spirit of Anzac trip. I am sure it will be a memory I will never lose. I pay tribute to all those who played such an important part. Whether they were big cogs or small cogs, all played their part with an enthusiasm and a joy which is an integral part of the memories we will all carry away from the occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to add my few remarks to the words already said in support of this joint motion. The point I highlight is the perspective that I obtained as one who did not go to Gallipoli but who covered the pilgrimage, if that is what it is to be called now, essentially from what the media told me in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I make it clear that in no way are my remarks meant to denigrate or take away from the courage and commitment of our young men-or, indeed, those now very old men who returned to Gallipoli. The impression I got from watching the coverage of this Anzac return was that women were not really a significant part of the Gallipoli symbol at all. On a number of occasions the various media indicated that this might indeed become something of a national symbol for Australia, but I do not believe that we can properly have a national symbol if it is not able to speak to or be inclusive of all the people of this country.

In particular, I think the people of Australia need to be reminded of the contribution of women at the Gallipoli campaign and in our two world wars. While we did have one very elderly Army nurse, Kathleen Avery from South Australia, who went on that pilgrimage, I believe there was only one small reference to her, apart from general photographs. The whole story of the Army nurses in the First World War was something that I knew little about until I actually sought that information from the library via the official war history of the First World War, although I have known from the stories that have been told that women did make a contribution over there as well as here.

Something like 2,800 women enlisted as army nurses in the First World War and more than 2,100 of those women embarked on overseas duty. In addition, more than 120 women volunteered to work in a variety of ways, principally in nursing and caring for the wounded in England. Of those women who enlisted to serve overseas, 21 died in service overseas. It is, I suppose, a matter of remarkable tragedy that the causes of their deaths were actually cholera, pneumonia and influenza, but I suppose one could say at least that they were not shot to death on the battlefield.

The women did have a special role. The challenge that particularly those nurses waiting on the hospital ships off the coast of Gallipoli had to deal with is not something we care to think of. We have heard told the excitement of many young men who thought this was a great adventure; they would go to the other side of the world and take their place in such an adventure. But for those women, let alone those many men, waiting on those hospital ships, what they saw was not a celebration, not a wonderful adventure, but the smashed and broken bodies of those soldiers who survived to be nursed back to some kind of health and the many broken minds of people who suffered shell shock.

The sorts of down sides of war that I think we need not only never to forget but also to acknowledge are that so many Australian women had to bear both the immediate effects and the longer term effects as those men returned to this country permanently disabled. Of course I am glad that we acknowledge the contribution of support for people with such disabilities, but I do not think we should overlook the immediacy of those disabilities, that pain and anguish of the women who were nursing those people there and, of course, the families who welcomed or accepted back their broken and wounded men.

The other group of women very often forgotten in Australia are those women who maintained the effort during the war and who have kept the tradition alive in their own families and at Anzac ceremonies ever since. Those women very often finished up deprived of fathers, sons and husbands. Many, many thousands of widows in this country can relate just what price they paid in terms of the Anzac events, and I do not believe we should overlook them. They are never seen as a significant part of the war or as heroes of the day but, of course, they are heroes in a very particular way. If we are talking about the powerful sense of Australian national identity that emerges from Anzac, I do believe it is important that we never forget to define the contribution of those families and, in particular, those women who gave up their men and bore the consequences of that giving up of their men through many years of loss, difficulty and, certainly in many cases, poverty.

A number of honourable senators have said here that this is never to be seen as a celebration of war. I think we are all utterly agreed on that. It is not seen that way. It is a monument to peace and clearly a recognition of the importance of pursuing peace. In some ways, if we focus forever on the achievements of the battlefield, we can be in danger of celebrating death, and in drawing attention to the contribution of women I suggest that we never forget to celebrate life. It was those women who begat those men who then grew up to give their lives in the way they did, or who were at least injured and made their contribution through suffering. I think that if we are looking at this as a national symbol we must increase or extend the meanings that that symbol embraces and make sure that it is inclusive of the contributions of all peoples from this country.

I wonder, too, what Anzac Day as a national symbol would say to Aboriginal people. Certainly I think this country is still slow to acknowledge the contribution of many Aboriginal men in the armed forces at wartime. Of course, the words I used about the womenfolk apply equally to Aboriginal women in the way that they have suffered the loss of their menfolk.

If this is a national symbol, we have to see in what way it speaks to or has messages for people who live in this country but were not born here. In some ways, I suppose the alienation, the loneliness, the feeling of despair perhaps when one is on foreign shores far away from family and home and recognised traditions, may in fact be a metaphor that speaks immediately to people of non-English speaking backgrounds, to the many refugees and migrants who come to this country. In some way, I find that piece of symbolism easier to cope with than the way in which the celebration of Anzac Day acknowledges the great contribution of Australian women.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion moved by Senator Button, which is a most important one. I was a member of the parliamentary delegation which attended the very moving services on the Gallipoli Peninsula, particularly the dawn service at Anzac Cove and later the Australian national memorial at Lone Pine. At Lone Pine 2,000 young Australians were killed, for no territorial advantage, no military advantage at all. Very few of them have graves; there was no room or time to bury people at Gallipoli. They were not buried until 1919 and the memorials are memorials of names, they are not graves. The people killed on Gallipoli have no known graves.

SPEECH.PARA: We got a deeply moving impression of what it must have been like being a young Australian there. The Anzacs landed on the wrong beach, a mile from where they were supposed to land, in country that might have been possible to seize in a surprise operation, but against opposition it was impossible for either side-and both sides tried desperately-to advance more than a few yards at a time at the cost of impossible casualties.

Gallipoli was a military disaster, and we are not celebrating anything, either a war or a military disaster; we are looking at the sacrifices made by young Australians to achieve what was held to be a national objective and the spirit of the people who did it. Someone said to one of the old Diggers that it was hoped he was not finding it too much of a strain. He replied, `Well, I am 95, I am going to die soon; if I die here, at least I will be with me mates'. That represents a spirit which has lasted 75 years after the event and which at the time made a deep impression on all who came into contact with the Australian troops. Their size, their confidence and their courage made an indelible impression on everyone associated with them.

The casualties were very severe. In that campaign 5,582 Australians were killed, 2,012 died of wounds, 1,115 died of disease, 17,904 were wounded. The Australians, by the way, contrary to the impression some people give, did not make the predominant military contribution to the campaign. The British had twice the number killed. The French had more. But what I think is extraordinary is that, despite the fact that 5,000 Australians were killed, only 11 of our people were taken prisoner. Other countries had the ordinary proportion. Seven thousand British were taken prisoner and several thousand French, but only 11 Australians. That gives credibility to a remark that was made by an Englishman, a poet laureate, who was present in the campaign, John Masefield. We want to remember this because it shows the impression the Australians made the first time that they were in an awful situation, really the first time Australians had burst on the world scene. John Masefield, of the Australians involved in the campaign, said:
There was no thought of surrender in these magnificent young men. They were the cream of this world's manhood and they died as they had lived, owning no master on this earth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I realise that this motion is not designed to glorify war in any way, and I appreciate what other people have said about that. I really support the feeling in section 2 (d) of the motion when it says:

SPEECH.PARA: the sacrifices . . . emphasises the tragedy and futility of war and the need to re-dedicate ourselves to the cause of world peace.

I think that is a very important sentiment. I also think we owe to the elderly veterans who went to Gallipoli for the seventy-fifth anniversary a huge amount of respect. But we also owe them an apology that they were put through the needless torture and that so many of their mates died on those foreign shores so far from home. We also owe a huge apology to the veterans of all other wars in which Australians have died. That was a sentiment that I felt a couple of years ago when the Vietnam veterans had their return parade 20 years after the event. Instead of saying, `You beaut, chaps', we should have been saying, `We are deeply sorry that you had to go through that agony'. In fact they did not have to go through it at all and that is the real tragedy of Australia's involvement in all wars thus far in our history.

It is a great shame that the myth of the Anzacs continues because the events at Gallipoli are seen somehow as being the birth of our nation. This is the kind of nonsense that keeps being brought forward and that we had for days on end in the media. If that is the birth of our nation I think it is a very sorry nation indeed that is born out of the suffering and slaughter of its young men on foreign soil for no good reason. Why were the Anzac or Australian troops there? This question has not been asked because there is no really good answer to it. We were there because the British Government asked us to be there, and the Australian Government said yes, as it has said subsequently in the First World War, the Second World War, the Korean War and in the Vietnam War. Other countries have dictated our foreign policy and our defence policies and we have let young Australians be slaughtered.

That is why I think we owe a huge national apology to any service man or woman who has gone overseas to fight in other nation's wars. I do not think that that will ever happen again. I do not think that Australians will ever let that happen again. I sincerely hope not. I think it is rather strange that two very important days in the Australian national calendar commemorate very bizarre affairs. One is the commemoration on 25 April of the butchery of so many of our young men on foreign soil and the other event where the nation seems to come together is a horse race on the first Tuesday in November each year. These are very strange notions of nationhood.

I think our sense of national commitment and national pride should spring from other sources, from our ability to live together to create a vibrant and sharing community where we are at peace domestically at home with each other and with our neighbours, with an equitable share of the wonderful resources this country has to offer. We have so much to offer yet we cling to the myth that the nation was born on a foreign battlefield where so many of our young men bravely died-I acknowledge that, of course-for a cause that was not relevant to Australia. They should never have been there. That is the tragedy of it.

I would like to support some of Senator Crowley's remarks on the omission of women from the whole scene but add to her remarks that we should recognise not only the participation of women as volunteers or conscripts but also the other darker side of the picture, and that is of the millions of unacknowledged victims of war right through the ages and right around the globe; that is, millions of women and children who have suffered the worst excesses of war-pillage, rape, torture and death. As Senator Crowley was speaking I was reminded of the origins of Mother's Day, and it is quite appropriate that I mention this now because Mother's Day is this Sunday. The first Mother's Day was commemorated in 1888 in the United States when a poet there by the name of Julira Howe wrote a poem calling on women. She was very distressed about the Franco-Prussian war and about the American War of Independence which had recently claimed the lives of thousands of young men and women, mostly men, there. She wrote a poem calling for women to refuse to bear children to be used as mere cannon fodder. She said:
We do not give birth so that our children can kill other women's children.

I think it is very important that we acknowledge that aspect also, the unacknowledged victims-heroines perhaps-of war situations. That aspect should not be omitted. That element is omitted from the Anzac tradition or this myth that we have built up about Anzac. I think that is something we should correct.

As I said, I do not want to denigrate the sacrifices that these men made when they were younger, and I am very glad that the veterans went and returned safely back to Australia, but I do think we must ask the question: What on earth were they doing there in the first place? We ought to really challenge the decision-making processes of our Government, which continue to this day to be subservient to the wishes of other nations. We are not truly independent. Perhaps Australia will be really independent by the year 2001, the centenary of the founding of the Commonwealth of Australia. By then we might have learned how to be truly independent, to stand on our own two feet and to take our place in the world in conjunction with peace building in our region. That is our role. We have a tremendous opportunity in Australia, and I think we have blown it on so many occasions by being subservient. I think that the continuation of the Anzac myth continues to foster the myth that this was somehow a glorious day in Australia's history. There was nothing glorious about the butchery of so many young men. To them we owe our great and sincere apology.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Anzac Day commemorations have been known to me since I was a child, but I cannot say that I understood the issues as clearly as I do now. My travelling to Gallipoli with the delegation for Anzac Day gave it a new meaning for me and provided a better understanding in relation to the events of the campaign. I would like to thank the Government and the people of Australia for the opportunity of being a member of that delegation.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe that any thinking person would not agree with what Senator Hamer said. For instance, it was a terrible strategic decision and it was a disaster to send people to Gallipoli. It cost the lives of so many people who were so invaluable to this country and who should have been enhancing the future of Australia instead of losing their lives at Gallipoli.

However, quite separate from that is the question of those people who went over there without understanding the reasons for the war and not questioning what they would do when they got there. Quite apart from that is the question of how they behaved and the bravery they showed, the mateship, and the good humour. Of course, descriptions of those events over many months contain a lot of humorous stories within the framework of so much horror and sadness. I certainly received a better understanding of the way in which the Turks courageously defended their homeland. I suppose that if somebody came from a far away place and looked at the conflict, he might look favourably upon the Turks, because we had to go a long way to get into that dust-up. One of the war historians said that it was probably the last conflict and the last battle that could be considered to have been fought under the terms of chivalry. I think that was highlighted by the fact that when there were so many dead on the battlefield and an armistice was declared, there was mutual respect. Both the Turkish and Anzac troops exchanged souvenirs and even exchanged commodities which the other did not have. Also, at the end of the conflict, there was no lasting hatred and no lasting dislike of each other.

I pay tribute to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) for the way in which he delivered his speech, and I record an appreciation of the content of that speech. He said some of the things that Senator Vallentine has said: we were not there to glorify war but, rather, to remember the courage that was shown by those people in that conflict. Based on that experience and other experiences throughout the history of the world, we should maintain a determination that we never again get into the position of conflict where so many lives are lost. We must continue to work for world peace. We should look at the question of mutual assistance between Turkey and Australia and, of course, with other countries. I agree with a lot of what Senator Vallentine said about the abhorrence of war. However, I choose to raise that question at another time. I do not believe, either, that volunteers will ever rush to the flag as they did in those days without an understanding of what the conflict was about. I believe that people read too much to do that these days and they understand the world situation and the arguments between nations.

In closing, I would also like to thank the Turkish Government for the way in which it received our delegation and all those people from Australia, the sort of assistance it gave to us and the friendship it generously extended. I am certainly looking forward to returning to Turkey as a country in which I felt at home. I was also struck by the honesty of those people with whom I had dealings, down to the man in the street selling postcards, and also taxi drivers. I wish them all the best in building their nation, as they strive to do, as I dedicate myself and express a determination to build this nation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
