TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a statement on behalf of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) relating to a review of migration legislation. I have sought and obtained agreement from both the Australian Democrats and the Opposition to incorporate this statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement reads as follows-
REVIEW OF MIGRATION LEGISLATION
Mr President: I seek leave to make a Ministerial statement on a review which the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has commenced of the Migration Legislation.
Honourable Senators will be aware of the far reaching changes which were introduced in 1989 into the regime governing our migration administration.
After the Parliament enacted the Migration Legislation Amendment Act in June 1989, Regulations were made on 19 December 1989, as required under that Act.

Large sections of the new Act and Regulations are now being administered smoothly. The Government, however, has heard a good deal of criticism of the operation of parts of the new system not least from the last Parliament's own Committee-the Joint Select Committee set up by resolution moved by my predecessor on 31 May 1989. Accordingly, the Government has decided to act on a number of the criticisms and concerns voiced. The Minister intends to make some changes to the Regulations immediately, and set up a structured process of Parliamentary scrutiny and public consultation to examine further necessary changes.

I should first, however, provide a short overview of the character and direction of the changes to the Migration Act 1958. In amending the Act, the Minister's predecessor laid the basis for quite significant and far reaching changes of approach to migration administration.

Prior to these changes, decision making under the Act had largely been a matter of administrative discretion. Accordingly, there was a lack of uniformity and consistency in decision making. Policies and guidance were scattered across a variety of Departmental handbooks. Instructions were frequently expressed only in broad terms and, in some instances, had essentially evolved over time without being articulated in detail anywhere. This meant that individuals, and their representatives, as well as departmental decision makers, had no coherent body of rules to consult to implement the Government's policy requirements.

The Minister, because decision making powers were vested in him, and policy was a matter of discretion, was placed in the unenviable position of being a general avenue of appeal on the merits in respect of any decision made by any officer of the Department.

There was also increasing evidence that illegal entrants and others were using the avenues provided by policy loopholes and procedural complexities to challenge decisions quite properly using the emerging body of administrative law.

The introduction of so large a body of Regulations under the amended legislation in a much compressed time frame compared to what was originally intended was required by the Migration Legislation Amendment Act. This resulted in a lack of clarity, and, in a number of cases, unintended consequences.

Accordingly, the Minister's predecessor made it clear on a number of occasions that it would be necessary continually to monitor the regulations and amend them as problems emerged. The Minister's predecessor made a number of changes prior to his leaving the portfolio and the changes the Minister is making are part of that ongoing process.

Underlying the Government's approach to any review of the legislative framework are our basic objectives of maintaining Government authority over our non-discriminatory migration program and other entry of people into Australia; continuing to ensure that its migration administration has effective means for minimising the potential for abuse of the system by illegal entrants; and retaining the power, through its control systems (including the discretions available to the Minister) to respond sensitively and with compassion when individual cases arise that require special consideration.

Control over the migration program and entry generally is exercised through the codification of policies into regulation so that they are fixed in law. Codification means that policies are clearly specified in criteria and people are clear on their entitlements and obligations. This narrows the range of discretions needed to make decisions. The correlative of this meant that policies had to be spelt out in fine detail. Further, the Department has to have in place proper administrative procedures consistent with the principles of administrative law and these procedures in turn must also be reflected in the regulations. Because of the scope and complexity of migration policies and procedures, this in turn meant a very extensive body of Regulations. To some extent the sheer volume of the Regulations has given rise to some of the criticisms of complexity.

The second objective of minimising abuse of the system by illegal entrants has also been largely attained by the codification process. By this means it has proved possible to define clearly the entitlements we are prepared to allow for particular groups of illegal entrants, rather than have broad discretionary criteria for illegal entrants as a group. It is quite clear that we must distinguish between those people who become illegal quite innocently and unintentionally through ignorance of proper procedures, and those who exploit every loophole in immigration policies to stay on in Australia even though they have no right to do so. This is by no means easy as considerable ingenuity is directed towards finding loopholes which must then be plugged. And, of course, the Regulations become increasingly complex as these loopholes are plugged.
Another related objective is to ensure that those who jump the queue are not advantaged to the detriment of those whose family sponsor their coming to Australia in accord with proper procedures.

The other main objectives was that of removing from the Minister the almost intolerable burden of being a court of appeal for all the adverse decisions made by Departmental officers. The Minister sees his role as principally being responsible for setting and correcting the direction of policy. He has powers to deal with the individual case at the primary decision level, but there he is bound by the Regulations. Without going into detail, the Minister also has powers under sections 115 and 137 of the Migration Act to set aside decisions after each review stage. Under these sections he is not bound by the criteria established by the Regulations and has a power to make any decision more favourable to the applicant that he judges to be in the public interest. This is a discretionary power and he is under no obligation to use it. However, the Minister is restricted in the exercise of the power in that the person seeking his intervention must have a review right. The Minister must also report to Parliament if he makes such a decision.

I might also emphasise that the Minister has no intention of intervening under his review powers unless there is serious reason. That is, he shall not be setting aside decisions reached in accord with the criteria established by the Regulations unless he is convinced that there is a gap in policy, that the refusal is an unintended consequences of the Regulations or that an individual case requires special consideration. In these circumstances the Minister shall move to amend the Regulations as necessary.

There has been a considerable amount of criticism of the Regulations on the grounds that they are inflexible, harsh and overly complex. Some of the criticisms raise valid concerns and I shall indicate later how the Minister intends to deal with these. But it is worth noting at the outset that the Regulations work reasonably well in by far the great majority of cases and have caused few problems. The great bulk of the problems have emerged in two general areas. First, people whose circumstances fall outside policy and who were previously handled on an ad hoc discretionary basis. Second, people who are illegally in Australia and who either simply do not wish to leave when they should, or who argue that there is good reason for staying on after they should have left. When numbers of people entering Australia were significantly smaller than they are now, we as a community could accept dealing with these problems by waiving policy on an ad hoc basis. Now, however, the numbers are becoming so large that more formal measures need to be in place to maintain the integrity of the program.

The Minister will be approaching the question of changing the legislation in a 3-phase approach. The first phase incorporates those changes where a response is needed immediately, or where further consultation is not needed. These changes are of some significance. The phase will also include a number of technical changes which have only minor policy or procedural implications but which will improve the working of the Regulations and clarify some of the criteria.

The Minister will also ensure in making changes in the first phase, that provision is made such that people who may have applied after 18 December, but before these changes come into place, are not disadvantaged by any changes relating to their application.

The first phase will, in particular, provide greater access to review rights under the transitional arrangements. That is, the Minister accepts that it is quite inequitable to leave people without a review right. The Minister is therefore going to reinstate the Immigration Review Panel to provide a review channel for people who were here before 19 December 1989, had lodged an application before that date and had no review avenue in the event of an adverse decision.

The Minister also intends in the first place to give effect to some recommendations of the Administrative Review Council in relation to the Minister's powers to substitute a decision more favourable to the applicant at the review stage. As the legislation is presently formed some applicants could be disadvantaged if the Minister were to intervene on his own initiative at the internal review stage and remove from the applicant any review of the internal review decision by the Immigration Review Tribunal.

Accordingly, I foreshadow a Bill to amend the Migration Act to ensure that the Minister's discretion to make a decision after the first tier can only be exercised at the request of the applicant and where the Minister is prepared to make a decision agreeable to the applicant. The Bill will maintain the situation that the Minister has no duty to exercise that discretion when requested. The Government will also move to amend the legislation to allow the applicant to appeal to the Immigration Review Tribunal on the internal review decision where the Minister does not intervene.

The Minister will also overcome an anomalous situation with regard to review fees. Where an applicant has appealed to the Immigration Review Tribunal and the Minister has exercised his discretion in favour of the applicant, the applicant will be refunded any fee paid to the Tribunal.
The Government will also be moving quickly to establish a Joint Committee on Migration Regulations and will seek to ensure that the terms of reference of that Committee facilitate wide consultation.
The Minister also now intends that he should report every six months to Parliament on any intervention at any decision-making stage in respect of applications for visas and entry permits.

The Minister's reporting will cover an analysis and cataloguing of cases determined by him and will contain his conclusions about possible needs to amend existing regulations or make new regulations. By reporting regularly in this way the proposed Joint Committee will be provided with an opportunity to scrutinise any decisions the Minister has taken and to report to him and the Parliament on the appropriateness of any legislative or regulatory amendments.
The Minister's reporting will also include Immigration Review Tribunal comments about the impact of the Regulations in the light of the cases that come before them.

In addition, the Minister will reduce the complexity of the application procedures by collapsing the current 97 entry permit classes down to a possible 7; provide changes to relax certain deadlines; provide for the waiver of appeal fees in hardship cases; eliminate the requirement for preferential family applicants for permanent residence in compassionate circumstances recognised in the Regulations, to leave Australia simply to lodge applications in situations where this requirement is unnecessarily harsh and arbitrary; and provide discretion for relaxing the provisions barring the return to Australia of illegal entrants, other than deportees on criminal or security grounds, so as to recognise compelling compassionate circumstances. These changes will meet a number of the more pressing problems which have emerged.

The second and third phases will deal with changes which require more time to decide. The Minister intends in the process of finalising these to pursue a structured process of Parliamentary scrutiny and public consultation. The proposed Joint Committee will play a central role in this process.

By this consultation process the Minister hopes to avoid the problems which emerged because of the tight deadlines within which the Regulations had to be introduced. In particular, the Minister wishes to ensure that Departmental manuals setting out the Regulations and procedures are in place when the Regulations are changed, and that officers of the Department are given adequate time to digest the changes and be trained in any new procedures which may result.

One area the Minister is not addressing in the first phase is the general area of asylum and the special case of the long-term future of PRC nationals in Australia. This area is to be the subject of further consideration by Government. The Minister shall, however, be giving early consideration to humanitarian entry criteria and, in particular, the barriers to the entry of persons who have a right of settlement in third countries.

In the second phase the Minister shall be examining such issues as the health criteria; restrictions on the grant of permanent residence to visitors who marry Australian citizens; and the question of tightening criteria for testing the genuineness of marriage; clarifying the entitlements of illegal entrants to remaining in Australia; and restrictions on temporary resident permit holders having access to permanent residence. But he will be looking at these issues in a measured fashion, and will not be rushing into quick ad hoc solutions to meet the exigencies of particular cases. The Minister is also certain that other issues will emerge as public consultations are carried out. He hopes to have these changes in place beginning in August and to have completed this phase by December.

The final phase relates to a general redrafting of the Regulations. The Government accepts that the Regulations could be made less difficult to understand. There are two aspects to this: some of the problems stem from Departmental procedures and the Minister is taking steps to change these in the first two stages of his review. The other aspect stems from language and structure. The Minister will shortly be talking to the Attorney-General about undertaking this exercise as matter of priority. It will, however, probably take about 12 months to achieve this.

In the time available to the Minister it was not possible to establish with complete confidence as to which changes in the Regulations that I am foreshadowing today will require changes in the Migration Act itself. This matter is being examined as a matter of priority. The timetable that I have outlined may need to be varied to allow for the processes of any necessary amendment of the Act to take place.

The Minister is confident that by adopting this structured approach to amending the migration legislation we will have a legal regime in place which, on the one hand, will meet the reasonable needs of people seeking to come to or remain in Australia, along with the rights of Australian sponsors. On the other hand, we will continue to meet the legitimate concerns of the Australian community that the numbers of people coming either to stay permanently or temporarily are consistent with the interests of the Australian community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

This report is clear evidence that the Government has failed to administer the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, is failing to administer immigration programs and has failed to complete its own reforms of the immigration programs. It is no surprise to this chamber that, for seven years now, and with increasing urgency since the report two years ago of the FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies, there is a failure on the Government's part to bring any competent degree of public confidence into Australia's immigration program.

This report is also a direct illustration of the failure of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) himself. I say this because, following the election, we saw the Prime Minister sack his fifth Minister for immigration, Senator Robert Ray. Along with that, he has sacked, or forced to resign, the head of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and has put into his place one of his own Prime Minister and Cabinet Assistant Secretaries, Mr Conybeare. There has been pressure on other senior public servants in the Department to leave their positions and to leave the Department. One very senior member of the Department, apart from the Secretary, has now left the Department, and there has been an attempt to force some others to go, but they have not succumbed.

There is a great concern, detected by the Public Service itself, over the amendments to the Public Service Act which Mr Dawkins moved in 1983 which gave this Government the powers, arguably, to take these actions. Yet, at the time when that Act was debated and adopted in this Parliament, such exercise of powers was not contemplated and certainly was not foreshadowed.

Throughout all of these dramatic events there has been no explanation by the Prime Minister. The statement that was put down here today-and in the other place by the new Minister, Mr Hand-makes no reference whatsoever to these dramatic events. Whilst the statement actually admits failure to administer the Department, failure to administer the immigration program and especially failure to have predicted the complexity and inadequacies of the regulation promulgating process, it makes no reference to these dramatic events. I believe that this chamber deserves a full explanation for the actions of the Prime Minister in these regards.

It is speculated that the reason for the Prime Minister's dramatic actions is entirely a consequence of the regulation process getting out of hand-that is, the bungle that emerged following 19 December 1989 in Senator Robert Ray's administration of the promulgation of regulations under the Act. This is a puzzle, given the clear statement made by the Prime Minister on 3 April during the election campaign, when he said:
I do not claim that our new regulations are yet perfect. Robert-
that is the Minister, Senator Ray-

has made clear that some of the criticism has been fair. But he has also said, and I agree totally, that clearly defined and publicly available rules for decision-making will introduce more certainly, consistency, and fairness to the operation of migration policy.

From a total reversal of the Prime Minister's statement during the election campaign it is surmised that, for the want of adequate process in developing the regulations and because of the confusion in this area, he has held not only the Minister responsible and sacked him, but also the head of the Department-that is, Mr Ron Brown-and sacked him.

It is well known to this chamber that Mr Brown is no ordinary head of a department. He is a most competent person and a very experienced public servant who brought enormous assets to his job as the head of the immigration department. Prior to that he was the executive officer of the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS). He had the full support not only of the SBS board in its early stages of development, but also of ethnic community leaders and the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia, and of all sides of discussion of immigration and ethnic affairs matters in heading that statutory authority. Prior to that he had very senior jobs in the Department of Social Security. In fact, I first met and grew to be very fond of Ron Brown when he was the director of the Social Security Department in my State of South Australia. As a new senator 12 years ago I had an office in the same building at No. 1 North Terrace in Adelaide.

There is no explanation why this good man-free of any public controversy, free of any criticism prior to his spontaneous sacking by the Prime Minister-has gone. I do not believe that it is because he failed to implement the policy of his Minister. I believe he implemented it perhaps too well.

It is a grave injustice that a senior public servant, or indeed any person, can be sacked so contemptuously by Mr Hawke and this Labor Government. Labor thinks that it can be proud and arrogant immediately after winning an election, even if so narrowly, and take such actions. What in fact it shows is that the Labor Government-and this is again reinforced by the statement put down by the Minister today-is on the back foot because it failed to win votes from the general public on immigration matters, and it failed to win support from ethnic community leaders; it had somewhat taken them for granted.

Labor did not allow public consultation in this massive amendment to the immigration legislation, and in the enormous tomes of new regulations that were to be the foundation for the operation of the immigration program. The ethnic leaders were not consulted at all. They started to put pressure upon the Prime Minister during the election campaign, and he realised that he had made grave errors in the way in which, over the last 18 months, the Labor Government had gone about immigration and ethnic affairs policy. So the Prime Minister looked around for a scapegoat. As a signal particularly to ethnic community leaders, whose votes he wanted to buy, he sacked Senator Robert Ray, who over the last 12 months had only too carefully been fulfilling and putting into place the policy that Cabinet had endorsed. Mr Brown was sacked as well.

I put this Government on notice that the Opposition will watch most carefully every aspect of the Government's relations with not only ethnic community leaders but all Australians in so far as there are changes in policy during the life of this Parliament. Mr Hand, the new Minister, is also on notice. He has been moved from an area where he failed to gain public support-that is, as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs-an area of enormous controversy during the past Parliament. There was unnecessary controversy because he stirred up a civil war over the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission proposal. That was evident in the debate in this chamber during the months and months of questions that were directed to Senator Tate on the other side of the chamber. That failure on Mr Hand's part as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs must not be repeated in this area of immigration and ethnic affairs. There must be public consultation, there must be an open approach and there must be an early set of explanations as to why the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, has made these dramatic decisions.

If there is any evidence of the Hawke Labor Government changing immigration policy just to buy the votes of some ethnic community leaders-and against the national interests of Australia-there will be very sharp criticism not only from the Opposition but from the entire Australian public. I remind the Senate that there have now been six Ministers for immigration during the Hawke Government period: Stewart West lasted 1 3/4 years; Chris Hurford, 2 1/4 years; Mick Young, nearly one year; Clyde Holding, who was seen to have failed in his job, only half a year.

At the dramatic point when the FitzGerald report was before us and when there was an unprecedented lack of public confidence in immigration, a desperate measure was taken by this Government to appoint Senator Robert Ray, a new Minister with authority and credibility, to come in and act in the national interest with a whole new set of policies, to tidy up the Act, to set up thousands of new regulations, to codify the immigration program, and to ensure that the criticisms that the Opposition had been making for five years were positively responded to.

He did his best, but he did not do it very well. Instead of acknowledging those deficits only, the Prime Minister has gone much further and wanted to wipe clear the slate of all those who tried to put the Senator Robert Ray and Ron Brown period of immigration and administration into place.

Mr Hand is the sixth Minister. The others have all come in for enormous criticism in this Parliament and Mr Hand will have to lift his game and start with careful explanations of these activities of the Prime Minister if he is going to win any public credibility or attention in this Parliament.

I have referred to the dismay that has gone through the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Hundreds of public servants in senior positions, even overseas, argue that Mr Brown adequately addressed the agenda set by Cabinet. As they see it, he sharpened the economic focus of the Department. As they see it, he did the bidding of his Minister, Senator Robert Ray. What kind of security do you think they feel now when a new Minister has come on board? They will have to give formal allegiance to the policy that may be developed in the coming months, but there is a grave uncertainty and insecurity that has been introduced into immigration, even within the Department itself.

I know that the statement made today seeks to address some of the massive problems related to the regulation process and I will come to those in due course. I wish to remind the Senate that in the very first week that Senator Ray was appointed, in an article in the Age newspaper I commended the appointment and said that the Prime Minister had seemed to accept the failure and the enormous low in immigration under Minister Holding and that it was time to make a fresh start. I said the ball was at Senator Ray's feet. I said:
He has, quite genuinely, received good wishes from all sides in Parliament.

But if he fails to renew public confidence in immigration, that same Parliament will be unforgiving. For the sake of all Australians, his task is to turn away from the Hawke Government's five years of failure.

I believe that the Parliament, in the light of the statement that is before us today, should be unforgiving. Senator Ray was not given full cooperation to achieve the task that he had set out for himself and now even those achievements have been put in jeopardy.

In some ways it all began with the bombshell of the FitzGerald report in mid 1988. This soundly weighed the immigration policy of the Government and found it entirely wanting. In 73 recommendations it set out the way to recover public confidence in immigration. A few months later the Government's response to the FitzGerald report, which had been warmly received by the Opposition, appeared and was totally inadequate. To the extent that there was any approaching of the FitzGerald report's recommendations it was the activity of a new and authoritative Minister, Senator Ray. Even that now is in jeopardy.

It was on the basis that certain assurances were given and certain amendments achieved that the Opposition agreed to the massive change in immigration law in mid 1989. But despite the amendments that we were able to gain to that immigration Act, there has not been the follow-through in the regulations that were then formulated and which guide the Act.

I hold in my hand two reports, both of which are confidential. One is the first report to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs of the Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations given to him on 28 November last year. The other is the second report also given to the Minister on 12 December last year. Even though we were a joint select committee of this Parliament we have not been free to bring the reports to the Parliament. So as a member of that Select Committee I can give only some general description of these two reports.

The reports are full of specific recommendations to meet the inadequacies of the draft regulations that were to be promulgated on 19 December last. I remind the Senate that was a few days before this Senate rose, before this Parliament finished its sitting prior to this week. The statement put down today by the Minister for Immigration does go some way to responding to the specific recommendations in those two reports, but the public does not know what were in the reports and this Parliament does not know.

A great deal of effort was put in by the Committee; some 25 meetings were spread out over six weeks. Senator Jenkins is in the chamber; as another member of the Committee she is very familiar with the enormous effort that went into the formulation of those reports. We found that the draft regulations, had they been promulgated as intended by the Government, would have been an unmitigated disaster for this country.

If the Prime Minister is trying to explain his dramatic decisions following the election as a positive response to the Opposition's criticisms as set out, for example, by some of us in these two reports, he may be feigning to take up the constructive measures that we have proposed to rescue the immigration program of Australia. But I do not believe that that is the entire explanation of the dramatic changes. I believe that the press has got a large degree of this right and so have those with an interest in immigration in this country who have been receiving rumours that the Labor Government under Prime Minister Hawke and Minister Hand is seeking to go much further away from the recommendations of the FitzGerald report. They are wanting to go back to open vote buying through family reunion programs, even though they know in their minds and hearts that it is not in the national interests of Australia.

Those such as Senator Walsh or Senator Robert Ray who argue outside or inside Cabinet that this is not responsible of the present Labor Government need to be listened to. If there is a failure on the part of the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and the Minister, Mr Hand, to respond to those responsible warnings, it will come to light and there will be much to be paid with regard to debate and criticism in this chamber.

Let me focus for a moment on yesterday's opening speech by the Governor-General in the opening of Parliament. On page 10 of the speech there are some four paragraphs that relate to immigration and ethnic affairs. These paragraphs are cliched. They sound innocuous and they paper over the issues that I referred to at the outset of my speech. If this was the only knowledge that the public had of the state of immigration in this country, they would go off to sleep-as many honourable senators appeared to be doing, especially on the Government side, while the Governor-General was giving his speech. It talks about a whole set of principles which are accepted on all sides in this Parliament. It does not refer at all to the issues such as were raised by Senator Walsh and reported widely in the press even as recently as yesterday.

Senator Walsh is not only speaking out on economic issues but also he is speaking out on the question of immigration, and half the Labor Party want to shut him up-including Mr Hand and the Prime Minister. But on the other hand, those from the Centre Left, including the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, or even those of the Left, such as the honourable member for Cunningham, Mr West-and, for all I know, Senator Cook and Senator Tate, who are sitting here in the chamber-want to listen carefully to what their esteemed colleague wants to be saying because, frankly, Senator Walsh has been in the Cabinet for the last seven years, he has observed the way decisions have been made and he is alert to the inadequacy of these dramatic decisions by the Prime Minister and the way in which Mr Hand has been appointed and other changes have been made to the Department and to policy.

Senator Walsh has blown the whistle on the Hawke Labor Government on immigration. Senator Walsh has said that immigration decisions by this Government are in disarray. We hear of the changes related to vote buying by Labor instead of actions being taken in the national interest, and that seems to be one of a number of the decisions of the Labor Government about which Senator Walsh is rightly critical.

I have not time to refer to the Opposition's contribution to the regulation review through the select committee. I note, however, that there was no public consultation during that review. There were some select submissions made, but all on a confidential basis. There was a compressed time of only six weeks to consider the draft regulations. There were serious deficiencies about review, about the exercising of compassion, and about a whole range of particular issues related to visas. The Opposition members on that select committee were Mr Ruddock, the shadow Minister; Mrs Sullivan; Mr Cobb; and me. In mid-December we urged the Minister to defer the legislation and we said we would facilitate amendments concerning the operation of the legislation so that the whole mess could be put right during January, February and March, if necessary, before the new Act came into effect. But he did not take up our genuine offer.

I wish to refer now in particular to some pages of the Minister's statement. The preamble is very brief. It does not even mention the FitzGerald report. It does not mention the Opposition's insistence on crucial amendments to the primary Act, amended in June last year. It does not mention the actual reports of the parliamentary committee. However, it does give the three principal reasons why the legislation was reformulated. On page 2 of the statement there is an admission of confusion and failure. In the second paragraph there are these words:
This resulted in a lack of clarity-
that is a euphemism by Minister Hand for confusion-
and, in a number of cases, unintended consequences.

That is his best euphemism for failure. The Minister sets out on that page some basic objectives of the immigration program under his superintendence, and certainly there is no controversy about those basic objectives on any side of the Parliament. On page 3 he refers to the ministerial review and I note that in the fifth paragraph he sets out a new set of criteria for ministerial intervention in immigration decisions. He talks about a serious reason being required, quite rightly, but then refers to `a gap in policy', `unintended consequence' and `special consideration'. These three phrases are new; they are therefore very important in determining those matters which the Minister will bring to this Parliament in the six-monthly reports which he has announced.

On pages 4 and 5 the Minister talks about the first phase of decisions to change the present immigration system and to overcome the mess. Every one of those changes, those phase one announcements, whether it concerns the review procedure, the reestablishment of a joint parliamentary committee, the necessity for the Minister to report regularly to Parliament and the content of those reports, or particular administrative changes, is responding to the parliamentary committee's recommendations to his predecessor, Senator Ray.

Phase two concerns those decisions to be put in place between August and December this year. It addresses the need for up-to-date departmental manuals; the question of asylum, in particular Chinese nationals' temporary residence in Australia following the events in Tiananmen; the definitions in the regulations relating to health, to spouses, to marriage; and some change of status matters. Again, all of those matters are responding to the select committee. Finally there is the general redrafting of the Act and indeed the vocabulary of the regulations themselves. The Opposition has no trouble with the suggestions that are made there because they have been in fact sponsored by us.
I conclude by saying that this whole statement is further evidence of the failure of the Hawke Labor Government to bring public confidence back to immigration in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats welcome the statement of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) because it vindicates the stand taken by the Democrats on the Migration Amendment Act of June 1989 and the regulations tabled on 19 December last year. It seems that we may be able to replace bureaucratic nonsense with sensible and realistic criteria. The Minister's statement is virtually a complete backdown. The very title gives the game away: Review of Migration Legislation. In the past two years we have been through the process of the FitzGerald review of immigration procedures, the Government's response, the Migration Legislation Amendment Bills, and finally the promulgation of the regulations.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Government concedes in this title to the statement that a review of migration legislation has become necessary demonstrates that the whole thing has been a monumental disaster. I have said on a number of occasions that I believe that the legislation was written by bureaucrats for bureaucrats, and I would go further and say that the Immigration Department has hoodwinked a succession of Ministers in the past and I believe that Senator Ray has been their most gullible victim. This statement by the Minister gives hope, I believe, to the Senate that finally the interests of the Australian community at large may be served, rather than the interests of bureaucratic procedures. I would also ask why if, as is stated on page 4 of the statement, the regulations work reasonably well, a major review is necessary and why has the machinery of the Parliament been passed over in favour of an arbitrary departmental review?

I would further ask, why not rewrite the whole Act now, as recommended by FitzGerald, which should have been done in 1989? Indeed, as was said in May 1989 by the Democrats, the legislation significantly infringes human rights, But this is more than a technical problem. The whole thrust of the Act and regulations discriminates against human rights in favour of economic and bureaucratic criteria.

We learn on page 5 of the statement that an applicant will be refunded any fee paid to the Tribunal, if the Tribunal finds in his favour. But since the Tribunal acts to enforce regulations derived from the public interest, I ask why should the appellant pay at all? Prospective immigrants and immigration officers will be most relieved to read on page 5 of the statement that the Minister will reduce the complexity of the application procedures by collapsing the current 97 entry permits classes down to a possible seven.

The unofficial consolidation of migration regulations, which was put together after 19 December last year and which I received in January, contains some 130 pages. There are 195 regulations and eight schedules. There is a section on fees and there are some 27 migration review regulations. Immigration officers have found it extremely difficult to apply the details of the regulations and we have all read reports in the newspapers during the last few months about that. Prospective migrants have been given in some cases false information, in others misleading information, and in others misleading advice and conflicting advice. Indeed, it has been a nightmare for all concerned.

The immediate former Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Robert Ray, may well say that it seemed to be a good idea at the time. But when he stated that there might be changes to the regulations, he flagged this last year during the debate in December and it was flagged again in the newspapers. But here we read on page 6 of the statement of present Minister Hand that these changes will meet a number of the more pressing problems which have emerged.

We read also from the statement that there will be changes to relax certain deadlines. That could have been dealt with in June 1989 when I brought forward some 42 amendments to the then immigration Bill. Some of the changes flagged here by the Minister in his statement could have been dealt with last year. Some of these problems need never have arisen and I would say should never have arisen.

We learn from the statement that there will be provision for the waiver of appeal fees in hardship cases and in special compassionate circumstances. This again was flagged nearly a year ago by the Democrats in debate.

We read in the statement that in compassionate circumstances there will certainly no longer be requirements which are unnecessarily harsh and arbitrary; as far as illegal entrants are concerned, compelling compassionate circumstance will be given consideration. The Government has heard a great deal of criticism of the operation of parts of the new system. It heard it not only from the Democrats last year but also from knowledgeable immigration law specialists when the Act was first introduced and later when the regulations became public.

I believe the Minister did go into this with a good heart. Indeed, in December 1988, in the Government's response to the Fitzgerald committee report, the Minister said that changes from that time would be demonstrably open, consistent and equitable, with no more decisions being made behind closed doors. In the attempt to codify the immigration procedures in these regulations it has been found that it has not been possible to do that. The Government was warned and the Minister was warned, but no attention was paid to those warnings.

The regulations were tabled in December last and since that time we have had what I think could be termed one almighty mess as far as our immigration procedures are concerned. I will refer to a few details in the paper.

The Minister said, `Large sections of the new Act and regulations are now being administered smoothly'. I think from the remarks I have previously made and those made by Senator Teague that the public at large would realise that that statement must be taken with a big pinch of salt. I must also be critical of the Opposition, because both the Opposition and the Democrats realised last year from our first reading of the legislation when it first came forward-I believe it was introduced in March-that it simply could not work as it was and the fact that it depended on so many regulations which at that time were totally unseen meant that it would be extremely difficult to administer. As Senator Teague said when he spoke, at a later time the Opposition came to an arrangement with the Government and the legislation was subsequently passed in the Senate in June. But those amendments were simply not enough. I would say that the Opposition, by aiding and abetting the Government in the way that it did when the legislation was passed, has brought us further to the situation in which we now find ourselves. I deeply regret that the Opposition could not support any of the 42 amendments that I brought forward last year.

On page 2 of the statement Minister Hand talks about unintended consequences. Well, the Government was warned time and time again. The consequences may have been unintended by the Government, but certainly they were brought to its attention on a number of occasions last year and, as Senator Teague has said, also by the joint committee. Again on page 2 we read that the Minister will have the discretion to respond sensitively and with compassion when individual cases arise that require special consideration. The Government had the opportunity to make provision for that in the legislation so that it would have been before the Parliament and it could have been debated properly and not been dependent on regulations and I point out that we have not yet seen the regulations in their final form. I commend the Minister for stating in this paper that we are unlikely to see them for at least another 12 months. By now the Minister and the Department must have realised that the situation is so complex that it simply cannot be cobbled together at the last moment. The Minister says that the Department has to have in place proper administrative procedures. We all realised that, of course, and found the regulations in their cobbled together state most improper and very awkward to deal with.
On page 3 the Minister states:

. . . we must distinguish between those people who become illegal quite innocently and unintentionally through ignorance of proper procedures, and those who exploit every loophole in immigration policies to stay on in Australia even though they have no right to do so.

Of course we must. But in the original regulations and in the legislation there appears to be no intention to distinguish between those who became illegal innocently and those who did so deliberately. In fact, the regulations dealing with that particular aspect were unnecessarily draconian right around. The statement says:
The other main objective was that of removing from the Minister the almost intolerable burden of being a court of appeal . . .

Yet the Minister, by giving himself discretion, and also discretion not to use that discretion, as it states in this paper, still leave, that in some disarray. We read that the Minister has the powers under sections 115 and 137 of the Migration Act to set aside decisions at each review stage. Way back last year I argued that discretion must be available at all stages of the review process because it is quite impossible to codify every possible event in human lives and every possible event and complication that can arise when people seek or are forced to seek migration to Australia. What must be most welcomed is that the Minister now must report to the Parliament if he changes decisions and this must be done openly, and that any changes made by the review panels and the Review Tribunal must also be reported to the Parliament. What has been unconscionable has been the move toward there being no parliamentary accountability as far as our immigration procedures are concerned.
The Minister says, on page 3:
There has been a considerable amount of criticism of the Regulations on the grounds that they are inflexible, harsh and overly complex.

Well, that again is nothing recent. Three phases are mooted, three changes which will occur in three phases. The first phase will give greater access to review rights under the transitional arrangements. That was a matter which has caused particular concern to a number of people, professionals in the area and also those with great concerns in the area-that we have a transitional period while we move from one system of immigration to another, and that people have been denied their review rights. I am very pleased to see that that will change, and Minister Hand is to be commended for foreshadowing those changes.

A Bill is foreshadowed, a Bill which will amend the Migration Act to ensure that the Minister's discretion to make a decision after the first tier can only be exercised at the request of the applicant and where the Minister is prepared to make a decision agreeable to the applicant. Also, the Minister will seek to overcome `an anomalous situation with regard to review fees'. As I said before, I believe, and the Democrats believe, that the whole area of review fees needs to be looked at very thoroughly. There seems to be a fee for virtually having a page turned over and, indeed, prospective migrants to this country will now find it extremely difficult if they cannot front up with fee money as required all the way along the line, especially if reviews are to be involved.

The Joint Committee will be re-formed, and that is to be greatly welcomed. Also, the Parliament will have the opportunity to review and scrutinise reports put forward by the Committee. I regret very much also that the two reports put out by the Committee, after a great deal of work and after a great number of meetings both during parliamentary sessions and out of those sessions, have not yet come before the Senate.
In a final conclusion, I would refer back to 14 December last year, when I moved and the Senate passed the following motion:

That . . . the Senate condemns the Government for setting in motion the process of making complex and weighty Migration Amendment Legislation which depends heavily on Regulations, which are themselves equally complex and weighty, without first giving the Parliament a proper opportunity to scrutinise and approve those Regulations.

That amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Migration Legislation Amendment (Consequential Amendments) Bill of December last year was passed by the Senate, and although Senator Ray described it as one of the grossest inaccuracies ever carried by the Senate, I believe that the words given here by Senator Teague and myself belie that absolutely.

The Minister's statement is a bald admission that the legislation was hasty, inadequate and inflexible, as we argued way back in 1989. It is a bald admission that the Department has not yet got its act together in a number of ways. At this stage the Government should be launching into an independent review of the objectives, standards and culture of the Immigration Department. The Democrats believe that if this is not done soon, no amount of amended legislation or amended regulations brought forward bit by bit will solve our current problems. It is necessary for the Minister to exercise authority here and to cease being mystified and/or misled by officers of the Department. Indeed, I would agree with Senator Teague that statements should be made in this Senate and in the Parliament as a whole as to exactly what has happened in the Department this year and why we have the sackings of major people in the Department.

Nonetheless, I commend Mr Hand for his political common sense in tabling the statement today. At least we have an expression of problems that exist. At least we have a paper before us which, although inadequate, must be regarded as a first step to at last moving in a more sensible direction and not moving at a pace at which I believe neither the Parliament nor the Department nor the Minister were capable of putting forward sensible legislation and regulations. It is to be regretted that those regulations were brought forward on 19 December in such a hurry.

When I asked the Minister what would be the consequences of delaying the tabling of those regulations, I was told that all the pamphlets, the brochures, the booklets and the explanations were ready to go and there would be absolute chaos if they were not tabled at that time. In fact, we now find, in this statement, that one of the reasons given by the Minister for the messy state of affairs since the tabling of those regulations is that the officers have not been able to be correctly and properly briefed. So I would suggest that there was not a straightforward understanding last year of what the situation actually was, and it would have been much better for the legislation not to have been passed in haste, as it was in the first half of last year, and for there to have been proper consultations with all parties concerned, and then we would not be wasting time backtracking continuously and now having, at this late stage a review of migration legislation. Unfortunately, it is necessary, and I am sure that the Committee will continue to do its best to help the immigration area by putting forward regulations and amended legislation so that our Department can get itself out of its chaotic situation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
