DEBATE.TITLE: PETROLEUM (AUSTRALIA-INDONESIA ZONE OF COOPERATION) BILL 1990PETROLEUM (AUSTRALIA-INDONESIA ZONE OF COOPERATION) (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Cook) agreed to:
That these Bills may proceed without formalities, may be considered together and be now read a first time.
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That these Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
PETROLEUM (AUSTRALIA-INDONESIA ZONE OF COOPERATION) BILL 1990

The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to the `Treaty between Australia and the Republic of Indonesia on the Zone of Cooperation in an area between The Indonesian Province of East Timor and Northern Australia' which was signed on 11= December 1989.

The introduction of the Petroleum (Australia-Indonesia Zone of Cooperation) Bill is required to fulfil certain of our obligations under the Treaty and in particular to enable the Ministerial Council and Joint Authority to exercise the rights and responsibilities prescribed in relation to the exploration for, and exploitation of petroleum resources in Area A of the Zone of Cooperation.

Meanwhile the Petroleum (Australia-Indonesia Zone of Cooperation) (Consequential Provisions) Bill provides a series of amendments to legislation that would otherwise be inconsistent with certain provisions of the Treaty.
The Treaty has a ten year history. Negotiations with Indonesia over sea-bed boundaries in 1971-72 left unsettled the delimitation of the sea-bed boundary in the Timor Gap area.

Negotiations were reopened in February 1979. After several rounds of talks, however, it became clear that it would be difficult to reconcile the two countries' competing sea-bed boundary claims. Both Governments subsequently began exploring the possibility of a provisional `joint development' regime for petroleum resources, to operate pending final agreement on the precise boundary. The concept of a Zone of Cooperation was then developed, whereby both countries would jointly invite contractors to explore for and exploit petroleum resources under production sharing contracts in the disputed area.

Agreement on the text of the Treaty, which is incorporated as the Schedule to the Petroleum (Australia-Indonesia Zone of Cooperation) Bill, was reached by officials on 27 October 1989. The formal signing by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, and the Indonesian Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Ali Alatas, took place on 11 December 1989.

The Timor Gap Treaty is the most substantial bilateral agreement concluded in the forty year history of Australia's relations with Indonesia. The Treaty represents a unique approach to the settlement on a provisional basis of a dispute over territorial delimitation. This constructive approach has established a basis for cooperative exploration for and exploitation of petroleum resources which would otherwise have been indefinitely delayed by efforts to define a single boundary line. The Zone of Cooperation is an area of very high prospectivity.

The zone of cooperation consists of three areas. Area A is the area of joint development where the control of petroleum operations will be exercised by a Ministerial Council and a Joint Authority on behalf of Australia and the Republic of Indonesia. The Joint Authority will be responsible for the day-to-day management of petroleum operations in Area A and will report directly to the Ministerial Council, a body comprised of an equal number of Australian and Indonesian Ministers.

Area B is the area of sole Australian jurisdiction, but Australia will pay 10 per cent of gross Resource Rent Tax revenues from this area to Indonesia and notify Indonesia about petroleum operations in the Area. Area C is the area of sole Indonesian jurisdiction, and Indonesia will notify Australia about petroleum operations in that Area and will pay 10 per cent of its Contractor's Income Tax Revenues from this Area to Australia.

This Bill, together with the Petroleum (Australia-Indonesia Zone of Cooperation) (Consequential Provisions) Bill, is therefore directed at making Australian law consistent with the provisions of the Treaty. The Treaty includes four annexes. Annex A provides maps and the coordinates of the Zone of Cooperation. Annex B is the `Petroleum Mining Code for Area A of the Zone of Cooperation' which governs operational activities relating to exploration for and exploitation of petroleum resources. Annex C is the `Model Production Sharing Contract between the Joint Authority and (Contractors)', being the basis on which production sharing contracts for Area A should be concluded. Annex D is the `Taxation Code for the Avoidance of Double Taxation in Respect of Activities Connected with Area A of the Zone of Cooperation'.

The principal financial impact will be the prospective receipt of sales proceeds by Australia from the production sharing arrangements. The basic principle of the Treaty is that the Joint Authority, exercises the rights of the two countries in the exploration for and exploitation of their petroleum in Area A of the Zone of Cooperation. The Joint Authority is to enter into contracts with corporations to explore for and produce petroleum. In return, these contractors will receive a share of the petroleum produced, to which they will acquire ownership at the point of tanker loading.

Primary responsibility for the marketing of petroleum rests with the contractor. There are, however, safeguards to ensure that petroleum is marketed at world prices. Provision is made under the Model Production Sharing Contract for the Joint Authority to determine the value of petroleum sold by the contractor to purchasers, such as affiliates, that are not third parties. In addition, the Joint Authority may market any or all of the petroleum produced with the approval of the Ministerial Council, when the Joint Authority can receive a better price than the contractors.

The method of sharing petroleum production between the contractor and the Joint Authority is provided in Section 7 of the Model Production Sharing Contract. This provides for three progressive stages in this sharing of crude oil production, between the Joint Authority and the contractor. The Joint Authority's share is to be paid intact and in equal shares to Australia and Indonesia. The initial stage is the shared first tranche petroleum. In the next stage, contractor's investment credits and operating costs are recovered from production revenues. The final stage is the sharing of residual production.

First tranche petroleum amounts to 10 per cent of crude oil production during the first five years of production and thereafter 20 per cent. On oil production up to a daily average rate of 50,000 barrels per day, this first tranche petroleum is to be shared in the ratio 50:50 between the Joint Authority and the contractor. For the next 100,000 barrels per day of production first tranche petroleum is to be shared in the ratio 60:40 between the Joint Authority and the contractor; and for production above 150,000 barrels per day the respective sharing ratios are 70:30.

The second stage provides the contractor with production equal in value to investment credits of 127 per cent of exploration and capital costs together with all operating costs, including exploration costs and depreciation of capital costs.

The third stage allocates residual production once investment credits and operating costs are recovered. The split of this production is based on the same progressive sharing arrangements between the Joint Authority and the contractor as applies to the allocation of first tranche petroleum.

The revenues from first tranche natural gas production are shared constantly 50:50 between the Joint Authority and the contractor. Following the recovery of investment credits and operating costs, residual natural gas production is again shared in the 50:50 ratio.

An additional and prospectively significant financial impact is the taxation receipt from business profits derived from Area A. Both countries' will apply their taxation legislation to contractors deriving profits from their operations in Area A but in such a way that only 50 per cent of business profits and losses are taken into account by each country. As noted, Australia is obliged by its Treaty obligations to pay 10 per cent of its gross Resource Rent Tax revenue from Area B to Indonesia. Neither revenues from production sharing, nor taxation receipts from business profits from petroleum operations in Area A, can be estimated until more is known of the petroleum potential of Area A.

A third element in this overview of financial impacts is that the provisions to apply to individuals working in Area A provide that residents of Australia will be subject to Australian taxes, and residents of Indonesia will be subject to Indonesian taxes. Double taxation provisions apply to business profits and salaries of individuals who are residents of neither Australia nor Indonesia.

The Joint Authority will be self funding from contract fees. Such fees will not, however, be receivable until contract bids are received and contracts are subsequently awarded. This may not occur until some twelve months after the Treaty enters into force. The final element in the financial impact of implementation of the Treaty is therefore the initial working capital for the Joint Authority estimated at $US2m. Australia is required to advance its half share or $US1m. It is anticipated that this advance will be repaid within five years. The scope of the Treaty extends well beyond production sharing, taxation and the arrangements for the Ministerial Council and Joint Authority. The Treaty, under Articles 12 to 30, covers the range of issues likely to be encountered in the exploration for and exploitation of petroleum.

These include the prevention and minimisation of, and liability of contractors for, pollution of the marine environment. For this purpose and civil claims generally, the legislation provides that State and Territory courts are vested with federal jurisdiction in relation to acts or omissions done in Area A resulting in damage or liability suffered by Australians. This will include liability for the pollution of the marine environment.

There are a range of other Articles in the Treaty covering other activities, contingencies and potential developments arising out of the exploration for and exploitation of petroleum in Area A. These include surveillance, security measures, search and rescue, air traffic services, and health and safety for workers. These and other issues will be dealt with through a range of rules, regulations and procedures required by the Treaty.

This package of legislation gives effect to the Treaty and its Annexes which govern all aspects of the exploration for and exploitation of petroleum in Area A of the Zone of Cooperation. The regime established by the Treaty for Area A of the Zone of Cooperation is unique compared with similar joint development zones in other parts of the world in both the complexity and comprehensive nature of its provisions. The joint nature of those provisions do not simply replicate the system existing in either Australia or Indonesia, but combine features of both in an innovative and practical arrangement.
This legislation gives effect to a substantive and complex Treaty which allows this vital cooperative effort with Indonesia to proceed.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators and present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill and the Petroleum (Australia-Indonesia Zone of Cooperation) (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1990.
PETROLEUM (AUSTRALIA-INDONESIA ZONE OF COOPERATION) (C0NSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1990

This Bill provides a series of amendments to legislation that would otherwise be inconsistent with the provisions of the `Treaty Between Australia and the Republic of Indonesia on the Zone of Cooperation in an area between The Indonesian Province of East Timor and Northern Australia'. The text of the Treaty is the schedule to the Petroleum (Australia-Indonesia Zone of Cooperation) Bill 1990, or Treaty Bill.

These amendments relate to legislation pertaining to the exploration for and exploitation of petroleum in Area A of the Zone of Cooperation. Area A is the area of joint development where a Ministerial Council and a Joint Authority will exercise the rights and responsibilities of Australia and Indonesia in relation to the exploration for an exploitation of petroleum.

The Crimes at Sea Act is amended so that it applies in Area A consistent with Article 27 of the Treaty. Northern Territory criminal law will apply to offences by Australians, while Indonesian law will apply to Indonesians. The provisions, consistent with the Treaty, deal also with persons who are neither permanent residents nor nationals of either Australia or Indonesia.

Other parts of this Consequential Provisions Bill are provided to make Australian legislation consistent with Articles of the Treaty dealing with the application of customs, migration and quarantine laws, industrial relations issues and changes required to permits which had been issued under the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act in Area A.

The Customs Act is amended consistent with Article 23 to make it an offence, without authorisation, for persons or goods to be brought directly to or from a resource installation in Area A without first entering or returning to either Australia or Indonesia. Goods taken to, or brought from Area A, for use in petroleum operations are not liable to customs duty, but are subject to duty if they are transferred permanently from Area A to another part of Australia.

Amendments to the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act and the Income Tax Assessment Act ensure that the anti-avoidance measures provided in these Acts are not diminished by the Treaty or the Taxation Code.

The Industrial Relations Act amendment provides for employment contracts and collective agreements entered into under Article 24 of the Treaty to specify the Australian Industrial Relations Commission as an available mechanism for the settlement of disputes.

The Migration Act is amended to allow control of persons moving onto and from resource installations in Area A and by regulation to allow the application of that Act in Area A if that proves necessary.

The amendments provided to the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967 redefine the scheduled `adjacent area' to exclude Area A of the Zone of Cooperation, and hence place it outside the scope of this Act. These amendments provide that those parts of permit areas extending outside Area A are to be renewed. Provision has been made in the event that compensation is found to be payable in relation to the termination of permit areas in Area A, in terms consistent with paragraph 51 (xxxi) of the Constitution. Legal advice to the Government, however, is that no such compensation will be payable.
The Quarantine Act amendments are similar to those made to the Migration Act. These control persons, goods and equipment leaving or entering Area A for quarantine purposes.

The financial impacts of these amendments are relatively less significant than those relating to the Treaty Bill. The non-liability of goods to customs duty, when used in petroleum operations in Area A, has the potential to relieve importers from duty over a broad range, but generally this exemption from duties would be within the level of 10 per cent to 20 per cent. Until the petroleum potential of Area A is better understood and hence development plans can be prepared, there is no basis on which to estimate the impact of this provision.
The object of these amendments is therefore to apply existing Commonwealth legislation in Area A in a manner which is consistent with the Treaty.

I commend the Bill to honourable senators. I indicated earlier that the Explanatory Memorandum which I presented in relation to the Petroleum (Australia-Indonesia Zone of Cooperation) Bill also covers this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON CERTAIN ASPECTS OF THE AIRLINE PILOTS' DISPUTE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 May, on motion by Senator Cooney:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report arose from a reference made by the Senate on 17 October 1989. Events have rather overtaken the purpose of this inquiry, although some matters can still be drawn from the report and from the events of that time which may be worth following up in the future. Senator Brownhill was anxious to talk about this matter. He told me that he may make some criticism of the way in which the Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Airline Pilots' Dispute was chaired. I was Chairman of that Committee. Many people will be surprised when I read out the list of senators who were members of that Committee because all of them are normally fairly silent in this chamber. They are people of absolute courtesy. Some senators may be surprised to learn that, as members of the Committee, they had the ability to express themselves clearly.
—We may even be shocked.
—Thank you, Senator Cook. The members of the Committee, besides myself and Senator Brownhill, were Senator Collins, Senator MacGibbon, former Senator Sanders, and Senator Schacht.
—A fine bunch of men.
—A fine bunch of men.
—We would not have heard a peep out of any of them.
—We would not have heard much from them in this chamber, but it may surprise the Senate to learn that we heard a lot from them during the Committee's deliberations.

SPEECH.PARA: The airline pilots dispute was quite a tragedy. Indeed, it was more than a tragedy. Some awful things came out of that dispute. It seems to me that the dispute was brought about by a lot of misunderstanding, by many people putting their heads down and charging when they should not have. As a result of the dispute, the community was denied crucial services. The tourist industry was devastated and the pilots themselves underwent an awful trauma.

The report makes no recommendations, mainly because, as I said before, events overtook the inquiry. For example, part of the inquiry concerned whether the military aircraft that were used were safe. By the time we wrote the report, the military aircraft had been taken out of the service that was being provided by the airlines to the public. I think it was agreed that whatever happened during the dispute there was never a time when the air service was unsafe. Differences among Committee members arose out of the question of whether a reduction in safety was one that merited more or less concern.

With regard to the safety of airline travel, Mr Dick Smith made a very important point. He is now the Chairperson of the Civil Aviation Authority. He said that travel by air is 400 times safer than road travel. That point is referred to in paragraph 4.113 of the report. I think we ought to take on board the point that air travel is safer than road travel. A few tragic events in recent times have indicated that that is so. I think that is something from which we can learn in the future. Air travel should be made more readily available to people than it presently is. It saves people from having to travel by road and it is a safer way to travel.

We were asked some legal questions about certain issues. It is very difficult for any Senate committee and, indeed, for the Senate itself, to give any definite legal opinion, simply because we are not the arm of government which is deputised by the Constitution to do that. That seemed to me to raise some problems. In the future, if we refer questions to any committee, we ought to take on board the fact that it is very difficult for the Senate and its committees to express any definitive opinion about legal affairs.

The next point I want to make is that one person interested in the tourism industry was most concerned, as one would expect him to be, about the devastation that the dispute caused to the industry. When asked what solution he would give, he mentioned the invoking of the essential services legislation. Indeed, in this context there was also a common law action taken in Melbourne against the pilots, before Mr Justice Brooking, in which damages were awarded. My view-and I say it in this context-is that common law actions against unions should not be pursued.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not?

—It is very bad to create in an industrial culture a climate where people go round wielding the proverbial big stick. We have heard arguments again and again in this chamber about the need for productivity and the need to get everybody on side, and we certainly do not keep people on side by invoking the law and by trying to bludgeon people into a course of action. I say that in the context where, from our side of the chamber, there was some encouragement at an early stage for taking common law action. I simply state my view that one should not take common law actions in an industrial context and should certainly not invoke the use of sections 45d and 45e.
—Ever? Is that what you are saying?

—I would go close to saying `ever'. If Senator McGauran could put to me a situation where it became blatantly clear that that was called for I would consider it, but I have not seen in recent years the need for any action to be taken where in fact it has been taken.

SPEECH.PARA: So, in my view, we can learn from the strike the following matters: firstly, the need for industrial relations to be conducted in a calm and clear atmosphere and in an atmosphere of goodwill; secondly, if I have a criticism of the action of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots, it is that it conducted its industrial relations and industrial action in an ill-advised fashion. I think the decisions it made were made too late and were too ineffective. When a leadership has the responsibility of guiding workers, be they airline pilots, plumbers or anybody else, it has a responsibility to conduct its industrial action in a way that benefits its members and the community in general.

The next thing I want to say is that air safety has been proved in Australia and, in that context, more thought should be given to enabling more people to travel by air than is presently the situation.

The next thing I say-I have already mentioned this-is that the Senate should not readily refer questions of the legal meaning of things to committees or even deal with them ourselves in the sense of trying to find answers to those issues.

Finally, the Senate very kindly gave the Committee the right to meet while the Senate was sitting. In my view, it is time that that entitlement was extended to all committees. There is more and more sense in the Senate giving permission to the Senate committees to meet during sitting times.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak as one of the two members of the Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Airlines Pilots' Dispute who felt it necessary to dissent from the majority report on both occasions that the Committee presented a report. In saying that, I do not condone the actions of either party in this particular dispute. The dispute was initiated by the actions of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots but we must remember, though, that one month after the dispute started the Federation was prepared to enter into bona fide negotiations to resolve the impasse that had occurred as a result of the initial actions and the actions at that particular stage of the airlines themselves who refused to enter into any negotiations.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not deny the right of the airlines not to enter into any negotiations, but the airlines also had a legal obligation-Senator Cooney talked about the law a minute ago-to provide services within Australia under the two airlines agreement. It amazed me that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who has always been a mediator in strikes and industrial action, did not attempt in a constructive way to bring those two parties together.
Senator Cook interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook cannot tell me he did because he did not. The people of Australia stood by and watched what happened in amazement. Senator Cook has now taken over the Industrial Relations portfolio, so obviously he would now take note of some of the things that have happened in the past to ensure that we make things better in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: The third term of reference related to the nature and extent and legality of the compensation arrangements entered into by the Government and the airlines. This was a highly technical area, a highly technical reference, which required a detailed knowledge of constitutional and statute law. Senator MacGibbon and I wanted and needed expert advice-and so did the rest of the Committee-but the decision of the majority of members of the Committee was to seek advice from the Attorney-General's Department on the legality of the Government's actions in paying compensation to the airlines. It was taxpayers' money that was being paid to the airlines. Since it was the Attorney-General's Department which advised the Government initially, Senator MacGibbon and I viewed it as farcical and irresponsible that the Department should be placed in a position of being the sole arbiter of the Government's actions.

An area that Senator Cooney made mention of a moment ago was the question of safety, which was the main part of the reference. Of course, there is more to safety than just `safety'. As Mr John Calwell, an executive committee member from the New South Wales Technical and Air Safety Working Group of the Guild of Air Pilots and Air Navigators, stated, there is a safety culture, which is just as important as anything else. An essential item of that safety culture is that priority be given to safety over commercial interests. I think it is highly necessary, the way things have turned out and even for the future, that safety have precedence over commercial interests. He went on to say that there should be cooperative attitudes among all sections of the industry, a willingness to apply and abide by the most stringent safety regulations and a career structure which encouraged stability in the industry. That is an area that concerned me in this inquiry.

I have sat on many committees in this Parliament, and I feel that I have always benefited from the opportunity to delve into various subjects and learn more about them in order to help the Australian people concerned. I regret, however, that the same comment cannot be applied to this particular Committee. For a start, my view is that it was always intended by the Government to be a whitewash. There was no real intention to get to the bottom of the issues and no real attempt to question in depth anyone who might have told us what we needed to know. At each turn my colleague Senator MacGibbon and I were confronted with almost a conspiracy of silence. We had the airline executives telling us regularly that flights were almost back to normal when the reality was that they were not. We had flight attendants hampered in what they could tell us because they had to keep their jobs and work with foreign crews, at which so much criticism had been levelled.

We had claim and counterclaim of intimidation and of legal challenges. A great deal of acrimony surrounded this dispute, and that is understandable. There was not, however, in my view, the old Australian concept of fair play.

I will cite one particular example. Early in the sittings of the Committee I had the opportunity to visit with a former public servant who had extensive knowledge of civil aviation operation procedures. He had expressed a willingness to talk with me because he had already spoken and written publicly on issues surrounding the dispute that had disturbed him. But some minutes before I met him he had been handed a libel writ. I guess that means very little to those in public life but to this man it was quite devastating. He was not a young man or in particularly good health. When I saw him he was virtually in a state of shock and fearful that he was about to lose the home and pension that he had secured. The big boys can play rough and dirty if they like but I would have thought the rules are that you pick on someone your own size. In this case that did not happen.

I do not believe this report has brought anything to light. As we say in our dissenting report, we are of the opinion that the approach taken by the Committee lacked objectivity and impartiality. We state further that the participation of the Prime Minister was a significant factor. We do not know his full involvement in the dispute or his reason for it, and perhaps never will. We do not know the motive behind the actions taken by the airlines. We know what the pilots intended and wanted but whether their actions were, in hindsight, unfortunate, ill timed or just ill considered is perhaps for others to judge.

We do know-and we did not need a Committee to tell us-that the tourism industry and the travelling public have suffered enormously. The full impact on society includes the now altered preferred modes of travel. The impact on business structure and viability for so many industries and towns will take years to calculate. This report could have answered many questions. I regret that it did not. It now remains for the evolution of time to disclose the real story behind it all and what effect it has had and will have on the airline industry and all that that incorporates.

With deregulation just about to start we will all wonder whether it was worth while, whether it was necessary and whether, if the Government had really tried, the two combatants in the dispute could not have been brought to the table when they wanted to get to the table so that the dispute did not cost so much to the Australian community and to the Australian economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the presentation of the report of the Senate Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Airline Pilots' Dispute, which was a select committee set up toward the end of last year when we were experiencing the most expensive strike in Australia's history and arguably the most mismanaged industrial relations exercise by any government in the history of this nation.

SPEECH.PARA: The dispute is not over yet but in the nine or 10 months it has been running it has already cost this country billions of dollars. It has had a major impact on our reputation overseas as a tourist destination. It has sent hundreds of thousands of people in the tourist industry out of jobs and made them bankrupt. In many ways the accounts are not yet in for the consequence of this dispute. There is also a very great indirect cost. One of the tragedies of the dispute is that, because only about 4 to 6 per cent of the Australian community fly, the great majority of Australians were not aware of the direct impact of the strike, let alone the consequences on our balance of payments.

There is also a very great indirect cost which is most marked on the professional core of pilots who provide an essential skill in a highly developed community. Over 350 of those pilots, the cream of the internal airline pilots of this country, have gone to overseas airlines. Malaysian Airline System, Singapore Airlines Ltd and Cathay Pacific Ltd have picked the cream, the eyes, out of our best pilots. Gulf Air, Taiwan Airlines, the second Korean airline, a number of European airlines and some American airlines have also benefited. The Malaysian airline took all the check and training captains out of Australian Airlines Ltd, and that is why Australian Airlines had such a very difficult job getting re-established afterwards, because the heart of their piloting expertise had gone.

So, through the stupidity of the Government and the way that it mishandled the dispute, we subsidised our competitors in the international routes in our region with millions of dollars in transferring those people. To the 350-plus pilots who resigned to work overseas must be added a similar number, or more, of pilots who took premature retirement rather than stand up to the bullying tactics of Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines. Somewhere near half the pilot core in this country left the industry and we are left with a bunch of people who have nowhere near the experience and expertise to fulfil what is a highly technical job.

Another thing that has not dawned on the Australian Labor Party yet is that its actions have changed the face of industrial relations forever in this country because the ALP, the great protagonist of the unionists and proponents of stand-over tactics in industrial relations, used the Australian Defence Force as strike breakers. It ran the Royal Australian Air Force and Royal Australian Navy around the country as strike breakers. That is unheard of and absolutely unconscionable. The Services in this country exist to defend it and to render aid to the civil authorities when there is an emergency, not to get involved in commercial operations and least of all to subsidise the Government's old mates in Australian Airlines and Ansett by offering ridiculously low charter rates for aircraft.

What else did the Government do? It brought in overseas labour-not Australian scab labour but overseas scab labour-to break the strike. What is worse, compounding that, it resorted to common law actions. No wonder Senator Cooney is uncomfortable about that. He has spent a lifetime making a living out of union relations, defending unionists when they tried to take on the community in various ways and blackmail it. He finds that, under common law, the Government of which he is a member is suing people-under common law-who dared to withhold their services. Voluntary employment agreements have been introduced-things that the Goss Labor Government in Queensland is now trying to eliminate.

That is all good basic stuff from an industrial relations point of view but it is very difficult for the Labor Party to defend. I think that we on this side of the chamber can be grateful because when we get into government and are faced with recalcitrant unions we have a precedent we can follow with great equanimity.

Despite doing all those things the Government refused to recognise the national interest, which was to resolve the dispute. The dispute could have been resolved from 12 September onwards, within a one-month period of the dispute coming on. The evidence that was given to the Select Committee showed-and it was never refuted-that members of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots were prepared to enter into negotiations with their employers to resume their services. Not once did the employers negotiate with them. Not once would the Government say to the employers, `For the national good, see if you cannot reach agreement'.

Today what is the position? We are not back to normal yet. Before the dispute Cairns in my own State used to have 23 flights a day. There are about eight now. People who want to fly to Rockhampton or Mackay just have to fly when the airline wants to run its one service a day. All of this is because we had a Government that colluded with management to pursue whatever goals management had at the time. Anyone who doubts that there was collusion between the Government and the airlines should look at the ridiculous gift rates that the Government charged the airlines for the charter of the Air Force aircraft and Navy aircraft at the time.

One of the ironies of it all is that everyone has forgotten now what the strike was about. It occurred because the airline pilots wanted a raise and the Government said they could only have 6 per cent. The contracts that were signed-and Senator Cooney is smiling at this-provided at least a 30 per cent rise. The contracts that the Government approved provided at least a 30 per cent increase in the salaries of the pilots. Today pilots who are flying for Ansett and Australian are now getting between $175,000 and $200,000 per annum.

Some of those pilots have exceeded or are exceeding their flying hours and they are looking forward to three months holiday. In other words, the Government's action in refusing a price rise has given at least a 30 per cent increase to airline pilots and, in some cases, it has given them a 100 per cent increase.

Senator Brownhill talked about the dishonesty in the evidence given to us by the airline management. They lied about the services that were being offered and being flown around Australia. They also misled us about the number of pilots they had. Some of their management practices are open to doubt. I want to put before the Senate one case of a pilot who flew for TAA between 1970 and 1978. He was dismissed because he was mentally unstable. He reapplied and he was refused re-employment with TAA. Then, after the dispute, he came back, and he was signed on. He was dismissed again when they found out how bad he was. Then he made some death threats and the whole thing went public. The interesting point is that the management has been at pains to play down the death threats. No-one has answered on behalf of the company why this man, who was fired because he was mentally unstable, was ever re-employed. I would have thought that a general manager of that company would have had the resignation of the personnel manager and the chief pilot on his desk before sunset on the day that was discovered.

I also want to say something about the Civil Aviation Authority and the Federal Airports Corporation, because these are two statutory authorities that were set up by this Labor Government in the guise that they are independent. Both bent over backwards to cooperate with whatever the Government's policy was at the time. The CAA was very badly caught out in a regulatory role and it acceded to any requests the companies made in the early part of the dispute. Later it took fright when it realised what it was doing and it tried to apply the letter of the law, but it certainly did not operate as an independent authority. The same applies for the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation, which operated as an organ of the Government's propaganda in not enforcing standards at the time.

This is one of the shabbiest exercises in industrial relations we have seen. It has cost the country billions of dollars. It has, as Senator Brownhill said, reduced the margin of safety that formerly existed in the Australian airline services. We now have airlines manned by pilots who lack the experience of those before the dispute. We have aircraft manned by crews that lack the morale, the cohesion and the goodwill that existed before the strike. It is my fervent wish that this country gets through the next two or three years in these disturbed circumstances without having a major accident.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

That consideration of committee reports be not further proceeded with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I present the report of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs entitled Accommodation for People with Disabilities, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The Senate referred the matter of accommodation for people with disabilities to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs in June 1989 during the Senate's consideration of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1989.

At that time, the Committee was inquiring into a related matter-the employment of people with disabilities. The Committee decided to examine both matters together and scheduled an extensive series of public hearings and visits between August and November last year. The program was disrupted, however, by the pilots' dispute as it became impossible to form a quorum for all but a few hearings. The Committee decided to defer further consideration of the employment inquiry in order to meet the reporting deadline for the accommodation inquiry of the first sitting day in March 1990.

The Committee held nine days of hearings and inspections in January to complete the accommodation inquiry. The announcement of the Federal elections in February made it impossible, however, for the committee to finalise its consideration of the report prior to the election.

Although point (a) of the Committee's terms of reference specifically referred to intellectual disability, the rest of the terms of reference did not restrict the Committee to that one type of disability. As the Disability Services Act refers to intellectual, physical, sensory and psychiatric disabilities, the Committee encompassed all those four types of disability in its inquiry.

Prior to the enactment of the Disability Services Act in 1986, Commonwealth funding of accommodation for people with disabilities was largely restricted to the funding of hostels and nursing homes under the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act 1974 and the Nursing Homes Assistance Act 1974.

For some time, there has been a growing realisation that nursing homes, hostels and institutions were no longer appropriate forms of accommodation for people with disabilities. They largely segregated people with disabilities from the rest of the community, restricted their lifestyles and offered few opportunities for choice.

In 1984 the present Commonwealth Government set up the Handicapped Programs Review. After an exhaustive inquiry and consultations, a report entitled `New Directions' was issued in 1985, recommending radical changes to assistance programs for people with disabilities. These changes were incorporated in the Disability Services Act 1986.

Section 5 of this Act made provision for Principles and Objectives. These were issued separately and gazetted on 9 June 1987. The Principles state that people with disabilities have the same right as other members of Australian society including the right to receive services in a manner which results in the least restriction of their rights and opportunities.

These rights contained in the Principles under the Act give effect to the provisions of the Declaration of the Rights of Disabled Persons proclaimed by the General Assembly of the United Nations on 9 December 1975.
The Principles and Objectives received overwhelming support throughout our inquiry.

An area of contention during the inquiry was whether people with severe or profound disabilities could cope with living in the community instead of in a hostel, nursing home or institution. Any concern that such people could not live in group homes was dispelled during the Committee's visits. Members of the Committee met people with profound multiple disabilities who had successfully adjusted to community living after having spent a long time in an institution.

The Committee also received evidence from many people and organisations about the successful transition of people with different types and levels of disability from hostels or nursing homes to small group homes or other types of community accommodation. For example, the Nulsen Haven Association, a service organisation in Perth told the Committee:

We noticed some very significant changes . . . With the people themselves, their whole life has changed and the quality of life has improved. Their daily routines are more flexible; they fit in with their needs, not with the needs of a larger accommodation option. They have developed some very special social networks in the community which are very valuable.

It is essential that people who move out of hostels or nursing homes have access to any training they need and are given enough support on an ongoing basis to enable them to live in group homes or other types of community-based accommodation.

The level of support will vary for each individual. It will probably change over time, reducing for many people as they settle in to community living, but increasing for other people with progressive disabilities, such as muscular dystrophy.

Under the Disability Services Act, the support needs of all consumers will be assessed individually and will vary according to the type and severity of the disabilities. Although the Government has set notional maximum levels of financial support, additional support will be given if a service provider can demonstrate the need for it. The Department of Community Services and Health has assured the Committee that it is trying to maintain as much flexibility as possible, in keeping with the spirit of the legislation and its Principles and Objectives.

The Committee was required to compare the cost of funding the types of accommodation funded under the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act and the Nursing Homes Assistance Act with the types of accommodation eligible for funding under section 10 of the Disability Services Act.

The Committee found that it was too early to make any realistic assessment of comparative costs. Most nursing homes and hostels had yet to undergo their formal reviews with the Department of Community Services and Health. Until those reviews are held, and changes to accommodation agreed to by the service providers and the Department, it will be impossible to assess both transitional and recurrent costs.

The Committee received evidence from service providers who have made the transition to community-based services that, generally speaking, recurrent costs for community homes have been lower than those of nursing homes, except where higher support needs have had to be met.

In planning a transition to community-based accommodation, service providers and government need to take account of the availability of generic services, such as medical and dental services, shops and transport. Access to such services will help people with disabilities to participate as fully as possible in the wider community and will avoid the dispersal of scarce disability funds into services which duplicate those already available in the community.

The Committee believes that the programs designed to provide support to keep people with disabilities in their own homes, such as Home and Community Care, the Attendant Care Scheme, or the 325 Program, should be expanded to cater for the growing demand for those services.

The Disability Services Act is based on a flexible approach to types of accommodation for people with disabilities which may be funded under the Act, provided that they adhere to the Principles and Objectives. The Act does not prescribe the number of people who can live together, but the Department of Community Services and Health told the Committee that it would become increasingly more difficult for a service provider to show that accommodation was consistent with normal community living as numbers in a house increased above about five or six.

People with disabilities should have a choice in the type of accommodation in which they live and it must be an informed choice. If a person is to choose between different types of accommodation, that person must either have had experience of those types or have been given suitable training beforehand, with support from parents or advocates when needed.

The provision of adequate respite care services is an integral part of ensuring that quality care is available for people with disabilities. The availability of planned or emergency respite care enables many people with disabilities to stay with family or other carers rather than live in accommodation provided by a service organisation.

The Committee supports the principles of the separation of services to reduce the possibility of any one service provider exercising undue control over a person's life. Where it is necessary for an organisation to provide more than one service, it should be treated as an exception to the rule. When an alternative service becomes available, it should be substituted.

The total number of people with disabilities in Australia is not known. The Department of Community Services and Health assessed the number as about 93,000 who might qualify for assistance under the Disability Services Act. The large majority of these people do not receive any assistance under the Act, although some might receive State Government support.

The Committee was told by many service providers during the inquiry that they had waiting lists of people who were seeking supported accommodation. Although the names of some people would appear on waiting lists of a number of service providers, there is, nevertheless, an unmet need for government support.

In addition, the Department told the Committee that there is an unmet demand for support under the 325 Program, the Attendant Care Scheme and Home and Community Care. The Department of Community Services and Health can only support disability services within the limits of the annual budget for the Disability Services Program.

The Committee therefore recommends that sufficient funding be provided in the Budget for the Disability Services Program to ensure that adequate resources are available to support people with disabilities when they move to community housing.

The Committee received evidence that there has been a lack of co-ordination in some States and Territories between Commonwealth and State officials and between different State departments. Many service providers receive assistance from both Commonwealth and State Governments. Housing and transport are two forms of assistance which are mainly provided by State Governments while ongoing personal support has been the main form of Commonwealth Government help. Often assistance from one government is dependent on complementary assistance being made available from the other, but a lack of co-ordination between governments or between departments sometimes makes the provision of assistance at the same time difficult to achieve. The Commonwealth and the State Governments should ensure that there is effective co-ordination between their services for people with disabilities.

Service providers, particularly in New South Wales, were critical of a high turnover of project officer staff in the Disability Services Program of the Department of Community Services and Health, arguing that it hampered negotiations between service providers and the Department.

The Committee found that the level of classification of project officer positions, inappropriate selection procedures and inadequate training programs all contributed to the problems referred to by service providers.

The Committee recommended that the Department of Community Services and Health establish effective selection processes and effective training programs for project officers working in the Disability Services Program, with the aim of appointing people who have the capacity, motivation and experience to succeed in this demanding job.

During the passage of the Disability Services Bill in 1986, it was amended in the Senate to include psychiatric disabilities as well as physical, intellectual and sensory disabilities. The Commonwealth Government has, however, given low priority to assistance for people with psychiatric disabilities, as this area has traditionally been the preserve of State Governments. During the inquiry, there were a number of submissions urging the Commonwealth Government to take a more active role in this area.

The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth Government accepts the responsibility under the DSA to provide funding for accommodation support services for people with psychiatric disabilities. The Commonwealth Government should consult and negotiate with State and Territory Governments so that an appropriate adjustment in Commonwealth/State financial arrangements can be made to cover the resulting transfer of funding for some services from State or Territory Governments to the Commonwealth Government.

The Committee supports the Disability Services Act and its Principles and Objectives. From the evidence obtained during the inquiry, people with disabilities enhance their lifestyle and show improvements in personal development and health once they move to community-based accommodation. With adequate support, even people with severe or profound disabilities can live in community-based accommodation.

Another important consequence of people moving from nursing homes or hostels to community-based accommodation has been the increased contact with family and friends as well as the ability to form new relationships in that community.

Finally, I emphasise that a move from a large facility to a group home is not necessarily the ultimate option. It is often a stepping stone to an even less restricted type of accommodation, such as living alone or with one other person. The Committee spoke to a number of people in group homes who were planning to do just that. Support needs to be available for people to move to the least restrictive option.

I'd like to express our thanks to those who made submissions to the inquiry and those who allowed us to visit them at home. I also pay tribute to the progressive service organisations and organisations representing people with disabilities and their families who have campaigned over many years to bring about the changes in community attitudes and government policy which have enabled people with disabilities to take their rightful place in the community. In conclusion, I'd like to thank the Secretariat staff and members of the Committee who sacrificed their January break to complete this inquiry on time.
I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator O'Chee, I remind honourable senators that this is his first speech and I would ask that the usual courtesies be extended to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, in speaking on this motion, I have the great honour and privilege of standing before you as a senator for Queensland. As you will no doubt be aware, when our Constitution was created, it was the intention that the rights of States be protected through the creation of the Senate as the States' House. The people of Queensland, whom I represent, are proud and loyal Australians, but they are, equally, proud Queenslanders. In the 133 years since the proclamation of our State, ordinary Queenslanders have worked with courage and drive against great adversity to create a State which we, perhaps a little immodestly, believe to be the equal of any in this country. That same drive and that same courage are exemplified today by the people in the flood-ravaged interior of our State. It was a cruel irony indeed that washed away years of drought with the worst floods in the recorded history of this country. Many ordinary people, in towns like Alpha and Jericho and Charleville, lost everything that they had to show for years and years of struggle.

SPEECH.PARA: For some, alas, the tragedy will be too much, but for others the pioneer spirit on which this country was built has been reborn anew. I take this opportunity to beg the people of Australia and all of the members of this Parliament to offer these people every assistance, irrespective of cost. We must throw away the rule books, because this is a quite extraordinary disaster. These people require not loans but grants, and they require real assistance to ensure that they can rebuild their lives as they were before the floods. If we refuse this help, then we will be turning our backs on our duty to our fellow Australians to give them assistance in a time of desperate need. I do not believe that we should do that.

On a much happier note, last night I had the great pleasure to be elected a senator of Australia by the Legislative Assembly of Queensland. As you realise, the Legislative Assembly of Queensland is the representative body of that State. I watched the proceedings of the House from the Strangers Gallery and I hope and pray, now and in the future, that our State members in Queensland will serve the State according to its needs and will keep foremost in their minds its future prosperity.

Of course, the casual Senate vacancy which I fill was created by the resignation of Senator John Stone. Without doubt, filling any casual Senate vacancy is getting in to things at the deep end; but to attempt to replace John Stone is, I think, a bit like jumping into the Marianas Trench. Senator Stone was, in his time, a Rhodes scholar, Secretary to the Treasury, and a man whose intellectual contribution to this country would be very difficult indeed to rival in any sphere. I take this opportunity to personally thank John Stone for his kindnesses to me over the last week and a half, and I also take this opportunity to wish him, as I am sure all senators would wish him, every happiness in his future endeavours. He is a great Australian, and I feel that if I could do half as good a job as John Stone, I would be doing pretty well indeed.

Of course, the election of John Stone to this chamber in the first place was, I believe, a tribute to the foresight and to the philosophical strength of the National Party of Australia, of which I have been a proud member for the past nine years. I was first introduced to the National Party through my acquaintance with the late Sir Bruce Small, who exemplified perhaps better than anyone else the free enterprise spirit of our National Party. We of the National Party are firmly committed to the creation of conditions in which people with enthusiasm and drive and initiative, people with a love of free enterprise, are allowed to work for the betterment of their families, themselves and this nation as a whole. In working for themselves they work for all of us.

I believe that one of the things that mark our party apart from others is its broad base of members. In almost every meeting I go to I see it. From truck drivers to shopkeepers, from farmers to professional people, they are all there; and they are united by one thing, which is a commitment to hard work, to honesty, and to the Australian way of life. For those reasons I am very proud to be counted amongst their number.

That broad base in the community of which I spoke is important for another reason too. Australia is becoming an increasingly cosmopolitan country. Many people are migrants or are children of migrants. Our community is made up of a multitude of different ethnic groups. As you may or may not know, I am descended from Irish and Chinese ancestry. My father's family migrated to Australia from China between the wars. On my mother's side I am a fourth generation Australian. Both my parents, as well as my brother and sister, have travelled down to Canberra by bus to be present today. I thank them for their encouragement and assistance throughout the years.
Honourable senators-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —I also take this opportunity to salute my great aunt, who unfortunately was too ill to come down to Canberra. She has been an inspiration to me and is somebody who is forward thinking and whose views I have always valued. I hope and trust that she is listening on radio today, because my thoughts are with her.

SPEECH.PARA: Before coming to this place I had, Mr President, the very good fortune to travel widely and also to read law at Brasenose College, Oxford. Amongst the numerous names of well-known old members of my college, I single out two. One is Field Marshal Earl Haig, and the other is John Buchan, the author who was to become Lord Tweedsmuir and the first Governor-General of Canada. I single them out because there is a very good story told of how John Buchan during the First World War acted as a courier for Haig.

Apparently, the young officer was in the habit on his frequent train journeys from the front to headquarters of changing into his pyjamas to go to sleep. On one particular occasion he awoke just as a train arrived at the station where the headquarters was situated. With great presence of mind he quickly pulled on his long boots and his greatcoat and tumbled out of the train and gave Haig a very soldierly salute. Unfortunately, there was one problem: there was a gap between the boots and the greatcoat which exposed a portion of coloured pyjamas. Haig, looking him up and down, just said, `Well, Brasenose never was a terribly dressy college'. I would hope-as my predecessor, Senator Stone, said in his maiden speech-that at no time shall my dress here offend.

Dress aside, I believe that my time at Oxford was a tremendous opportunity to study and I would very humbly hope that some of the wisdom prevailing there may have rubbed off on me so that I might be better able to serve this great country in the decision making and problem solving ahead. I select for you three of those problems-the environment, the economy, and the challenge facing youth-for consideration today, Mr President.

As I said, I have had the very good fortune to travel around a fair bit, but I am always proud to come back home to Australia because of how beautiful this country is and how pristinely clean it is. Unlike Europe or northern America, we are not cursed with acid rain. Nor are we cursed with piles of garbage building up in the streets. And it must remain that way.

I cite as an example too the Antarctic Continent, of which Australia is a major custodian. This ice locked landscape constitutes the last great wilderness left to mankind. Its ecology is terribly fragile and without doubt tied to our global future in ways far too subtle or too numerous for us to appreciate fully. I believe Australia has a duty to protect this jewel, at least until it can be more properly understood. It may very well hold valuable insights into our world which are the key to the long term survival of mankind on this planet. For example, it was from the Antarctic that we first observed the growing hole in the ozone layer. I believe there are probably many other secrets which it holds which will in due course be revealed to us if we preserve and cherish the Antarctic as it deserves.

All in all, these are very exciting times in which to live and we have many challenges facing us environmentally. But I warn everyone of one thing: the environmental debate must not become marginalised by sensationalist, single issue arguments, but rather we must take the broader view and look to make the protection of our environment part of our everyday lives. The environment is not just about rainforests or wetlands; the environment is the whole of the Australian land mass.

We city dwellers have a lot to learn from the man on the land, because he is on the whole a very good manager and custodian of the environment. This is because he is in sync with it and because he is so totally dependent upon it to continue providing an income for himself, his family, his children and his children's children. I urge all to take note of this. I urge all to seek the broader view and look for a balanced perspective from which we can attain sustainable growth without squandering this nation's birthright. Sustainable growth should also be an objective in our approach to the economy.

When I was selected by the National Party in Gympie a little under a week and a half ago, I made a promise that I would travel around Queensland and listen to what Queenslanders had to say and take their voice to Canberra and let it be heard. I would have wished for longer to travel but, in the brief time that I have available to me in my discussions with electors and in what I heard from them, it became very clear that their principal concern was on matters economic. Never before has this country been in such a perilous economic condition. It is time we started talking about it, using simple everyday language.

It is very easy for us here to talk about our attitudes to things in terms of the words `wet' or `dry' or whatever; but remember, to most people in the population, these words are equated with whether or not one uses underarm deodorant. The important thing is that we talk about facts. It is a fact that our net foreign debt currently stands at $118 billion. Just to pay the interest on that will cost us next year well in excess of $12 billion-or $7,400 for every man, woman and child in this country.

Let us get one thing right: we will be paying that money away. We will, all of us, pay it every week in higher taxes to meet the Government's interest bill. Small businesses will pay it in the money that leaves these shores and never comes back. Ordinary workers will pay it because at the end of the day, no matter how hard they work, no matter how productive they are, there will not be the money to reward them as they deserve. That is the legacy of the last seven years, a legacy which our children will probably still be paying off in 20 years' time.

I say these things very deliberately, Mr President, because I have grave doubts about our ability to meet our foreign debt commitments. Gross foreign debt currently stands at one-third of gross domestic product although in 1983 when the present Government came to power it constituted only 13.8. per cent of GDP.

Foreign investment is nowhere near as dangerous as foreign debt. Foreign investment, properly managed, represents a stake in the future of this country through the creation of jobs and industry. Foreign debt represents a disembowelling of the economy as money is ripped away from the pockets of ordinary Australians and put in the hands of people with no long term interest in this country.

Hand in hand with high foreign rates, high interest rates which crucify business and which make the great Australian nightmare, interest rates are higher than they have ever been in Australia's history. The ordinary people of Australia are screaming for interest rates to be brought down because they can no longer bear the cost.

Prime lending rates are in excess of 18.5 per cent. Under the current Government these interest rates are rivalled only by the horror years of the Whitlam era. The lesson is very simple. It is this: high interest rates equal business failure and misery for small business and workers alike. Business needs a chance to breathe, and whilst it is breathing it needs direction. Businesses must be encouraged to borrow to invest, not borrow to spend or borrow to speculate, because only in that fashion can we build a solid and stable economy.

Allow me to address too the buzz words of micro-economic reform. I assume by this Canberraspeak we mean reform of that small portion of the economy fortunate enough to survive the ravages of the current Treasurer (Mr Keating). We in the National Party are firmly of the belief that competition in the marketplace is essential for our long term economic future, but we are also of the belief, however, that competition must be accompanied by competitiveness.

If this Government is fair dinkum about reforming our economy it will and must start with the labour markets. It is absolutely critical that the terms of employment are decided by the employer and the employee together and not by the faceless members of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and certainly not by yesterday's men in the Australian Council of Trade Unions. We need voluntary employment agreements which, I hasten to add, are just that-voluntary and agreements-because in this fashion we will get the flexibility to help our economy recover. Only in this fashion can we ensure that our factories and businesses work efficiently and that we get real returns on capital investment.

I make all these comments on the economy because I grew up as a young child in a different world where happiness and prosperity in this country seemed to belong to us as a right, but for the next generation of Australians the future is not so rosy. Attendant with our economic woes have come broken homes, latchkey kids and a growing despair amongst young people. School students are struggling to find places in tertiary studies and they are struggling to pay for those places if they are lucky enough to get there. Tertiary education must be understood to be an investment in the future of this country and must be treated accordingly. It is shameful that it pays better to be on the dole than it does to be a student on Austudy and we have to do better by our young people. We have to encourage them to study and not drive them away. But they are the lucky ones, because many fall by the wayside well before that.

We cannot fail to observe with anything less than a sense of tragedy the growing drug abuse and homelessness amongst young Australians today. This, I believe, is something that we must address immediately. We must ensure that nobody in this country has his life counted for nought. We must address the problems of young people to ensure that each and every one of them has the opportunity at least to seize for himself prosperity and happiness and in so doing make this country great.

May I remind this chamber that in the past youth has not let this country down. Many of those who served in two world wars were not old enough to vote. Many were too young even to have enlisted but they concealed their ages because they knew their country needed them and they were not going to stand idly by. I am before you very humbly as what I understand to be the youngest person to occupy a seat in this chamber. I am also here on behalf of another generation of Australians that is just as keen as those who went before. We love our country and all that it stands for and we ask for nothing but opportunity and incentive to stand up and be counted.

Australia should and must harness the powerhouse of young people who are ready to fight for its future. In all our deliberations here I would beg that we remember one thing: that my generation represents the future of this country. Give us the chance and we will answer the call. Give us the task and we will carry the load. Give us your trust and we will not let you down.
Honourable senators-Hear, hear!
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Mr R. Nestdale: Death-Election: Scrutineers-Mr E. M. Williams: Death

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being nearly 6 p.m. I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.
