She was not able to be in the Senate last December when a number of us spoke about the death of Robert Nestdale, but she was able later at a conference of Young Liberals to put down her own tribute to Robert Nestdale and to indicate some of the people-Audrey Hepburn, the Secretary-General of the Commonwealth, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the former Prime Minister, and various people, such as the Attorney-General of New South Wales-who took part in that memorial service.

SPEECH.PARA: I come before the chamber tonight only to seek from my colleagues the chance to round out the record which we started when we spoke about Robert Nestdale that night in December. I have spoken to one of the Ministers about these documents. I seek leave to table this statement by Mrs Joan Hall and also to table the message sent to the memorial service for Robert Nestdale by Chief Emeka Anyaoku, the Secretary-General of the Commonwealth.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is now well over a month since the Hawke Labor Government was reelected for an historic fourth term. The passage of time will continue to dim the memory of that great day, but before we forget about it completely, there are some important points which arose on election day which I feel duty bound to bring to the attention of honourable senators and to express my own personal reservations about.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say at the outset that the reservations I have concerning the conduct of the election in no way relate to the behaviour of any candidate or any political party; on the contrary, in my State at least the election was conducted in a spirited but fair manner by all parties concerned.

The matters which I would like the Senate to take note of relate to the conduct of the count. The first of my concerns arises from the treatment of scrutineers in some booths. There were many cases of a distinct lack of cooperation on the part of employees of the Australian Electoral Commission in their treatment of scrutineers.

In one notorious case, the State member for Playford in South Australia was informed that he had no right to test the validity of the votes cast. He was then informed that he would be allowed to test the validity of the votes cast, but only after they had been tallied and the numbers checked. He was later told that he would only be allowed to check if the ballot did not take a long time to count. When the count was finished, he was told that, unfortunately, the ballot had taken longer than the returning officer was prepared to spend counting votes and, therefore, the checking by scrutineers for validity or otherwise of votes cast would be dispensed with altogether. Frankly, I find that unacceptable.

It is a mystery to me why officers in charge of booths would behave in this manner. Perhaps it could be that they consider scrutineers an unnecessary encumbrance. Perhaps it could be, as has been suggested to me by a colleague, that they are just sick and tired of party scrutineers pre-empting official results, and they simply crave a little limelight. Whatever the reason for this behaviour, it seems obvious to me that to prevent scrutineers from fulfilling their duties to the candidate who appoints them is an unacceptable solution to whatever problem the Electoral Commission is attempting to remedy.

I understand that Senator Schacht took up this matter with the Electoral Commission before the election, and asked that it instruct its divisional returning officers to comply with the wishes of scrutineers and count slowly where those scrutineers so desired. The Electoral Commission declined to do so, and left it to officers in charge of booths to determine their own procedures. This abrogation of authority led to situations such as the one which confronted the member for Playford, which I mentioned earlier. Counts were rushed and it was impossible to obtain results from some booths.

While rushing through a count in this manner would prevent their reporting of unofficial results, and it did, it could also prevent a complete and thorough scrutiny of a count. The two are very similar processes. I am not sure whether the brains trust at the Electoral Commission realise it, but a good scrutineer-and in the Australian Labor Party there is but one type-can check the validity of votes and determine preferences at the same time. It is a simple process, and one which does not extend the count by any great degree.

I have been told that in some electorates in South Australia the divisional returning officers gave their poll officials the instruction that the Federal office declined to give. The scrutiny was done in a way that allowed preferences to be determined. The count was not unnecessarily delayed, and all parties involved appreciated the sensible approach of those officers.

For all the years that I have acted as a scrutineer for the Labor Party, no problems have ever arisen because scrutineers were allowed to examine ballot papers at will. If all participants in the count behave reasonably, they can all get the information that they desire without ignoring or damaging the interests of any group. There is no question in my mind that before the next Federal election, the Electoral Commission should give every divisional returning officer the direction that they should cooperate with scrutineers, and allow them to validate votes and determine preferences as they desire.

The second matter that I wish to raise briefly is similarly a question concerning the time taken to count the vote. There was, in my State, no mention of the Senate count on the night of the election. There is always an unseemly rush to count the votes for the House of Representatives-and justifiably so, considering that determines who is to form a government for the next three years. But during the television coverage for the 24 March election, I do not think I heard one report concerning the Senate count. It is important that some votes are counted for the Senate, so that when the media spotlight is at its brightest-on election night-the people of Australia are made aware of what is going on, and who is going in to the upper House of their Federal Parliament.
I am not certain whether the problem was with the delay in counting the Senate vote but, whatever the problem, it is one which is depriving this chamber of publicity which it quite richly deserves.

My final comment concerns the length of time taken to count the Senate vote. At the declaration of the Senate poll for the State of South Australia, both Senators Teague and Crowley commented that the time taken to count the Senate vote was inordinately long. The electoral Commission must look at its methods, and determine a way to complete the count earlier.

Before I conclude, there is one final point I would like to make. In case my comments have appeared overly critical of the Electoral Commission, let me make clear my appreciation and support for the fine work that the Commission does. On the whole, we are very well serviced by our Electoral Commission. It is important, however, that where problems do exist, those problems are addressed and resolved. I hope that my criticisms are not seen as being made in anything other than the constructive spirit in which they are intended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with sadness and with pride that I pay tribute tonight to Edwin Meredith Williams, known as Ted Williams. Ted was born in Subiaco in Western Australia on 31 December 1923. He died on 20 March 1990. I was present when Ted collapsed and died while speaking at the annual general meeting of the Asbestos Diseases Society of Western Australia. He died while he was in the midst of a passionate diatribe describing how unionists who became members of parliament had betrayed asbestos workers.

SPEECH.PARA: Ted Williams had studied engineering and worked in Wittenoom in Western Australia from 1948 until 1950. He suffered from an asbestos-related disease. The Asbestos Diseases Society of Western Australia was formed in 1979 and Ted became a member in 1986, and from then until the time of his death he played an executive role in the society. I would like to add that I am very proud to wear the badge of the Asbestos Diseases Society of Western Australia.

Like so many others, Ted was concerned that worker's claims for compensation were unconscionably slow to be addressed. He was a dedicated member of the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union for over 40 years and he served in various capacities as a union official. He was also a dedicated member of the Historical Society of Western Australia-indeed, a very rounded man.

Ted had an unceasing commitment and genuine dedication beyond the ordinary call of duty to the Asbestos Diseases Society of Western Australia and I would like it on record in this place that Ted Williams died in the call of duty while fighting for justice and the recognition of asbestos diseases victims and their families. I express my condolences to his wife, Gloria, and the family.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 6.09 p.m.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Brisbane Forest Products and Sawmillers Exports

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 13 November 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Minister provide copies of the Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) for the Brisbane Forest Products and Sawmillers Exports operations.

(2) For the Sawmillers Exports operation, were additional EIS's prepared before conditions were relaxed in 1982 to include silvicultural residues and freehold land, and when the quota was increased in 1989 to 500,000 tonnes.

(3) Will the Minister give an assurance that the conditions on Brisbane Forest Products' licence will not be relaxed to include silvicultural residues at least until a detailed and thorough EIS is prepared and made available to the public.
(4) Will the Minister initiate research into the manufacture of a variety of wood products from eucalypts, now being used for export woodchips, so that value-added products can be produced locally.
(5) Will the Minister provide incentives for the establishment of mills to manufacture paper from recycled material and fibre crops than timber.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The potential environmental effects of Brisbane Forest Products' woodchip export operation were fully assessed, but it was decided that these effects were not significant enough to require the preparation of an environmental impact statement.

Sawmillers Exports prepared an environmental impact statement on its woodchip export operation in 1977, at the request of the Commonwealth Minister for Environment, Housing and Community Development and the New South Wales Minister for Decentralisation and Development. Neither my office nor the Department of Primary Industries and Energy holds a copy but I understand that the library of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories holds a copy which the honourable senator would be able to borrow.

(2) The decision in 1983 to allow Sawmillers Exports to export woodchips derived from silvicultural residues was made only after a long assessment by the relevant Commonwealth and State authorities, including a twelve-month trial of the removal of this resource. During this time, no environmental problems were identified and no substantive reasons were advanced to justify refusal of the company's request. The decision to allow the use of silvicultural residues also took into account the findings of the State Pollution Control Commission's 1975 public inquiry into woodchipping on the New South Wales north coast and the 1977 report on woodchipping by the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment. Both of these reports found no significant environmental objections to the use of silvicultural residues for the production of woodchips.

Although Sawmillers Exports is permitted to obtain woodchips from freehold land, it may do so only after approval has been given for each property by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. To date, the company has only once, in 1985, sought such approval and this request was granted only after advice was received from the Commonwealth and State environmental authorities, the State Department of Agriculture and the Soil Conservation Service.

The 1989 decision to increase Sawmillers Exports' maximum export tonnage was based on advice from the New South Wales Forestry Commission that there would be sufficient sawmill and logging residues in the company's area of operation to satisfy the request without any change to forest operations apart from the removal from the forest of additional wastes which, in the absence of the woodchip export industry, would almost certainly be left in the forest to rot. The Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories also advised that it had no objections on environmental grounds to the proposal.

(3) In line with standard procedures, the environmental implications of any proposal by Brisbane Forest Products to amend the conditions of the export licence would be fully assessed. Whether that assessment would include the preparation of an environmental impact statement would depend on the details of the application and other circumstances at the time.

(4) The Government is already involved in forestry and forest products research, including the use of hardwood pulpwood, through the CSIRO Division of Forestry and Forest Products. The Government is also discussing with industry the establishment of forest industry research funding arrangements whereby the research needs of Australia's forest and forest products industries will be addressed.

(5) The Government has recently legislated to exempt from wholesale sales tax certain printing and writing paper, tissues, toilet paper and paper bags if they are made wholly out of recycled paper. The Government is also trialling recycled paper in selected Government departments.

The Prime Minister also indicated on 19 March the Government's intention to develop a national waste minimisation and recycling strategy in co-operation with the States and industry. The Government will be seeking the establishment of minimum goals for rates of recycling.

Any decision to establish a new pulp or paper mill should be based on commercial considerations by the company involved and should not depend upon government incentives for any particular process or feedstock.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 22 November 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When will the results of tests to determine whether the recent outbreak of disease in Victoria is fireblight be available.

(2) Is any change contemplated in the conditions for importation of apples and pears from New Zealand since the Minister's answer to my Question on Notice No. 570 (see Hansard of 11 October 1988, page 1184).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The results of the tests undertaken to determine the identity of the organism recently isolated from a nashi orchard in Victoria were released on 21 November 1989. The organism responsible for the fireblight-like symptoms was determined to be an unrelated bacterium Pseudomonas syringae.

(2) Conditions for importation of apples from New Zealand are prescribed in the Quarantine (Plants) Regulations under the Quarantine Act 1908. The regulations require certification by the New Zealand Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries that apples are produced in districts where fireblight does not occur.
The current proposal from New Zealand, which is the subject of extensive consultation throughout Australia, addresses the certification requirement.

The Government is preparing to introduce into the Parliament a Bill for a new Agricultural Quarantine Act. The Bill will address the requirement for a more transparent and practical form of legal quarantine framework. At present no substantive legislative changes to the conditions for the importation of apples from New Zealand are contemplated in the new legislation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 5 December 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With regard to an article which appeared in the Australian Rural Times of 12 October 1989 that the fumigation procedures on imported strawberries have not been of adequate standard and that, as a consequence, the western flower thrip, previously not present in Australia has been allowed into the country with a potentially disastrous impact on crops such as tomatoes, cotton, potatoes and egg plant, can the Minister advise whether the fumigation dose rates on US imported strawberries have been increased to prevent any further importation of the thrip.
(2) Can the Australian primary producer be reassured that this thrip has been completely destroyed and is no longer present in Australia.

(3) Will the Department tighten the quarantine procedures on all imported fruits or plants (for example, at present fumigation on imported strawberries is only voluntary) and will the Minister consider making fumigation compulsory.
(4) How many other fruits and plants only undergo voluntary fumigation.
(5) If no effective de-infestation treatment for thrip can be found will a ban be put on US imports of strawberries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The import of strawberries from the US has been prohibited. No imports will be permitted until an effective treatment for western flower thrips has been demonstrated by US authorities.
(2) The Australian primary producer can be assured that there are no records of the western flower thrip being established in Australia.

(3) The Department reviews quarantine procedures for efficacy as necessary. Compulsory treatment such as fumigation is required when inspection is not effective at detecting pests of quarantine significance.

(4) No fruits or vegetables are allowed entry only on the basis of voluntary fumigation. All imports are inspected for pests and disease. If pests of quarantine significance are found fumigation or other appropriate treatment is required to disinfest the product. At the choice of the importer some imports known to be prone to general insect infestation are fumigated at set rates after inspection for disease as this allows quicker release of the product rather than wait for the more detailed examination required for insects.
(5) As I indicated above imports of US strawberries are prohibited at this time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 7 December 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: How many of the Lindsay Quarantine Review Committee recommendations were (a) fully implemented; (b) partially implemented; if so, what were the reasons and (c) rejected; if so, what were the reasons.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: In response to the Lindsay Committee report the Government, in 1988, issued a quarantine policy statement ``Australian Quarantine-Looking to the Future''.

Appendix II to this Statement detailed the Government's response to each of the 59 recommendations put forward by the Lindsay Committee. This record shows that the Government fully accepted 51 of the recommendations, rejected 2 recommendations and determined an alternative approach to the remaining 6 recommendations. Details of those recommendations rejected or altered are as follows:

(i) Rejected-The Government rejected Recommendations 41 and 42 relating to the collection of charges for quarantine services as it believed that the existing system of user pays fee for service charging under which 60% of the cost of the service is recovered from users, was more equitable and efficient than that recommended.

(ii) Alternative Approach Adopted-The Government adopted an alternative approach to a group of recommendations (numbers 13, 14, 15, 17, 23, 26) relating to the transfer of a range of quarantine functions from the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service to the Australian Customs Service. The Government decided that a more cost efficient and effective arrangement was to transfer these functions to each State or Territory and have them provide a single quarantine service on behalf of the Commonwealth.
Consistent with Recommendation 50 of the Lindsay report, a Strategic Planning Group has been established to facilitate implementation of those recommendations adopted by the Government.

Some of the recommendations were an affirmation of existing practices, some were able to be readily implemented and others requiring major work will take longer eg. those that depend upon the outcome of negotiations with third parties such as the states or overseas countries.

The Strategic Planning Group is operating to a 2 year time-frame (beginning December 1988) for implementation of the Government policy statement and all new arrangements/policies have either now been implemented or are in the process of being implemented.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 11 December 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In relation to the World Heritage nomination of Fraser Island and Cooloola, which are the core of the Great Sandy Region, upon what basis did the Minister reach the conclusion `I wouldn't like to think that Australia would put up a park which wouldn't pass the test and at this stage of the game I don't think that Fraser Island would pass' which was reported in a Brisbane Channel 7 news interview broadcast on Friday 27 October 1989.

(2) How does the Minister reconcile his position with that of a former Minister for the Environment (Mr Newman) who advised the Parliament in December 1976, when Fraser Island was the first site to be listed on the Australian Register of the National Estate, that the Commonwealth Government would give consideration to World Heritage listing for Fraser Island.

(3) Has the Minister initiated any evaluations of the significance of Fraser Island's outstanding attributes recognised by the Fraser Island Environmental Inquiry and the then Minister for the Environment.
(4) Is it true that the Minister has never taken the opportunity to inspect Fraser Island.

(5) Did the Minister also tell representatives of the Fraser Island Defenders Organisation on 7 June 1989 that he was prepared to consider a new nomination for World Heritage for the Great Sandy Region but that Fraser Island Defenders Organisation would have to prepare the nomination from its own resources without Federal assistance or support.

(6) Is Fraser Island going to be like Kakadu which was vociferously denounced by Senator Evans as `clapped out buffalo country' only to become part of Australia's, indeed the world's natural heritage.
(7) Will the Minister give an undertaking to initiate an independent evaluation of the merits of the Great Sandy Region for World Heritage listing as he did with Kakadu.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) At this stage there is no World Heritage nomination for Fraser Island. In my view much more work is required on assessing the possible World Heritage values of the Great Sandy Region and developing a management regime consistent with those values before Australia will be in a position to convince the World Heritage Committee that the Region meets the stringent criteria for World Heritage listing.
(2) I am not responsible for statements made by Ministers of former Governments and I am not aware of any attempt by the Fraser Government to prepare a World Heritage nomination for Fraser Island.
(3) My Department is currently examining a proposal from Mr John Sinclair of the Fraser Island Defenders Organization (FIDO) nominating the Great Sandy Region for World Heritage listing.
(4) I have not yet visited Fraser Island.

(5) When I met representatives of FIDO on 7 June 1989 I said that the Government would be prepared to consider a recommendation prepared by FIDO. I indicated that appropriate support, which necessarily would be limited, could be made available by my Department.

(7) As indicated above my Department is currently examining a proposal from FIDO. In addition the Queensland Government on 17 January 1990 announced agreement with the Australian Conservation Foundation (ACF) to hold an independent economic and environmental inquiry into logging on Fraser Island. No doubt in the course of the inquiry the natural and cultural heritage values of the Great Sandy Region will be canvassed. I support this initiative from the Queensland Government and look forward to seeing the results of the inquiry.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 19 December 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many Ministerial councils, or similar forums, for the meeting of State, Federal and other Ministers exist.
(2) What are their names and general objectives.
(3) How many times per year does the council(s)/forum(s) meet.
(4) What is the membership (including officials) of each council/forum, and who chairs the meetings.
(5) Is the council(s)/forum(s) served by a Secretariat, if so, what is its composition, who is responsible for financing it, and what does it cost.
(6) What meetings of the council(s)/forum(s) were held for the last 3 financial years and how many persons attended the meetings, including officials and private ministerial staff.
(7) What were the costs of each of these meetings to the Commonwealth including travel, entertainment or dinners/lunches, accommodation, etc.
(8) Where were the meetings held and what was the venue.
(9) Are the records of the meetings available to the public; if so, where can they be obtained; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are two Ministerial Conferences and one Ministerial Council which the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and the the Minister for Local Government attend:
(2) (i) The Conference for Commonwealth/State/Territory Ministers responsible for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. (CCSTMIEA)
Objective: To provide a means of consultation between Commonwealth and State/Territory governments on aspects of immigration and ethnic affairs.

Objective: To provide Ministers with an opportunity to discuss matters of mutual interest in the Local Government field and to initiate and fund research into topics of importance to Local Government.
(iii) Ministerial Council on the Development of Albury-Wodonga. (MCDWA)
Objective: To generally supervise the development of the Albury-Wodonga growth centre.
The LGMC is normally held annually.
The MCDAW meetings are held annually.

(4) CCSTMIEA: All responsible State/Territory Ministers attend with Departmental Secretaries and other senior departmental officials. The New Zealand Minister for Immigration also attends. Other officials who attend include the Director of the Office of Multicultural Affairs and the Chairperson of National Accreditation Authority for Translators and Interpreters (NAATI). The meeting is always chaired by the Commonwealth Minister.

LGMC: Commonwealth, State, Territory, and New Zealand Ministers responsible for Local Government are members. The meetings are also attended by Ministerial staff, officials from Departments, the President, Senior Vice President and Director of the Australian Local Government Association. Chairmanship rotates with the host Minister chairing.

MCDAW: Ministerial members are the Commonwealth Minister for Local Government, the New South Wales Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs and the Victorian Minister for Industry, Technology and Resources. The Ministers are usually accompanied by officials from their Departments. Corporation executives also attend the meetings. The meeting is chaired by the Commonwealth Minister for Local Government.

(5) CCSTMIEA is served by a Secretariat from within the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and is staffed by 3 people headed by an Administrative Service Officer Class 8 (ASOC8). The CCSTMIEA is not the sole responsibility of this area. Its duties include Secretariat support to the National Population Council, the National Conferences of State/Territory Directors, Executive meetings and associated research work. The Secretariat is financed by Departmental budget allocations. Because of the many functions carried out in the Secretariat it is not possible to separate out costs for individual conferences.

LGMC is served by a Secretariat from within the Office of Local Government (OLG) of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and is staffed by one ASOC6. The work load is estimated at 63 person days per annum. The Secretariat is financed by Departmental budget allocations. Salary costs are estimated at $8,128 while resource costs are subsumed within OLG administration costs.
MCDAW is not served by a Secretariat. Support services are provided by the Albury-Wodonga Development Corporation at the meetings at an estimated cost of $500 to $600.

(6) CCSTMIEA has met 3 times in the past 3 financial years. The March 1987 Conference was attended by 37 people. The March 1988 Conference was attended by 38 people. The March 1989 Conference was attended by 37 people.

The LGMC has met 4 times in the last 3 financial years. The November 1986 conference was attended by 39 people. The July 1987 Conference was attended by 26 people. The June 1988 conference was attended by 31 people. The May 1989 conference was attended by 33 people.
The MCDAW has met 3 times in the last 3 financial years. Approximately 20 people attended each meeting.

(7) CCSTMIEA: The cost of the past 3 meetings to the Commonwealth was limited to the transport and travelling allowances of the Minister and Departmental officials that attended. Without a substantial resource input an exact costing is not readily available.

LGMC: The cost of these conferences to the Commonwealth was limited to the transport costs and travelling allowances of the Minister and the Department officials who attended. Without a substantial resource input an exact costing is not readily available.

MCDAW: Lunches provided by the Corporation are estimated at $450 to $500 each. Other costs were limited to the transport costs and travelling allowances of the Minister and the Departmental officials that attended. Without a substantial resource input an exact costing is not readily available.
27 March 1987-Legislative Chambers, Parliament House, Wellington, New Zealand.
17 March 1989-Lakeside Reception Centre, Melbourne Zoological Gardens, Melbourne.
MCDAW meetings were all held at the Development Corporation's office in Albury-Wodonga.

(9) CCSTMIEA: Records of the meetings are circulated to all participants and are available on request from the Machinery of Government Section in the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs.
LGMC: The records of the meeting are not available to the public because the Council has not made a decision to make them available.
MCDAW: At the conclusion of each meeting, the Ministerial Council issue a communique detailing all decisions except those relating to competitive commercial activities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 21 December 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Following the Minister's answer to my question on Notice, No. 1243 (see Senate Hansard, 21 November 1989, page 2964) regarding family law matters, what action is proposed by the Attorney-General's Department to record the following statistics while matters are subject to the jurisdiction of the Family Law Act 1975: (a) how many family law files will be closed in 1990 and each subsequent year because of the death of one parent; (b) of those who will die, the number who are custodial parents; (c) the number who are mothers; (d) the number who are fathers; and (e) the number of children that die.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Science and Technology Information Service

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, upon notice, on 20 December 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What support, financial or other, has the Government provided to the Australian Science and Technology Information Service initiated by the Australian Academy of Science.
(2) What steps will the Government take now that the preliminary planning is complete and with private sponsorship proceeding, to ensure the success of this most valuable and necessary project.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: In 1989/90, the Government has allocated some $800,000 to promote awareness of the importance of science and technology in Australia.
A science information service is one of a number of possible means of raising awareness of science and technology.

In August 1989 $20,000 was provided to the Academy of Science from the Science and Technology Awareness program towards a feasibility study of the proposal for the establishment of an Australian Science and Technology Information Service (ASTIS). This was in addition to an amount of $10,000 contributed from Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce funds in June 1988.

The Government recently received the feasibility study report for ASTIS. The Government is, however, not convinced that the proposed media referral service is likely to be the most cost-effective means of raising awareness of science and technology. In our consideration of this matter we have also been guided by overseas experiences with media referral services.

The Government has therefore decided not to provide further support for ASTIS. Instead, the resources available for awareness promotion will be utilised in a range of direct programs such as public lectures, and seminars on science issues, provision of educational resource materials, interactive projects at science and technology centres, and integrated media productions on science and technology.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, upon notice, on 21 December 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it correct that 6 CSIRO agro-forestry projects on Mr Francis Clarke's property at Tarago, New South Wales, reported to have had funding of $500,000 and recognised as the best in Australia, have been abandoned because of funding cuts; if so, what were the reasons.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The work at Mr Clarke's property has not been abandoned, but CSIRO's involvement has been greatly reduced for the following reasons:

Some seven years ago it was decided, by the then Division of Forest Research, that resources should be concentrated on a detailed study of the biology of forest growth. This high priority study was designed to provide information that could be extrapolated to guide forest management under a wide range of conditions.
The intensive nature of the study required a site close to the Division's Canberra laboratories. A suitable location was found at Pierce's Creek.
It was necessary for the Division to reduce its work at Mr Clarke's property in order to free up resources for the higher priority work at Pierce's Creek.

Apart from the distance of the Tarago site from Canberra (about 80 km), a further difficulty was that, despite being resown, the pasture component of the agro-forestry system performed very poorly because of environmental factors.

Although the Tarago studies should ideally extend over a long period, it is possible to carry out the research in phases so that results can be reported progressively. The studies have already been reported through conferences and field days. The results of a decade of work at the site, during which the trees have been established and pruning completed, are being written up and it is hoped to provide further progress reports on the project in due course.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 22 December 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does (a) the ANZAC frigate contract; and (b) the new submarine project contract contain clauses governing the eventuality that Australia may cancel (i) some, or (ii) all of the warships to which it is committed under each contract; if so, what in broad terms do the provisions of (A) the frigate contracts and (B) the submarine contract state with respect to partial or complete cancellation.

(2) Does the frigate contract contain provisions for the cancellation of: (a) one; (b) two; (c) three; (d) four; (e) five; (f) six; (g) seven; and (h) eight ships; if so, what are the financial implications in each case.

(3) Does the submarine contract contain provisions for the cancellation of: (a) one; (b) two; (c) three; (d) four; (e) five; and (f) six boats; if so, what are the financial implications in each case.

(4) Does either contract contain cancellation penalty provisions over and above the costs already incurred or committed by the contractor; if so what is the extent in each case of the additional penalties.

(5) Are the relevant provisions of each contract; (a) classified; if so, what damage to national security could result from their disclosure; and (b) regarded as `commercial-in-confidence'; if so, why was it necessary to conceal from the Parliament and the people these details of contracts entered into on their behalf by the Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The ANZAC Ship Contract contains a general provision under which the Commonwealth may terminate some or all of the work under the Contract. In broad terms, the Commonwealth's liability in the event of such termination is to compensate the Contractor for loss or damage substained as a result. Anticipated profits on the remaining work which would have been completed are excluded from the assessment of loss or damage.

(b) The contract between the Commonwealth and the Australian Submarine Corporation (ASC) contains clauses which allow the Commonwealth to terminate the contract, or any part of the contract, upon giving notice in writing of its intention to do so. In this event the contractor is entitled to submit a claim for compensation in respect of loss or damage sustained.

(2) The ANZAC Ship Contract also contains specific provisions for termination, at the option of the Commonwealth, after delivery of either four or eight ships. Liability provisions are similar to the general termination clause but, the Contractor is obliged to use its best efforts to achieve specific reductions in the contract price.

(3) The Commonwealth has entered into a contract with ASC for six submarines. The contract does not specifically provide for cancellation of individual submarines but all or any part of the contract may be terminated by the Commonwealth as stated in answer to (1) (b) above.

(4) Neither project contract contains cancellation penalty provisions over and above the costs already incurred or committed by the contractor. However, the contractor could take legal action to apply for further compensation.
(5) (a) Sections of the Combat System Specification which forms part of the ANZAC Ship Contract are classified as they disclose performance details. The remainder of the contract is UNCLASSIFIED.

(b) The ANZAC Ship Contract is treated as `COMMERCIAL-IN-CONFIDENCE' because it contains pricing, schedule, equipment selection and other details which, if released publicly, could disadvantage the Prime Contractor in its dealings with sub-contractors and suppliers and in the general execution of the contract.

The contract between the Commonwealth and ASC is `COMMERCIAL-IN-CONFIDENCE'. This provision was made at the insistence of ASC and is normal commercial practice in contracts of this nature in order to protect the commercial interests of the company. Any breach by the Commonwealth of this commercial confidentially could:
a. if shown to put the company at a commercial disadvantage, result in a substantial claim for compensation in respect of the loss or damage so substained, and/or
b. destroy the credibility of the Commonwealth as a responsible customer.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Importation of Second Hand Materials Handling Equipment

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 22 December 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to the Minister's announcement on 30th November 1989 that Licensing Controls on the importation of second hand materials handling equipment would be removed from 11 December 1989, is it a fact that this announcement came only 6 days after the industrial truck industry received assurances from the Government that controls would be retained until about the middle of 1990.

(2) Why did the Government make such a precipitate decision before the States had been satisfied as to arrangements to ensure there would not be a flood of sub-standard and unsafe equipment allowed into the country.

(3) Given concern expressed recently by the Minister for Industrial Relations about the high level of work place injuries and the fact that statistics show 29 per cent of all accidents result from the use of mechanical equipment, what safeguards has the government put in place to minimise the risk of injury from potentially faulty imported machinery such as fork-lift trucks.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) It was not a precipitate decision. The original decision was announced on 13 June 1989, giving the States six months in which to put their views to the Federal Government and to take any appropriate action they considered necessary to improve the policing of the relevant State safety regulations.
The Government is satisfied that it has done all it can to ensure that there will not be a flood of substandard and unsafe equipment into the country.
Prior to the removal of the licensing controls, the States did not have the means of checking imports of new or second hand materials equipment registrations.
From the date of the removal of the controls the Federal Government has provided the States with the means of tracing all imports for safety standards registration purposes.

(3) The Government made a significant contribution in assisting the States to police their safety regulations by providing the means to obtain from the Australian Customs Service details of all individual company imports of materials handling equipment.

The availability of import data from the Australian Customs Service gives the States a ready means of checking import details against equipment registrations and will be of significant advantage in improving the policing of safety standards applying to materials handling equipment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 17 January 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Can the Minister provide the following information in relation to Department of Veterans' Affairs hospitals in Australia which maintain a centralised air conditioning system:
(a) the number of Veterans' Affairs hospitals which do maintain such a system and the number, if any, which do not have such a system;
(b) how often are the air conditioning units serviced;
(c) is it the same for each hospital;
(d) are contracts let by the Government for the servicing of these air conditioning units;
(e) if contracts are let, what checks are undertaken by the Department to ensure the contract has been honoured;
(f) have there been any instances where contracts have not been honoured; if so, on how many occasions, at which hospitals and what action was taken to prevent a re-occurrence.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Veterans' Affairs administers the operations of a major Repatriation General Hospital in each State capital city and auxiliary hospitals in New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland.

The majority of the buildings which make up these hospitals are over 40 years old and range from large multi-storey brick constructions to small single storey fibro/weatherboard constructed buildings. They are spread out over several hectares of the hospital grounds. As a result, air conditioning systems used in the hospitals vary considerably in size, number and capacity.

(a) None of the hospitals has a centralised air conditioning system in the true sense of the word but some buildings are air conditioned by built up systems which consist of one or more refrigeration and heating plants, with several air handling plant rooms.
Other buildings within the hospitals are air conditioned by packaged type air conditioning which may be self contained or a split system type. Room type air conditioners have also been used.
There remain many buildings situated throughout the grounds of all the hospitals which are not air conditioned.
(b) Maintenance on the air conditioning units is carried out on a cyclical preventative maintenance program. Various pieces of equipment require different maintenance intervals.

(c) Air conditioning systems are maintained in the same manner in all hospitals. Australian Construction Services (ACS) are responsible for all asset maintenance in Veterans' Affairs hospitals. Preventative maintenance on plant is based on ACS Guide Schedules for Preventative Maintenance which recommend the servicing frequency for components and systems.
(d) The Department of Veterans' Affairs is required under Government direction to utilise ACS for all its asset maintenance. ACS may subcontract the servicing of the systems.
(e) As ACS is responsible for all asset maintenance on behalf of the Department of Veterans' Affairs, it remains responsible for ensuring contracts are honoured.
(f) There are no known instances where contracts have not been honoured.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Dismissal from the Australian Defence Force

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 23 January 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Government consider that dismissal from the Australian Defence Force is `at pleasure' as held by the High Court in Coutts v the Commonwealth (1985) 59 ALR 699 or `for cause' as prescribed under the terms of the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982.

(2) If the Government considers that dismissal should be `for cause' will the Minister look into the case of Mr Brian Patton of Lismore, NSW, who was dismissed from the Australian Defence Force `at pleasure' on 6 November 1968.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Officers of the Defence Force hold their appointments at the pleasure of the Governor-General, and it is well-settled that their appointments may be terminated at any time. This is an administrative procedure and should not be confused with the punishment of dismissal from the Defence Force which may be imposed by a service tribunal upon conviction for certain offences under the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982.
(2) There is no basis to review this case.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 29 January 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of indications that the Government of Myanmar (Burma) has no intention of fulfilling its promise to conduct free and fair elections and that the authorities are implementing an active program of harassment against opposition parties, including preventing opposition members from campaigning or standing for election.

(2) In view of the dissatisfaction expressed by many Burmese and Australian nationals with what they perceive as inadequate criticism by Australia of the anti-democratic activities of the Myanmar regime, does the Minister believe that the inte-rests of trade with Myanmar should outweigh those of human rights in the region.

(3) Does the Minister agree that a recent deal made by BHP with the Government of Myanmar can be viewed as a most significant exercise which will have the effect of assisting that government to continue its anti-democratic actions and its war of attrition against ethnic minorities, as detailed in numerous media reports.
(4) Will the Minister either authorise a strong and categorical condemnation of the Myanmar regime without delay or provide the Senate with reasons for his unwillingness so to do.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Government has made it clear that it cannot accept the claim of the military regime in Myanmar that the elections set for 27 May 1990 will be free and fair while key political figures remain in detention and disqua-lified from standing for elections and while restrictions remain in force severely limiting the way in which political parties are allowed to conduct their campaigns.

(2) Australia's policy towards Myanmar has been one of unequivocal support for democratic political and economic reform and for an improvement in the human rights situation in that country. The Government's concerns about the human rights abuses, in general terms and in relation to specific cases have been repeatedly and unambiguously made known to the Myanmar authorities. Decisions on the nature, manner and timing of such representations have been based on considered judgments about the most effective means of achieving the Government's fundamental objective of improving the human rights situation in Myanmar.

(3) The Australian Government does not seek to direct the manner in which Australian companies conduct their business in other countries. Such companies are free to enter into joint venture or other agreements in Myanmar on the basis of their own judgment. The Government does not accept that, because it places no constraints on Australian private commercial activity in Myanmar, its policies on the wider issues of democratic freedom and human rights can somehow be held to be modified.

(4) Australia has never indicated support for the regime in Myanmar, for the way it came to power, or for its continued suppression of opposition groups. Australia has been, and will remain at the forefront of those countries seeking genuine political, economic and human rights reform in that country. The Government's record clearly shows it has taken every opportunity to encourage the regime to improve its human rights performance and adhere to its own undertaking that the elections will be free and fair.

The Government has regularly made strong representations direct to the authorities in Myanmar requesting that key political figures be allowed to stand for election and has called upon the authorities to lift the oppressive restrictions on political activity so that political parties can campaign effectively in the period leading up to the election.

The Government has made its views known in very clear terms and will continue to do so. I would draw the honourable senator's attention to the major statements that I have made on the Government's policy towards Myanmar, the most recent being on 19 January, 23 February and 1 March. I am sure that these meet her concerns.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 13 November 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What territorial waters does Australia claim around Norfolk Island and:
(a) What fishing zones exist in relation to these waters;
(b) what and how many commercial fishing vessels are licensed to fish them;
(c) what type of licences do these vessels have;
(d) what restrictions are placed on their fishing activities;
(e) what nationality are these vessels; and
(f) are any particular restrictions placed on how close these vessels can fish to Norfolk Island itself.
(2) Does any Government agency monitor the activities of fishing vessels in waters adjacent to Norfolk Island; if so:
(a) what agencies;
(b) how many infringements of
(i) Australian territorial waters by unlicensed fishing vessels;
(ii) fishing licences by both Australian and foreign vessels have been detected in each of the last three years; and
(c) what penalties have been imposed as a result of these infringements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Australia has declared a 200 nautical mile fishing zone around Australia and its external territories, excluding the Australian Antarctic Territory. The Australian Fishing Zone (AFZ) excludes certain waters where there would otherwise be an overlap with similar 200 nautical mile zones claimed by neighbouring countries, whether or not Australia has entered into a delimitation agreement with the country concerned.
The Australian 200 nautical mile zone around Norfolk Island abuts the New Zealand exclusive economic zone and the French exclusive economic zone generated by New Caledonia.

Within the zone an inshore demersal line fishery on the Norfolk Plateau is fully exploited by traditional Norfolk Island fishermen. This inshore region has been closed to all other fishermen who may wish to fish for demersal fin fish. The inshore region is excluded from consideration in the remaining answers.

(b) Any Australian vessel with a current unrestricted Commonwealth Fishing Boat Licence may fish for pelagic species in these waters but few, if any, fish the area because of its remoteness and unproven resources.

An offshore trawl fishery outside the Norfolk Plateau was established under new management arrangements which came into effect on 1 April 1990. Under the arrangements no long term entitlements have been issued to fish commercially for demersal species in these waters. One application to undertake short term exploratory trawling has been approved.

Under access arrangements applying from 15 December 1989 to 31 October 1990, 250 Japanese longliners are permitted to operate in the AFZ. If any of these vessels choose to fish in the portion of the AFZ surrounding Norfolk Island they may do so but in the past few have fished the area.
(c) For vessels engaging in demersal fishing, a current Commonwealth Fishing Boat Licence is required with an endorsement specifically permitting either trawling or line fishing.
Japanese tuna longline vessels hold Foreign Fishing Boat licences issued under an agreement between the Governments of Australia and Japan.
(d) As of 1 April 1990, the limitations set out in Fisheries Notice NIF 1 apply to these waters for dermersal fishing.
There are no specific restrictions on pelagic fishing by holders of an unrestricted Commonwealth Fishing Boat Licence.

Japanese tuna longline vessels are currently permitted to take all species of tuna and billfish by longlining, together with all other species of finfish which are incidentally caught. These vessels are not permitted to fish within 35 nautical miles of the Norfolk Island baseline.
A number of other conditions also apply to Japanese tuna longline operations, including radio reporting of catch and position ever two days and the carriage of official observers as required.
(e) The exploratory trawling operation which has been approved is a joint venture between an Australian company and a Japanese company using a Japanese vessel.
The only other vessels currently permitted to fish commercially in these waters are licensed Japanese longliners.

(f) The vessel approved to undertake exploratory trawling must remain outside a rectangle of approximately 30 nautical miles by 50 nautical miles around the Island, which prevents trawling on the Norfolk Island Plateau and slope areas.
Appropriately licensed Japanese vessels are not permitted to fish closer than 35 nautical miles from the Norfolk Island baseline.

(2) (a) The Australian Fisheries Service (AFS) is responsible for monitoring the activities of commercial fishing vessels in the waters of the AFZ adjacent to Norfolk Island. AFS and the Norfolk Island Government have recently cooperated on a project to install radar on the Island which will allow Norfolk Islanders to participate further in the surveillance of their adjacent waters.
Both the RAAF and RAN carry out periodic surveillance of the area and enforcement activities as required on behalf of AFS. Coastwatch is responsible for coordinating these activities.
(b) The surveillance and enforcement program has not detected any infringements of Australian fisheries laws in Australian territorial waters adjacent to Norfolk Island in the past three years.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Primary Industries and Energy: Surveys

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 22 December 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's Department undertaken any market research, opinion polls or surveys over the last 2 financial years: if so, in each case: (a) what was the title of the project; (b) what was the total cost; (c) what was the name of, and sum paid to, the agency involved and were tenders called; (d) what was the date of the project and what period did it cover; and (e) did the Office of Government Information and Advertising assist; if so, how.

(2) What market research, opinion polls or surveys does the Minister's Department propose to undertake in the next 6 months, and in each case: (a) what is the title of the proposed project; (b) what is projected cost of the project; (c) will an agency be appointed; if so, will tenders be called; and (d) over what period and what date(s) will the project be undertaken.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy has undertaken these activities over the last 2 financial years. Details are:
(A) (a) Year and Decade of Soil Conservation (later renamed Year and Decade of Landcare).

(b) Total cost is $75,000 of which $37,710 was expended in June 1989 for Stages A and B (developing a communications strategy and the initial benchmark reading of community awareness and attitudes toward land degradation), and the balance is to be expended on satisfactory completion of the assignment.
(c) The market research company is Lenehan, Lynton, Bloom and Blaxland (LLBB). LLBB have been paid $37,710 to date (see above). Tenders were called.
(d) Project commenced on 30 May 1989 and Stages A and B were completed in August 1989. Completion of the final stage is dependent on finalisation of the advertising concepts.

(e) The Office of Government Information and Advertising assisted by assessing existing research and providing a short-list of four market research companies for the task of compiling additional qualitative and quantitative research needed to underpin the campaign.
(B) (a) ``Demand for Australian Black Coal to 1995''-a study of Australian black coal demand by a joint Australian coal industry working party.
(b) Total direct costs around $15,000 (publication of reports).
(d) Project undertaken between early 1988 and December 1989, projecting coal demand to 1995.
(C) (a) 1988-Quarantine Awareness and Attitude comparative study. 1989-Quarantine Awareness and Attitude comparative study.
(c) The Public Policy Research Centre, a division of Yann Campbell Hoare Wheeler.

(d) Surveys were conducted in May-June 1988, and April-May 1989. They were concerned with establishing indices of public awareness and attitudes at the time the survey was undertaken, and charting any significant shifts against trends identified in previous surveys.
(e) The Office of Government Information and Advertising (OGIA) assisted in the selection of the research agency and was closely involved in the subsequent analysis of findings.
(2) The Department of Primary Industries and Energy proposes to undertake the following activities in the next six months:
(A) Year and Decade of Landcare-completion of the projection described at (1a). See (1a) (a)-(d).
(B) (a) Corporate Identity-Market research to provide data on community perceptions of the Department and the services it provides.
(c) Yes an agency will be appointed. Tenders will not be called.
(D) (a) Demand for Australian black coal-further studies along the lines described at (1b) are under consideration. No definite proposals are available at this stage.
(E) (a) A further survey of public awareness of the attitudes towards Quarantine is to be conducted in April-May 1990.
(b) $18,000 has been allocated for the survey.
(c) The agency which conducted the ``benchmark'' and initial comparative study will be commissioned to undertake the study.
(d) The study will seek to establish the situation as at the date the study is undertaken.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 21 November 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In relation to the plebiscite to be conducted in the eastern Arnhem Land area to determine whether Aboriginal people in the area which to have a separate land council:
(a) what is the text and layout of the ballot paper proposed to be used;
(b) who designed the ballot paper;
(c) were Aboriginal people consulted in the course of design of the ballot paper; if so, who;
(d) what provision does the ballot paper make to allow illiterate persons to record a valid vote; and
(e) is the estimated cost of the plebiscite $50 000.
(2) What is the text of a letter, alleged to have been signed by 14 elders, complaining about arrangements for the plebiscite, and who are the signatories.
(3) Is the plebiscite to be conducted in accordance with the electoral provisions of the ATSIC legislation and related regulations and rules; if no, why not.

(4) What is the nature of the information conveyed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs by the Australian Electoral Commissioner in relation to the plebiscite and, in particular, did the Commissioner recommend the indefinite postponement of the plebiscite.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) A copy of the proposed ballot paper is at Attachment ``A''.
[NOT INCLUDED ON DATABASE - SEE HARD COPY, PAGE 188]
(b) The ballot paper was designed jointly by officers of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and officers of the Australian Electoral Commission.
(c) In designing the ballot paper officers drew on experience gained in conducting elections involving Aboriginal people.
(d) The plebiscite rules, approved by the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, allow for assisted votes.

In summary the rules allow for the Presiding Officer (in the presence of scrutineers, or another polling official) to mark the ballot paper for the voter and subsequently to complete the declaration envelope which is read to the voter.

(e) The initial plebiscite cost estimate which formed the basis of the bid for funds was $21,000. A subsequent bid for an additional $7,000 was made. With unforseen contingencies included the plebiscite could have cost approximately $28,000.
(2) The text of the letter received by the Electoral Commissioner is at Attachment ``B''.

We, the undersigned, senior spokespersons for Numbulwar, Bickerton Island, Angurugu, Ngukurr and Umbakumba, write to request that you withdraw your office from holding the plebiscite scheduled to be conducted in this area 14-17th November 1989.

As you are aware, the Land Rights Act makes no mention of a plebescite, a ballot, a vote or the Electoral Office playing a role in this matter. We feel very strongly that by doing this favour for Mr Hand/N.L.C., you are being duped by vested interests and contributing to unacceptable political unrest in all our communities.
Our request for the Electoral Office to withdraw from the separate Land Council debate and let D.A.A. fulfil their obligations to us Aboriginal people is based on the following points.
(1) The separate Tiwi Land Council formation under the present Land Rights Act required no plebiscite. The Tiwi set the precedent.
(2) The Land Rights Act makes no mention of a plebiscite, voting, ballot or the Electoral Office.

(3) D.A.A. has at least three reports from its senior officers over the past 12 months, all reports say the same thing. All Aboriginal people want a separate S.E. Arnhem Land Council and no one wants an outside plebiscite.
(4) The plebiscite is in contempt of our petition, signed by over 1,000 Aboriginal people, to the Governor-General. (A copy can be provided)
(5) There are already serious breaches of the plebiscite rules.
(6) The plebiscite rules map shows an incorrect S.W. boundary that has confused everybody here and D.A.A. It is not the boundary the D.A.A. consultant recommended.
(7) The ballot paper designed by a D.A.A. ``expert'' disenfranchises nearly all senior Aboriginal people-it demands literacy as a skill.
(8) There will be no scrutineers or supervisors provided by any of our communities.
(9) There will be no acceptable disputes committee formed. (see attached)

(10) The voter qualifications are wrong and will cause arguments, fights and violence on the day and after. There are fights here now on this matter. Are you going to be responsible for any deaths and injury over this problem on the day and in the future?
(11) The N.L.C. are playing political games-see attached letter where they oppose the plebiscite to the Minister but publicly support it.
(12) Our F.O.I. for D.A.A. files and officers diaries will not be through before the plebiscite. Another denial of natural justice for us Aboriginals.

We will totally boycott the plebiscite. An absolute moratorium across all S.E. Arnhem Land. We have consistently stated this for six months. D.A.A. knows and have not told you. The plebiscite will be a $50,000 unnecessary waste of tax payers money.
If the plebiscite goes ahead against the Land Rights Act and all Aboriginal people we represent, there will be big trouble.
The media will tell all of Australia of the tragedy which takes place on this day of your making.
Please reconsider and make D.A.A. do its job.
(3) The separate rules for the plebiscite were approved by the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.
(4) The Electoral Commissioner did not convey any information to the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in relation to the plebiscite or its postponement.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Airline Pilots Dispute: Use of Military Aircraft

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 23 November 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many military tasks or exercises have been cancelled or postponed in order to free up military aircraft to deal with the pilots' dispute between 24 August and 24 October 1989.
(2) What is the breakdown of Navy, Army and Air Force tasks and exercises that have been cancelled or postponed from 24 August till 24 October 1989.
(3) What is the estimated cost to the Department of Defence for all costs incurred as a result of the pilots' dispute between 24 August and 24 October 1989.
(4) What is the difference between the cost to the Department of Defence between 24 August and 24 October 1989 and the funds accrued by the Department from the cost of charter over the same period.
(5) Will the Minister be recovering the total expense incurred by the Department of Defence at the additional estimates in April 1990.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There were a total of 63 planned ADF activities which were affected by the removal of their air support due to the assistance to the civil airlines. However, only 14 tasks were totally cancelled. Of particular significance in the cancelled tasks was the cancellation of most of the planned Naval HS748 electronic warfare training. The majority of other tasks were either delayed or had movement support provided by some other means. A full breakdown of the tasks and exercises affected is contained in TABLE 1.

It should be noted that the table contains only those activities which were programmed prior to the commencement of the support operations. There were activities which could have been expected to be programmed during the period, but which were not undertaken due to the known lack of aircraft. The full number and nature of these activities will never be known but one major area was the movement of duty personnel; alternate methods had to be found to move personnel on courses, postings and entitled leave.
Overall, the effect on Army operations was not as significant as might have been expected as the disruptions occurred in a reduced activity period following Exercise Kangaroo 89.
(2) The breakdown of Navy, Army and Air Force tasks is at Table 1.

(3) The estimated cost for all costs incurred as a result of providing assistance to the airlines between 24 August and 24 October 1989 was $10,969,406.18. This included the costs of some items, in particular fuel, which the airlines had agreed to meet directly but in the event could not.
(4) The difference between the cost to the Department of Defence and the recoveries which accrued to the Department between 24 August and 24 October 1989 was $713,858.

(5) $0.817m has been included for supplementation in the Department of Defence's Additional Estimates for 1989/90. This amount represents the total shortfall between recoveries to Defence and actual costs for the total period of Operation Immune, and includes the shortfall for the period between 24 August and 24 October 1989.
